2016-11-01.lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — The 911 call began with about six seconds of Arabic, and then Omar Mateen switched to English: “I want to let you know, I’m in Orlando, and I did the shooting.”

2016-11-01.lead_paragraph: ESCALANTE, Utah — With the jury acquittals last week of Ammon and Ryan Bundy and their accomplices in the 41-day armed takeover of the Malheur National Wildlife Refuge in Oregon last winter, the lives of federal land managers in the American West got a whole lot more difficult.
2016-11-01.headline_main: Bundy Verdict Puts a Target on the Backs of Federal Workers

2016-11-01.abstract: A Trump victory probably would lead to an immediate market sell-off, the direction in the days and weeks that follow is not clear.

2016-11-01.lead_paragraph: Assume, for a moment, that Donald J. Trump wins the presidency.
2016-11-01.headline_main: What Happens to the Markets if Donald Trump Wins?

2016-11-01.abstract: With an inscrutable letter, the F.B.I. director undermined trust in top law enforcement agencies and unleashed innuendo on the Clinton campaign.
2016-11-01.snippet: With an inscrutable letter, the F.B.I. director undermined trust in top law enforcement agencies and unleashed innuendo on the Clinton campaign.
2016-11-01.lead_paragraph: Four days after James Comey, the F.B.I. director, sent Congress a brief, inscrutable, election-shaking letter about emails that may or may not be new or relevant to the previously concluded investigation into Hillary Clinton’s private email server, his logic makes even less sense than it did on Friday.
2016-11-01.headline_main: James Comey’s Big Mistake

2016-11-01.abstract: Unlike Bitcoin, Zcash transactions can be confirmed without recording the addresses involved, which could make it harder to win support from regulators and bankers.
2016-11-01.snippet: Unlike Bitcoin, Zcash transactions can be confirmed without recording the addresses involved, which could make it harder to win support from regulators and bankers.
2016-11-01.lead_paragraph: Speculators are snapping up a new virtual currency known as Zcash that was designed by university academics and built to be all but untraceable.
2016-11-01.headline_main: Zcash, a Harder-to-Trace Virtual Currency, Generates Price Frenzy

2016-11-01.abstract: Prosecutors in the George Washington Bridge case have repeatedly brought up Gov. Chris Christie’s name even though his two former aides, and not he, are on trial.
2016-11-01.snippet: Prosecutors in the George Washington Bridge case have repeatedly brought up Gov. Chris Christie’s name even though his two former aides, and not he, are on trial.
2016-11-01.lead_paragraph: NEWARK — Prosecutors opened the case against two former aides to Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey with a stunning assertion: The governor himself knew during the lane closings at the George Washington Bridge that they were meant to punish a mayor for declining to endorse him.
2016-11-01.headline_main: Bridge Case Verdict May Hinge on Officials Who Weren’t Tried

2016-11-01.abstract: Thanks to a maneuver later outlawed by Congress, Mr. Trump potentially escaped paying tens of millions of dollars in federal personal income taxes.
2016-11-01.snippet: Thanks to a maneuver later outlawed by Congress, Mr. Trump potentially escaped paying tens of millions of dollars in federal personal income taxes.
2016-11-01.lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump proudly acknowledges he did not pay a dime in federal income taxes for years on end. He insists he merely exploited tax loopholes legally available to any billionaire — loopholes he says Hillary Clinton failed to close during her years in the United States Senate. “Why didn’t she ever try to change those laws so I couldn’t use them?” Mr. Trump asked during a campaign rally last month.
2016-11-01.headline_main: Donald Trump Used Legally Dubious Method to Avoid Paying Taxes

2016-11-01.abstract: The Associated Press poll once determined the national champion, but now the playoff selection committee, set to release its initial 2016 rankings on Tuesday, has the definitive list.
2016-11-01.snippet: The Associated Press poll once determined the national champion, but now the playoff selection committee, set to release its initial 2016 rankings on Tuesday, has the definitive list.
2016-11-01.lead_paragraph: For the past three weeks, No. 1 Alabama has claimed 60 of the 61 first-place votes in the weekly Associated Press college football poll. The only dissenter has stubbornly stuck with No. 2 Michigan.
2016-11-01.headline_main: A.P. Poll About to Take a Back Seat to College Football Playoff Rankings

2016-11-01.abstract: Some women are choosing to defy medical advice and social convention after mastectomies, saying they would rather live without breasts than undergo more surgery.
2016-11-01.snippet: Some women are choosing to defy medical advice and social convention after mastectomies, saying they would rather live without breasts than undergo more surgery.
2016-11-01.lead_paragraph: Before Debbie Bowers had surgery for breast cancer, her doctor promised that insurance would pay for reconstruction, and said she could “even go up a cup size.” But Ms. Bowers did not want a silicone implant or bigger breasts.
2016-11-01.headline_main: ‘Going Flat’ After Breast Cancer

2016-11-01.abstract: Hillary Clinton’s reaction to the F.B.I. director has echoes in the response to Kenneth W. Starr, the independent prosecutor who spent years investigating Bill Clinton’s administration.
2016-11-01.snippet: Hillary Clinton’s reaction to the F.B.I. director has echoes in the response to Kenneth W. Starr, the independent prosecutor who spent years investigating Bill Clinton’s administration.
2016-11-01.lead_paragraph: Bill and Hillary Clinton argued that the man in charge of the investigation had grossly overreached. He had been motivated by politics rather than public service. And he had no damaging information to support his relentless pursuit and the daily negative headlines it generated.
2016-11-01.headline_main: For the Clintons, Two Investigations, One Protective Reflex

2016-11-01.abstract: Though Mr. Comey acted publicly, while J. Edgar Hoover maneuvered in secret, Hoover was the last F.B.I. director to be accused of trying to influence a presidential election.
2016-11-01.snippet: Though Mr. Comey acted publicly, while J. Edgar Hoover maneuvered in secret, Hoover was the last F.B.I. director to be accused of trying to influence a presidential election.
2016-11-01.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Since President Obama named James B. Comey director of the F.B.I. in 2013, the 6-foot-8 former prosecutor has spoken often of dark chapters in the bureau’s history, notably J. Edgar Hoover’s order to wiretap the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and use the tapes to try to drive the civil rights leader to suicide.
2016-11-01.headline_main: James Comey Role Recalls Hoover’s F.B.I., Fairly or Not

2016-11-01.abstract: Through five games, the World Series has attracted an average of 19.3 million viewers, the most since 2004, when Boston won its first title in 86 years.
2016-11-01.snippet: Through five games, the World Series has attracted an average of 19.3 million viewers, the most since 2004, when Boston won its first title in 86 years.
2016-11-01.lead_paragraph: Through five games, the World Series between the Chicago Cubs and the Cleveland Indians has attracted the most viewers for the Series since 2004, when the Boston Red Sox swept the St. Louis Cardinals to win their first title in 86 years.
2016-11-01.headline_main: World Series Drawing Most Viewers Since Red Sox’ Sweep in ’04

2016-11-01.abstract: Mrs. Clinton’s campaign was optimistic that she would weather the F.B.I.’s review of a top aide’s emails, but acknowledged that optimism of gaining ground in places like Ohio and Iowa was fading.
2016-11-01.snippet: Mrs. Clinton’s campaign was optimistic that she would weather the F.B.I.’s review of a top aide’s emails, but acknowledged that optimism of gaining ground in places like Ohio and Iowa was fading.
2016-11-01.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The announcement that the F.B.I. is reviewing newly discovered emails of a top Hillary Clinton aide has slowed the campaign’s momentum and the hopes of expanding support in traditional Midwestern battleground states. Leading Democratic strategists say the news has caused some of Mrs. Clinton’s more casual supporters to drift away.
2016-11-01.headline_main: Confidence Even as Hillary Clinton’s Momentum Slows

2016-11-01.abstract: After lengthy investigations, officials also believe that a hacking of Democratic emails was aimed at disrupting the election rather than electing Mr. Trump.
2016-11-01.snippet: After lengthy investigations, officials also believe that a hacking of Democratic emails was aimed at disrupting the election rather than electing Mr. Trump.
2016-11-01.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For much of the summer, the F.B.I. pursued a widening investigation into a Russian role in the American presidential campaign. Agents scrutinized advisers close to Donald J. Trump, looked for financial connections with Russian financial figures, searched for those involved in hacking the computers of Democrats, and even chased a lead — which they ultimately came to doubt — about a possible secret channel of email communication from the Trump Organization to a Russian bank.
2016-11-01.headline_main: Investigating Donald Trump, F.B.I. Sees No Clear Link to Russia

2016-11-01.abstract: Some metrics suggest that this year’s Cubs are among the best defensive teams of the last two decades, and they turned in a number of fielding gems to win Game 5 of the World Series.
2016-11-01.snippet: Some metrics suggest that this year’s Cubs are among the best defensive teams of the last two decades, and they turned in a number of fielding gems to win Game 5 of the World Series.
2016-11-01.lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Defense does not usually get top billing in baseball, and it remains one of the harder aspects of the game to measure. But in Game 5 of the World Series on Sunday night, the Chicago Cubs put on a display of stellar fielding that was hard to overlook and highlighted how important good glove work can be to a team’s success.
2016-11-01.headline_main: Defense, Though Hard to Gauge, Gives Cubs a Clear Edge

2016-11-01.abstract: Quotation of the day for Tuesday, November 1, 2016.
2016-11-01.snippet: Quotation of the day for Tuesday, November 1, 2016.
2016-11-01.lead_paragraph: “This city is broken in some ways. We have decided that rather than confront the disagreements and the differences of opinion, we’ll simply annihilate the person who disagrees with us.”
2016-11-01.headline_main: Quotation of the Day

2016-11-01.abstract: Facing deadline pressure, a reporter typed out a sentence in the bottom of the ninth inning in Game 7 pronouncing the Indians the world champions. But the game wasn’t over.
2016-11-01.snippet: Facing deadline pressure, a reporter typed out a sentence in the bottom of the ninth inning in Game 7 pronouncing the Indians the world champions. But the game wasn’t over.
2016-11-01.lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — The Cleveland Indians remain one victory from winning their first World Series in 68 years. But in an alternate universe, the Indians’ wait for another championship is not nearly that long.

2016-11-01.abstract: Mr. Brokaw rose from teenage mail clerk to top mogul at the William Morris talent agency, where he broke ground in the fledgling television industry.
2016-11-01.snippet: Mr. Brokaw rose from teenage mail clerk to top mogul at the William Morris talent agency, where he broke ground in the fledgling television industry.
2016-11-01.lead_paragraph: Norman Brokaw, who rose from teenage mail clerk to top mogul at the William Morris talent agency, where he broke ground in the fledgling television industry for idled Hollywood stars and a black stand-up comic named Bill Cosby, died on Saturday in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 89.
2016-11-01.headline_main: Norman Brokaw, Agent to Marilyn Monroe and Elvis Presley, Dies at 89

2016-11-01.abstract: Mr. Putman turned out hundreds of songs, many of them country chart-toppers, after moving to Nashville and signing with Tree Publishing in the early 1960s.
2016-11-01.snippet: Mr. Putman turned out hundreds of songs, many of them country chart-toppers, after moving to Nashville and signing with Tree Publishing in the early 1960s.
2016-11-01.lead_paragraph: Curly Putman, a songwriter whose teary ballad with a twist ending, “The Green, Green Grass of Home,” became a worldwide hit for Tom Jones in 1967, and whose long string of country classics included “D-I-V-O-R-C-E” for Tammy Wynette and “He Stopped Loving Her Today” for George Jones, died on Sunday at his home in Lebanon, Tenn. He was 85.
2016-11-01.headline_main: Curly Putman, Writer of ‘The Green, Green Grass of Home,’ Dies at 85

2016-11-01.abstract: Ruth Bloomfield Margolin’s puzzle will have you trying to think up your own theme entries.

2016-11-01.headline_main: Choi Soon-sil, at Center of Political Scandal in South Korea, Is Jailed

2016-11-01.abstract: Hillary Clinton has endured many punches but she seems to always come back stronger and smarter, delighting her supporters and irking her detractors.
2016-11-01.snippet: Hillary Clinton has endured many punches but she seems to always come back stronger and smarter, delighting her supporters and irking her detractors.
2016-11-01.lead_paragraph: Donald Trump vs. Hillary Clinton. He is the showman who played to his audience. She is the survivor who kept going after the prize. It has been a four-year journey to a signal chapter in American history. A week ahead of Election Day, here is our essay on how Mrs. Clinton has taken many punches but has seemed to always come back stronger and smarter, delighting her supporters and irking her detractors. (Read our essay on Mr. Trump, too.)
2016-11-01.headline_main: A Survivor With a Steely Resolve That Can Inspire and Inflame

2016-11-01.abstract: The producers said they would agree to describe the nonprofit that commissioned the Broadway musical as it wished in the show’s program if the group would drop two legal claims.

2016-11-01.abstract: Three-quarters of participants in a new study said obese people should exercise more and eat better, even though science says it’s more complicated than that.
2016-11-01.snippet: Three-quarters of participants in a new study said obese people should exercise more and eat better, even though science says it’s more complicated than that.
2016-11-01.lead_paragraph: Americans believe that obesity is tied with cancer as the biggest health threat in the nation today. But though scientific research shows that diet and exercise are insufficient solutions, a large majority say fat people should be able to summon the willpower to lose weight on their own.

2016-11-01.headline_main: François-Paul Journe’s Motto? ‘He Invented It and Made It.’

2016-11-01.abstract: John and Stephen McGonigle create timepieces with a Celtic flair (from designs by their sister, Frances).
2016-11-01.snippet: John and Stephen McGonigle create timepieces with a Celtic flair (from designs by their sister, Frances).
2016-11-01.lead_paragraph: John and Stephen McGonigle’s house was full of clocks when they were growing up in rural Ireland. Their father, a compositor at the Irish Times, had a gift for fixing timepieces and word spread. “Every flat surface had a clock on it,” John recalled. “And instead of pictures, we had other people’s clocks on the walls.”
2016-11-01.headline_main: A Family Affair: McGonigle Watches

2016-11-01.abstract: A joke at a family lunch prompted Nicholas Bowman-Scargill to try his hand at his family’s 170-year-old watchmaking business.
2016-11-01.snippet: A joke at a family lunch prompted Nicholas Bowman-Scargill to try his hand at his family’s 170-year-old watchmaking business.
2016-11-01.lead_paragraph: When Nicholas Bowman-Scargill’s mother made a joke at a Sunday lunch about restarting the family’s 170-year-old Fears watch business, he laughed. The company closed 60 years ago, and its revival wasn’t something he had thought much about.
2016-11-01.headline_main: Reviving Fears for a New Generation of Watch Fans

2016-11-01.abstract: The philanthropist seeks to get contraception to 120 million by 2020, but the effort is running into barriers.

2016-11-01.lead_paragraph: Melinda Gates has made providing poor women in developing countries access to contraception a mission. The Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, which she leads with her husband, has donated more than $1 billion for family planning efforts and will spend about $180 million more this year.
2016-11-01.headline_main: For Melinda Gates, Birth Control Is Women’s Way Out of Poverty

2016-11-01.abstract: The union focused on preserving jobs as much as traditional contract issues like wages, and the agreement mirrors deals it had made with two other automakers.

2016-11-01.abstract: Will the Canada-E.U agreement mark the end of globalization, or a fresh start?
2016-11-01.snippet: Will the Canada-E.U agreement mark the end of globalization, or a fresh start?
2016-11-01.lead_paragraph: The new trade agreement between Canada and the European Union, negotiated over seven years, was finally signed on Sunday after 11th-hour concessions to a rebellious Belgian region that had threatened to kill the entire deal. The question now is whether the agreement spells hope for far larger trade deals in the works — notably American deals with Europe and with Asia.

2016-11-01.abstract: Senator Roy Blunt is trying to ward off an aggressive Democratic challenge from Jason Kander.
2016-11-01.snippet: Senator Roy Blunt is trying to ward off an aggressive Democratic challenge from Jason Kander.
2016-11-01.lead_paragraph: Being yoked to Donald Trump’s campaign has been harrowing for Republicans like Senator Roy Blunt of Missouri, the presumed early favorite now caught in a surprisingly tight race for re-election. “There you go again,” Mr. Blunt snapped recently at reporters who kept asking about his continuing endorsement of Mr. Trump despite the Republican nominee’s serial vulgarities and campaign gaffes. “Asked and answered like 10 times in the last week, and the answer’s still the same.”

2016-11-01.lead_paragraph: One day, Americans who were too young to have followed the 2016 campaign will look back and try to make sense of it. They will want to know how such a dangerous person could have gotten so close to the presidency — a man who spoke of abandoning our allies, admiring foreign despots, weakening constitutional rights, and serially molesting women.

2016-11-01.abstract: The decline in the pound since Britain’s vote to leave the European Union has had a big effect on sales.

2016-11-01.lead_paragraph: LONDON — The effect on the value of the pound of Britain’s vote to leave the European Union has rarely been out of the headlines since the June 23 referendum. But while the markets panicked — an estimated $2 trillion was wiped off world markets the day after the vote — the decline of the currency has proved a boon for Britain’s luxury watch retailers.

2016-11-01.abstract: Alienation between haves and have-nots is made worse by the willful impenetrability of financial jargon.
2016-11-01.snippet: Alienation between haves and have-nots is made worse by the willful impenetrability of financial jargon.
2016-11-01.lead_paragraph: As a rule of thumb, texts aimed at a general audience must be written at a 10th-grade level or below. This is what mass media does, and it is also what many great writers do: Emily Brontë, F. Scott Fitzgerald, Jane Austen, Charles Dickens, Mark Twain and Ernest Hemingway all pass the 10th-grade test with ease. That they accomplish so much with simple tools is part of what makes them great writers.
2016-11-01.headline_main: How Economic Gobbledygook Divides Us

2016-11-01.abstract: The candidate has brought views that used to be unthinkable to the main stage of American politics. Is the damage permanent?
2016-11-01.snippet: The candidate has brought views that used to be unthinkable to the main stage of American politics. Is the damage permanent?
2016-11-01.lead_paragraph: Early this year, when a string of primary victories established Donald Trump as a viable presidential candidate and making sense of him became a matter of some national urgency, one of the more incisive assessments came from Newt Gingrich. At a closed-door meeting of the Republican State Leadership Committee in February, Gingrich argued that Trump was not a conservative but rather an “American nationalist” — one whose success suggested he had found “a formula worthy of study.” He noted how Trump seemed bent on not just vanquishing his rivals but on eviscerating them. “He’s the grizzly bear in the room,” Gingrich said. “He’s not normal.”
2016-11-01.headline_main: The ‘Normalization’ of Trump, and What Comes After

2016-11-01.abstract: For all he gets wrong on race, the Republican nominee got one thing right: The Democratic Party does take black Americans for granted, and that’s a problem.

2016-11-01.lead_paragraph: With the race for the presidency entering its last days, Donald J. Trump last Wednesday once again made his pitch to black America: a new deal aimed just at them. “I will be your greatest champion,” Trump said at a campaign rally in the battleground state of North Carolina. “I will never ever take the African-American community for granted. Never, ever.”
2016-11-01.headline_main: Trump’s Inconvenient Racial Truth

2016-11-01.abstract: Saudi Arabia has injected more than $25 billion into the faltering Egyptian economy in two years, but ties between the two most influential Sunni nations are fraying.

2016-11-01.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — In the tumultuous two years since President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi of Egypt came to power, one ally has kept the Arab world’s most populous country from economic ruin: Saudi Arabia pumped more than $25 billion into the faltering Egyptian economy, dwarfing aid from the United States.
2016-11-01.headline_main: ‘We Don’t Owe Anyone’: Egypt Jousts With Its Chief Benefactor, Saudi Arabia

2016-11-01.abstract: For months, Mekasi Horinek and Deputy Jon Moll have lived the pipeline protests in North Dakota. But they fall on opposite sides, reflecting a community as divided as oil and water.
2016-11-01.snippet: For months, Mekasi Horinek and Deputy Jon Moll have lived the pipeline protests in North Dakota. But they fall on opposite sides, reflecting a community as divided as oil and water.
2016-11-01.lead_paragraph: CANNON BALL, N.D. — The prairie is seething. Work crews are plugging ahead on the 1,170-mile Dakota Access oil pipeline, inching closer and closer to a river crossing that activists view as a critical juncture in their monthslong fight against a $3.7 billion project that they say will threaten water supplies and that Native Americans say violates their right to sacred land.
2016-11-01.headline_main: The View From Two Sides of the Standing Rock Front Lines

2016-11-01.abstract: Adrenaclick, a cheaper alternative, has benefited from furor over EpiPen pricing. But its maker is struggling to meet demand, and a generic EpiPen is near.
2016-11-01.snippet: Adrenaclick, a cheaper alternative, has benefited from furor over EpiPen pricing. But its maker is struggling to meet demand, and a generic EpiPen is near.
2016-11-01.lead_paragraph: As the list price of a pair of EpiPen devices soared to more than $600 this summer, people scurried to find alternatives, occasionally throwing caution to the wind. Some bought cheap syringes filled with epinephrine, the medication in EpiPens; others made homemade auto-injectors, following the steps in a popular YouTube video.
2016-11-01.headline_main: Why the Lone EpiPen Competitor Hasn’t Taken Off

2016-11-01.abstract: A week before Election Day, polarized voters are wary, often without justification, about their fellow citizens and the integrity of the electoral process.

In Texas, some of the voting booths supposedly became possessed, switching ballots cast for Donald J. Trump to Hillary Clinton. And then there was the amateur genealogist said to be committing voter fraud by jotting down names found on gravestones.

2016-11-01.abstract: Juan Echevarria killed a man. He spent 14 years in prison. Now he desperately wants a college degree. Getting one may be the hardest thing he’s ever had to do.
2016-11-01.snippet: Juan Echevarria killed a man. He spent 14 years in prison. Now he desperately wants a college degree. Getting one may be the hardest thing he’s ever had to do.
2016-11-01.lead_paragraph: Around midnight on June 30, 1998, Juan Echevarria, a 23-year-old principal in a drug crew, ran into a crack dealer on a Harlem street corner. What ensued, he later told the police, was an argument over money. In those days, Mr. Echevarria would case New York City in a bulletproof vest, often armed with a handgun and sometimes cocaine and cash, overseeing dealers who sold on the streets and in the lobbies of Harlem and Brooklyn apartment buildings.
2016-11-01.headline_main: Life Beyond Bars: One Man’s Journey From Prison to College

2016-11-01.abstract: Brooklyn is a bona fide cultural capital — but you don’t have to spend a lot to appreciate it.
2016-11-01.snippet: Brooklyn is a bona fide cultural capital — but you don’t have to spend a lot to appreciate it.
2016-11-01.lead_paragraph: Green-Wood cemetery seemed a natural place to spend a few hours in the midst of a hectic urban tour. I passed under its imposing Gothic Revival gates and began heading uphill on Battle Avenue, named after a Revolutionary War battle that took place across its nearly 500-acre grounds. The views of the surrounding area and New York Bay became impressive after just a few minutes of walking. After several days in Brooklyn, I was realizing not just how huge it was, but how flat — so even the smallest changes in altitude provided for some great panoramas. The highest natural point in Brooklyn, Battle Hill, stands (at a mere 220 feet) within the cemetery.
2016-11-01.headline_main: Want the ‘Real’ Brooklyn? Go Cheap

2016-11-01.lead_paragraph: ATHENS — At law courts throughout Greece, people are lining up to file papers renouncing their inheritance. Not necessarily because some feckless uncle left them with a pile of debt at the end of his revels; they are turning their backs on what used to be a pillar of Greece’s economy and society: real estate. Growing personal debt, declining incomes and ever higher taxes as Greece’s depression grinds on have turned property and the dream of easy money into dread of a catastrophic burden.

2016-11-01.abstract: We’re open sourcing our video transcoding API and video encoding presets, as part of our plan to open source our video encoding and distribution pipeline.
2016-11-01.snippet: We’re open sourcing our video transcoding API and video encoding presets, as part of our plan to open source our video encoding and distribution pipeline.
2016-11-01.lead_paragraph: Video publishing at The Times is growingFor the past 10 years, the video publishing lifecycle at The New York Times has relied on vendors and in-house hardware solutions. With our growing investment in video journalism over the past couple of years, we’ve found ourselves producing more video content every month, along with supporting new initiatives such as 360-degree video and Virtual Reality. This growth has created the need to migrate to a video publishing platform that could adapt to, and keep up with, the fast pace that our newsroom demands and the continued evolution of our production process. Along with this, we needed a system that could continuously scale in both capacity and features while not compromising on either quality or reliability.
2016-11-01.headline_main: Using Microservices to Encode and Publish Videos at The New York Times

2016-11-01.abstract: Ben Pentreath lends his design eye to James Lowther’s Lacquer Company.
2016-11-01.snippet: Ben Pentreath lends his design eye to James Lowther’s Lacquer Company.
2016-11-01.lead_paragraph: For a new line for James Lowther’s Lacquer Company, Ben Pentreath (owner of the London shop Pentreath & Hall and decorator to William and Kate) stays true to his reputation as someone who lovingly upends classic British design. A Georgian-style night-stand, for instance, is done in slick olive green with a shocking robin’s egg blue interior. Craftsmen at Lowther’s workshop painstakingly apply 15 layers of extracted tree sap to every piece, sanding between the coats to achieve an impeccable high-gloss finish. “Nothing compares to the depth and richness of real lacquer,” Lowther says, calling imitations “flaquer.”
2016-11-01.headline_main: A New Collection of High-Gloss Furniture and Accessories

2016-11-01.headline_main: Presidential Election: Ryan Voted for Trump; Jay Z to Join Clinton

2016-11-01.abstract: In Cleveland, they recently unveiled a street sign for Charles Oakley. In New York, he has been estranged from the Knicks organization for years.
2016-11-01.snippet: In Cleveland, they recently unveiled a street sign for Charles Oakley. In New York, he has been estranged from the Knicks organization for years.
2016-11-01.lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Charles Oakley pushed his hands into his pockets and peered at the small photo of himself on the street sign that bore his name. The younger version of himself in the photo was vintage Oakley: the high-top fade, the furrowed brow, the familiar blue and orange of his Knicks jersey.
2016-11-01.headline_main: In Exile From the Knicks, but Still at Home in Cleveland

2016-11-01.abstract: Tania León said that going back to conduct her music in her native land is “spectacular” — and moving.
2016-11-01.snippet: Tania León said that going back to conduct her music in her native land is “spectacular” — and moving.
2016-11-01.lead_paragraph: For the first time since she left for the United States nearly 50 years ago, the composer and conductor Tania León will perform in her native Cuba later this month, conducting the National Symphony Orchestra of Cuba in a program featuring one of her own works.
2016-11-01.headline_main: Nearly 50 Years After Leaving, a Composer Returns to Cuba to Conduct Her Work

2016-11-01.abstract: Vegetarian plates in Brooklyn, Augustine in Lower Manhattan opens, and other restaurant news.
2016-11-01.snippet: Vegetarian plates in Brooklyn, Augustine in Lower Manhattan opens, and other restaurant news.
2016-11-01.lead_paragraph: LEUCA Andrew Carmellini, the chef known for the Dutch and Locanda Verde, and his partners in NoHo Hospitality have established several spaces in the new William Vale Hotel in Brooklyn, and this is the main event. It’s Mr. Carmellini’s first trip to the south of Italy; he named the restaurant for a town in the Salento area of Puglia. Chickpea Pugliese with bottarga, black spaghetti with cuttlefish puttanesca, and Sicilian pistachio cake are some of the regional fare. The dining room is wood-paneled. And under the executive chef Anthony Ricco, a wood-burning oven and grill deliver a few pizzas, roasted cabbage with Caesar flavors, smoked beets, and lamb mixed grill with eggplant Calabrese. (Thursday): William Vale Hotel, 111 North 12th Street (Wythe Avenue), Williamsburg, Brooklyn, 718-581-5900, leuca.com.
2016-11-01.headline_main: Leuca, Andrew Carmellini’s Latest, Opens in Williamsburg

2016-11-01.lead_paragraph: With the Broadway season getting especially busy, we’re here to offer monthly help on what you should see in New York. Here, the New York Times theater critic Charles Isherwood offers a look at two adventurous new musicals soon to open and a revival he calls pretty much “perfect.” There’s more: a chance to see Sutton Foster kick up her heels, and a bold take on Shakespeare’s history plays.

2016-11-01.lead_paragraph: This year’s New York Comedy Festival is underway, and one of its shows wants to do more than simply provoke laughter. Specifically, “The New Negroes” and its hosts, Baron Vaughn and Open Mike Eagle, want to challenge ideas about what constitutes black entertainment and expand the discussion about black life in America.

2016-11-01.abstract: The performance artist, who had a popular 2010 retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art, implicitly bids readers to warm their hands on the blaze of her greatness.
2016-11-01.snippet: The performance artist, who had a popular 2010 retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art, implicitly bids readers to warm their hands on the blaze of her greatness.
2016-11-01.lead_paragraph: Marina Abramovic’s first major performance art piece was based on an old Russian drinking game. In front of an audience in 1973, she took a series of sharp knives and stabbed each as quickly as she could into the spaces between her fingers. (In the game, there is only one knife and you take a drink for each nick.) Blood went everywhere.
2016-11-01.headline_main: Review: Marina Abramovic’s ‘Walk Through Walls,’ a Memoir of Masochism and Pretension

2016-11-01.abstract: Mel Gibson’s new film tells the true story of Desmond Doss, a conscientious objector who refused to bear arms but still won the Medal of Honor in World War II.
2016-11-01.snippet: Mel Gibson’s new film tells the true story of Desmond Doss, a conscientious objector who refused to bear arms but still won the Medal of Honor in World War II.
2016-11-01.lead_paragraph: Mel Gibson can be accused of many things, but subtlety is not one of them. Even at his worst — I mean as a filmmaker, not a political thinker — he consistently proves to be an able craftsman and a shrewd showman. “Hacksaw Ridge,” the first feature he has directed since “Apocalypto,” a decade ago, is a bluntly effective faith-and-flag war drama, the true story of a remarkable hero with a knot of moral tension at its center.
2016-11-01.headline_main: Review: ‘Hacksaw Ridge’ Has the Guts and the Glory. But Where’s the Gun?

2016-11-01.abstract: Bette Midler hosts the Hulaween Bash, MoMA P.S.1 hosts “White House of Terror,” and the Harlem School of the Arts holds a masquerade ball.
2016-11-01.snippet: Bette Midler hosts the Hulaween Bash, MoMA P.S.1 hosts “White House of Terror,” and the Harlem School of the Arts holds a masquerade ball.
2016-11-01.lead_paragraph: Costumes aside, Halloween offered philanthropic causes a festive way to raise money and awareness. Bette Midler brought back her “Hocus Pocus” character to life for her annual Hulaween Bash on Oct. 28, which benefits the New York Restoration Project. MoMA P.S. 1 and Susanne Bartsch (center, in red cape) held its fifth annual Halloween party on Oct. 29. And the Harlem School of the Arts held a masquerade ball on Oct. 31 at the Plaza Hotel.
2016-11-01.headline_main: Costumes for a Cause

2016-11-01.abstract: A teenager from a nomadic family bucks gender norms by raising a bird and training it to hunt in this documentary.
2016-11-01.snippet: A teenager from a nomadic family bucks gender norms by raising a bird and training it to hunt in this documentary.
2016-11-01.lead_paragraph: Aisholpan is a 13-year-old girl who lives in Mongolia, dividing her time between a boarding school and her nomadic family’s campsite. With the release of “The Eagle Huntress,” a thrilling new documentary directed by Otto Bell, she may well become something else: a pop-culture heroine with the power to inspire girls (and not only girls) everywhere. It would not be surprising on future Halloweens to spot a handful of Aisholpans, dressed in traditional fur-and-embroidery hunting gear, pigtails fastened with pink bows, amid the throngs of Elsas and Katnisses.
2016-11-01.headline_main: Review: In ‘The Eagle Huntress,’ a Girl From Mongolia Soars

2016-11-01.abstract: Kenneth MacMillan’s ballet, performed by the Royal Ballet with Natalia Osipova, revolves around a woman who claimed to be the surviving daughter of Czar Nicholas II.
2016-11-01.snippet: Kenneth MacMillan’s ballet, performed by the Royal Ballet with Natalia Osipova, revolves around a woman who claimed to be the surviving daughter of Czar Nicholas II.
2016-11-01.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Royalty, revolution, madness, memory. These are the potentially explosive ingredients of the choreographer Kenneth MacMillan’s “Anastasia,” his 1971 full-length ballet currently being performed by the Royal Ballet here for the first time since 2004, and offering the enticing prospect of the Russian ballerina Natalia Osipova making her debut in the title role.
2016-11-01.headline_main: Review: ‘Anastasia,’ a Grand Duchess or a Great Pretender?

2016-11-01.abstract: In this Brazilian film from Anna Muylaert, an androgynous teenager discovers that the woman who raised him isn’t his biological mother.
2016-11-01.snippet: In this Brazilian film from Anna Muylaert, an androgynous teenager discovers that the woman who raised him isn’t his biological mother.
2016-11-01.lead_paragraph: Who are you? That question nags at Pierre (Naomi Nero), the brooding androgynous protagonist of Anna Muylaert’s “Don’t Call Me Son.” This Brazilian film’s title takes on a double meaning after Pierre discovers that Arcay (Dani Nefussi), the woman he presumed to be his biological mother, stole him from the hospital when he was a baby. That upsetting news arrives when the authorities burst into their shabby apartment, slap handcuffs on Arcay, then immediately subject her and Pierre to DNA tests.
2016-11-01.headline_main: Review: ‘Don’t Call Me Son’ Considers Identity and Fluidity

2016-11-01.snippet: A new law in Ukraine required lawmakers and officials to declare their assets, and the results did not inspire confidence in the country’s economic and banking institutions.
2016-11-01.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Many of the lawmakers and officials responsible for inspiring public trust in Ukraine’s economic and banking institutions have little faith that their own wealth would be safe in the country’s banks, according to recently mandated financial disclosures.
2016-11-01.headline_main: In Ukraine, Not Even the Top Banker Trusts the Banks

2016-11-01.abstract: Kemang Wa Lehulere’s work can seem very abstract, but a closer look reveals allusive, layered references to his own personal history and that of his country.
2016-11-01.snippet: Kemang Wa Lehulere’s work can seem very abstract, but a closer look reveals allusive, layered references to his own personal history and that of his country.
2016-11-01.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — High above a gallery at the Art Institute of Chicago, balancing on a bright red ladder, Kemang Wa Lehulere worked intently on a school blackboard, his slashes of white chalk gradually cohering to reveal a rounded form. A video of a cigarette slowly burning played as male voices sang.
2016-11-01.headline_main: South Africa’s Rising Art Star Builds His New Stage in Chicago

2016-11-01.abstract: This MJ Kaufman play centers on a transgender character who finds solace in an enormous tree as he deals with issues of identity, intimacy and family.
2016-11-01.snippet: This MJ Kaufman play centers on a transgender character who finds solace in an enormous tree as he deals with issues of identity, intimacy and family.
2016-11-01.lead_paragraph: Archer, the central character in the transgender playwright MJ Kaufman’s “Sagittarius Ponderosa,” used to be Angela. He still is, as far as his family knows, and he doesn’t tell them otherwise when he goes home to Oregon as his father is dying. At 29, he can’t quite work up the courage to explain to them who he really is.
2016-11-01.headline_main: Review: In ‘Sagittarius Ponderosa,’ New Self Confronts Old

They arrested top executives and corporate detectives the company had hired to track down the whistle-blower. Here is how the events transpired.

2016-11-01.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — Peter Humphrey was in the bathroom of his Shanghai apartment when the police kicked the door off its hinges and knocked him to the ground. Nearly two dozen officers stormed his home. They confiscated files, laptops and hard drives related to his work as a corporate investigator.
2016-11-01.headline_main: Drug Giant Faced a Reckoning as China Took Aim at Bribery

2016-11-01.snippet: The first three teams were, as widely expected, Alabama, Clemson and Michigan. But the Aggies slid ahead of undefeated Washington in the selection committee’s first rankings.
2016-11-01.lead_paragraph: The College Football Playoff selection committee inaugurated a month of debate Tuesday by releasing the initial rankings of its third season. Alabama, the defending national champion, held the top spot, followed by Clemson, Michigan and Texas A&M.
2016-11-01.headline_main: College Football Playoff Ranking: Texas A&M Is a Surprise No. 4

2016-11-01.abstract: “Terms of Endearment” and “Clue” are among several films being adapted for the theater.
2016-11-01.snippet: “Terms of Endearment” and “Clue” are among several films being adapted for the theater.
2016-11-01.lead_paragraph: The recognizable brand of Hollywood movies has led to a parade of musical adaptations and, more recently, a surge of plays. Despite a poor track record — “Breakfast at Tiffany’s” and “Misery” were neither critical nor commercial hits — “Dead Poets Society” and “Terms of Endearment” are both onstage now, and more attempts are on the way. Even Quentin Tarantino has publicly mused about “The Hateful Eight” onstage. In the meantime, here’s a look at movies-turned-plays that are further along:
2016-11-01.headline_main: Plays Coming Soon From a Movie Screen Near You

2016-11-01.abstract: The former “S.N.L.” star Jason Sudeikis plays the stage version of John Keating, the teacher made famous by Robin Williams.
2016-11-01.snippet: The former “S.N.L.” star Jason Sudeikis plays the stage version of John Keating, the teacher made famous by Robin Williams.
2016-11-01.lead_paragraph: Still soaking in the happy haze that surrounds you after you’ve welcomed a new life into the world, Jason Sudeikis was contemplating his expanding obligations as an adult.
2016-11-01.headline_main: For Jason Sudeikis, It’s Time to Seize the Stage in ‘Dead Poets Society’

2016-11-01.abstract: Some studies suggest giving antibiotics to infants may raise the risk of childhood obesity. But the infections themselves may be to blame.
2016-11-01.snippet: Some studies suggest giving antibiotics to infants may raise the risk of childhood obesity. But the infections themselves may be to blame.
2016-11-01.lead_paragraph: Is the use of antibiotics in infancy tied to childhood obesity? Some studies suggest so, but a new analysis suggests the link may be with infections rather than antibiotics.
2016-11-01.headline_main: Infections, Not Antibiotics, May Be Tied to Childhood Obesity

2016-11-01.abstract: An investigation found that a peacekeeping mission failed to act in July as government soldiers carried out an attack on civilians, including aid workers.
2016-11-01.snippet: An investigation found that a peacekeeping mission failed to act in July as government soldiers carried out an attack on civilians, including aid workers.
2016-11-01.lead_paragraph: As South Sudanese troops entered the Terrain Hotel and began attacking the civilians — many of them Western aid workers — who had sought refuge inside, frantic pleas for help to United Nations peacekeepers stationed less than a mile away went unanswered.
2016-11-01.headline_main: As South Sudan Troops Killed and Raped, U.N. Forces Didn’t Stop Them

2016-11-01.abstract: The bank will reimburse more than 250,000 customers after claims they were overcharged for home appraisals ordered after they defaulted on their mortgage loans.
2016-11-01.snippet: The bank will reimburse more than 250,000 customers after claims they were overcharged for home appraisals ordered after they defaulted on their mortgage loans.
2016-11-01.lead_paragraph: In the latest hit to the battered bank, Wells Fargo has agreed to pay $50 million to settle a class-action lawsuit that accused the bank of overcharging hundreds of thousands of homeowners for appraisals ordered after the homeowners defaulted on their mortgage loans.
2016-11-01.headline_main: Wells Fargo to Pay $50 Million to Settle Home Appraisal Overcharges

2016-11-01.abstract: The estate mostly prevailed in a legal dispute with the Rosenbach Museum and Library, which contended that Mr. Sendak had pledged many rare books to it in his will.
2016-11-01.snippet: The estate mostly prevailed in a legal dispute with the Rosenbach Museum and Library, which contended that Mr. Sendak had pledged many rare books to it in his will.
2016-11-01.lead_paragraph: The estate of the author Maurice Sendak has emerged mostly victorious in a legal battle with the Rosenbach Museum and Library in Philadelphia, which had been the repository of thousands of his original drawings and parts of his book collection before his death in 2012. In a ruling in Connecticut probate court, a judge awarded the bulk of the disputed book collection to the Sendak estate, not to the museum.
2016-11-01.headline_main: Maurice Sendak’s Estate Is Awarded Most of a Book Collection

2016-11-01.abstract: Lawyers for Bridget Anne Kelly and Bill Baroni, former associates of Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey, accused the judge of encouraging a guilty verdict.
2016-11-01.snippet: Lawyers for Bridget Anne Kelly and Bill Baroni, former associates of Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey, accused the judge of encouraging a guilty verdict.
2016-11-01.lead_paragraph: NEWARK — Jurors deliberating the fate of two former aides to Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey accused in a bizarre plot to close lanes at the George Washington Bridge sent back three questions on Tuesday hinting that they may be divided.
2016-11-01.headline_main: Jurors’ Questions Hint at Division in Trial on Lane Closings

2016-11-01.abstract: Investigators looking into corruption within the Montreal police force for almost six months focused their attention on a reporter who had no apparent connection to the case.
2016-11-01.snippet: Investigators looking into corruption within the Montreal police force for almost six months focused their attention on a reporter who had no apparent connection to the case.
2016-11-01.lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Investigators looking into corruption within Montreal’s police force for almost six months focused their attention on one of Quebec’s most prominent journalists even though he had neither reported on the corruption case nor had any strong connection to it.
2016-11-01.headline_main: Montreal Police Face a Storm of Criticism Over Surveillance of a Journalist

2016-11-02.snippet: Edgar Oliver’s performance piece delves into life’s evanescence, from the father he never knew to a cracked curb on the Lower East Side.
2016-11-02.lead_paragraph: Edgar Oliver conducts the most extraordinary séances. In “Attorney Street,” his seriously haunting new performance piece at the Axis Theater Company, the phantoms summoned by this one-of-a-kind monologuist are both vivid and elusive, as such manifestations must be.
2016-11-02.headline_main: Review: ‘Attorney Street,’ a Gothic Elegy for a Fleeing Here and Now

2016-11-02.abstract: Having spent his career trying not to pay taxes, why would Donald Trump want to fix the system?
2016-11-02.snippet: Having spent his career trying not to pay taxes, why would Donald Trump want to fix the system?
2016-11-02.lead_paragraph: Donald Trump’s claim that he was smart for figuring out how not to pay federal income taxes was obnoxious when he said it, at least for the millions of Americans who pay their fair share. Now we learn that he was able to avoid some of those taxes decades ago with a tactic that is illegal now and was highly dubious even then.
2016-11-02.headline_main: Avoiding Taxes, Trump-Style

2016-11-02.abstract: With as many as 12 bills in the works, the City Council’s efforts to reform campaign finance laws have some worried that the changes might come at a cost.

2016-11-02.lead_paragraph: Three years after the 2013 elections revealed serious flaws in New York City’s campaign finance laws, the City Council may finally be moving to fix some of the worst problems — but not without including a few changes that would benefit individual Council members.

2016-11-02.abstract: Instead of being back in a production truck at the World Series, Bill Webb is dealing with injuries from a fall in addition to having been battling brain cancer.

The first case involved Donald J. Trump’s campaign chairman, Paul Manafort, and secretive business dealings in Ukraine. The second focused on Hillary Clinton’s relationships with donors to her family foundation.

2016-11-02.abstract: As more people are arrested and media outlets closed, other countries need to speak the bitter truth to Turkey.
2016-11-02.snippet: As more people are arrested and media outlets closed, other countries need to speak the bitter truth to Turkey.
2016-11-02.lead_paragraph: What is unnerving in President Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s march to authoritarianism is how dismally familiar it is: the coup that becomes a pretext for a massive roundup of real and imagined enemies; the claims to be the one man who can withstand the onslaught of foreign foes; the invocation of purported historical slights; the silencing of the news media. The world has seen this before in other countries. The pattern is tried and true; the tough question is how to break it.
2016-11-02.headline_main: Can Turkey’s Democracy Survive President Erdogan?

2016-11-02.lead_paragraph: For those of us who take our passions to the extreme, it can be difficult to find a middle ground. But Mr. Kowalski didn’t start flying to photograph — he photographed to fly, and he did so in order to fuel what he describes as an addiction.

2016-11-02.abstract: The host of “The Daily Show” on his childhood in apartheid-era South Africa and getting comfortable in Jon Stewart’s chair.
2016-11-02.snippet: The host of “The Daily Show” on his childhood in apartheid-era South Africa and getting comfortable in Jon Stewart’s chair.
2016-11-02.lead_paragraph: Your memoir, “Born a Crime,” is a striking depiction of your life in South Africa both under and after apartheid. How has that experience formed your perspective on the divisions we’re seeing in America because of the election? America is the place that always seems to treat the symptoms and not the cause. In South Africa, we’re very good at trying to go for the cause of racism. One thing that really never happened here, which is strange to me, was a period where white America had to reconcile with what it had done to black Americans.
2016-11-02.headline_main: Trevor Noah Wasn’t Expecting Liberal Hatred

2016-11-02.abstract: If you want to be happy for the rest of your life, new books suggest working hard and playing nice; taking it a few steps at a time; watching your pocketbook; and just not trying so much.
2016-11-02.snippet: If you want to be happy for the rest of your life, new books suggest working hard and playing nice; taking it a few steps at a time; watching your pocketbook; and just not trying so much.
2016-11-02.lead_paragraph: I’m a happy person. Here’s my secret: Every day I anticipate things will go horribly wrong, and when they don’t I am surprised, grateful and a little bit elated. For example, today I don’t have a brain tumor! My children can be obnoxious, but they’re not (as far as I know) plotting ways to trigger my life insurance policy! There’s always tomorrow, of course, but right now things look good. I’m the Queen of Low Expectations, and proud of it.
2016-11-02.headline_main: Roads to Happy

2016-11-02.abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on when to renege on a deal with a scammer, what is owed the seller of used goods and whether a doctor should offer to pray for her patients.
2016-11-02.snippet: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on when to renege on a deal with a scammer, what is owed the seller of used goods and whether a doctor should offer to pray for her patients.
2016-11-02.lead_paragraph: I manage my elderly father’s financial affairs and was unable to stop payment on a check he sent to a tech-support scammer. His bank investigated and determined, properly, that they could not intervene because he had signed the check. My phone calls to this company bore no fruit, so I offered them a choice: If they didn’t return half the money, I would report them to the consumer-affairs division of their state’s attorney general’s office and the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, register complaints on websites and so forth. My instructions were that they were to send me a certified check, made out to my father, by a certain date. They did send me a check, which cleared. But it was not certified, and it arrived after the due date. Do I have an obligation to uphold my end of the deal, by not registering complaints about an outfit that is clearly scamming elderly people? Charles W. Mitchell, Parkton, Md.
2016-11-02.headline_main: Is It O.K. to Double-Cross a Swindler?

2016-11-02.abstract: The story of their transactional relationship offers a window on rarefied New York.
2016-11-02.snippet: The story of their transactional relationship offers a window on rarefied New York.
2016-11-02.lead_paragraph: The sensational, spidery plot of the most gripping game of thrones in modern history is best captured by two images. The first is from Donald J. Trump’s extravagant third wedding at his Mar-a-Lago estate in 2005: The junior senator from New York, glowing in gold silk and pearls, smiles up at the mogul in white tie with genuine delight as he says something that cracks up Hillary, Bill and Trump’s bejeweled bride, Melania. Donald and Hillary look “just like teenagers in love” in the flashbulb moment, as David Patrick Columbia, the editor of the website New York Social Diary, notes dryly. The second, more sinister image is from the St. Louis presidential debate last month: A Tang-colored Trump looms behind Hillary like a horror-movie fiend as she makes a point, while three of Trump’s guests in the front row, women who accused Bill of sexual assault, give her the stink eye and Chelsea and Bill sit nearby looking grim. What a difference a decade makes: from a Babylonian celebration, with Hillary and Bill cozying up to Donald, to a seething face-off, with Donald summoning ghosts from Bill’s scandalous past and threatening to throw Hillary in the clink if he’s elected.
2016-11-02.headline_main: When Hillary and Donald Were Friends

2016-11-02.abstract: In just a year, Law and Justice has shown how a far-right nationalist government in Europe really governs — and how far it can push the limits of democracy.
2016-11-02.snippet: In just a year, Law and Justice has shown how a far-right nationalist government in Europe really governs — and how far it can push the limits of democracy.
2016-11-02.lead_paragraph: Last May, Poland’s ruling Law and Justice Party, a right-wing nationalist party committed to upending Poland’s established liberal order, convened an “audit” of the previous government in the high-Modernist Parliament building in Warsaw. Since winning a decisive electoral victory in October 2015, Law and Justice had set about dismantling many of the structural checks and balances designed to prevent a return to the authoritarianism of the Soviet era. The audit, called with little advance warning, was intended to discredit Civic Platform, the centrist, pro-European party that ruled Poland from 2007 to 2015.
2016-11-02.headline_main: The Party That Wants to Make Poland Great Again

2016-11-02.lead_paragraph: MAULVIWALA, India — Desperate to reduce the pollution that has made New Delhi’s air quality among the worst in the world, the city has banned private cars for two-week periods and campaigned to reduce its ubiquitous fireworks during holiday celebrations.
2016-11-02.headline_main: Farmers’ Unchecked Crop Burning Fuels India’s Air Pollution

2016-11-02.abstract: Mark Lyttleton, who left BlackRock, the world’s largest investment firm, in 2013, was accused by British authorities of trading two stocks using inside information.
2016-11-02.snippet: Mark Lyttleton, who left BlackRock, the world’s largest investment firm, in 2013, was accused by British authorities of trading two stocks using inside information.
2016-11-02.lead_paragraph: LONDON — A former fund manager at BlackRock pleaded guilty to insider trading charges in a London court on Wednesday, the British authorities said.
2016-11-02.headline_main: Former BlackRock Fund Manager Pleads Guilty to Insider Trading

2016-11-02.abstract: Need help sorting through TV’s endless array of shows and platforms? Here are seven new ones you should check out and where you can watch them.
2016-11-02.snippet: Need help sorting through TV’s endless array of shows and platforms? Here are seven new ones you should check out and where you can watch them.
2016-11-02.lead_paragraph: TENS of thousands of movies, thousands of TV shows, hundreds of channels, dozens of streaming services. There are more movies and series to watch than ever before and more ways to experience them. It can all be a little overwhelming. But we’re here to help. The New York Times recently debuted a website called Watching, designed to help you decide what to watch. British period pieces, Scandinavian crime dramas, sci-fi adventures, oddball dark comedies — tell us what you’re in the mood for, and we’ll help you find your next favorite show or movie.
2016-11-02.headline_main: 7 Fall Shows You Should Be Watching — And How to Catch Up

2016-11-02.abstract: Recorded just before the death of Phife Dawg in March, “We Got It From Here, Thank You For Your Service” is heavy with his presence.
2016-11-02.snippet: Recorded just before the death of Phife Dawg in March, “We Got It From Here, Thank You For Your Service” is heavy with his presence.
2016-11-02.lead_paragraph: ENGLEWOOD CLIFFS, N.J. — On March 22, at 3 a.m., Q-Tip and Phife Dawg were on the phone. The two rappers — lifelong friends from Queens and half of the influential hip-hop group A Tribe Called Quest — were “yucking it up,” Q-Tip recalled, and talking about a project few people outside their inner circle knew was in the works: a new Tribe album, the first in 18 years.
2016-11-02.headline_main: Loss Haunts A Tribe Called Quest’s First Album in 18 Years

2016-11-02.abstract: Jill Barton, an Australian nurse, faces resistance in a poor community that has long seen horses and donkeys as a source of income, with little regard for their pain.
2016-11-02.snippet: Jill Barton, an Australian nurse, faces resistance in a poor community that has long seen horses and donkeys as a source of income, with little regard for their pain.
2016-11-02.lead_paragraph: GIZA, Egypt — In a dank stable in the shadow of the Pyramids, a stallion lay on the ground, his broken leg at an odd angle despite the cast wrapped around it.
2016-11-02.headline_main: Treating Battered Horses in the Shadow of Egypt’s Pyramids

2016-11-02.abstract: From the archives of The International Herald Tribune: The leader of the Soviet party, Leonid I. Breznev, attacks Communist China and praises Josef Stalin in Tbilisi, Georgia, in November 1966.
2016-11-02.snippet: From the archives of The International Herald Tribune: The leader of the Soviet party, Leonid I. Breznev, attacks Communist China and praises Josef Stalin in Tbilisi, Georgia, in November 1966.
2016-11-02.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Soviet party leader Leonid I. Breznev today attacked Communist China and praised Stalin, a hero of China’s current cultural revolution, as an Old Bolshevik who played an important role in the 1917 revolution. Soviet history books never have denied Stalin’s revolutionary role. But since the de-Stalinization campaign began in 1956, it has been extremely rare for any Kremlin leader to give unqualified public praise to the late dictator.
2016-11-02.headline_main: 1966: Josef Stalin Makes a Comeback in Russia

2016-11-02.abstract: I hope my children grow up thinking it’s normal to have a woman lead the country.
2016-11-02.snippet: I hope my children grow up thinking it’s normal to have a woman lead the country.
2016-11-02.lead_paragraph: GREAT FALLS, Va. — When I was in third grade, my teacher asked who among us wanted to run for class president. I raised my hand along with a few boys, and the teacher told me to come to the front of the class. He turned me around to face the class and slapped my hands with a ruler, hard, and said, “That’s for thinking that a girl can be president of anything.”
2016-11-02.headline_main: Why America Needs a Female President

2016-11-02.abstract: After my struggle with postpartum depression, it’s not just a race. It’s a celebration of how far my family has come.
2016-11-02.snippet: After my struggle with postpartum depression, it’s not just a race. It’s a celebration of how far my family has come.

2016-11-02.headline_main: Running a Marathon With a Daughter to Cheer Me on

2016-11-02.lead_paragraph: There have been surprisingly few election polls since the F.B.I. director James Comey’s letter to Congress last week. The dearth of polls has actually been a pattern all year: The number of live-interview polls in the battleground states fell to 36 from 80 compared with a similar period in 2012, according to FiveThirtyEight’s Harry Enten.

2016-11-02.lead_paragraph: Holdings of artworks by Lee Krasner, a leading — though largely unsung — Abstract Expressionist painter and the widow of Jackson Pollock, will now be represented by the Paul Kasmin Gallery, the Pollock-Krasner Foundation announced Wednesday.
2016-11-02.headline_main: Keeping Lee Krasner Visible: Foundation Chooses New Gallery

2016-11-02.abstract: With a history as rich as it has been dramatic, Valletta has become a laid-back coastal destination with a thriving creative class.
2016-11-02.snippet: With a history as rich as it has been dramatic, Valletta has become a laid-back coastal destination with a thriving creative class.
2016-11-02.lead_paragraph: People love to invade Malta. The Mediterranean island nation, situated between Sicily and Tunisia, counts among its unwelcome guests the Romans, the Ottomans, Napoleon and, in the early 20th century, hundreds of Russian aristocrats fleeing the fall of the czarist autocracy. For the most part, the Maltese were having none of this. Napoleon was forced out after just two years, and the Knights of Malta — effectively, and against all odds — defeated the Ottoman Empire’s much larger forces. In Valletta, Malta’s capital, people still bring up the Great Siege with enormous pride, boasting about it as if they had actually been there.
2016-11-02.headline_main: Malta’s Emerging Capital by the Sea

2016-11-02.abstract: The election is around the corner, but don’t just sit on the couch watching prognosticators shout: Get into the kitchen!
2016-11-02.snippet: The election is around the corner, but don’t just sit on the couch watching prognosticators shout: Get into the kitchen!
2016-11-02.lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.
2016-11-02.headline_main: What to Cook Right Now

2016-11-02.abstract: Ray McKinnon discusses the themes of his SundanceTV show, which recently began its fourth and final season.
2016-11-02.snippet: Ray McKinnon discusses the themes of his SundanceTV show, which recently began its fourth and final season.
2016-11-02.lead_paragraph: “Rectify,” the critically praised but sparsely watched SundanceTV drama, was never intended for halfhearted viewing. Languid and contemplative — the first season covered a mere seven days — it follows Daniel Holden (Aden Young) as he returns to the stifling confines of his rural Georgia hometown after 19 years of death-row solitude. His conviction for the rape and murder of his high school girlfriend, Hanna Dean, has been vacated because of new DNA evidence. But though he is free, he’s not exonerated.
2016-11-02.headline_main: The Creator of ‘Rectify’ on Why You Can’t Watch and Multitask

2016-11-02.abstract: At its core, sexual harassment is about power, and politics is the ultimate power profession. And young people are particularly at risk.
2016-11-02.snippet: At its core, sexual harassment is about power, and politics is the ultimate power profession. And young people are particularly at risk.
2016-11-02.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Claire McCaskill, Democrat of Missouri, got her first tutorial about life as a woman in politics as a college intern at the statehouse in Jefferson City in 1974, when male lawmakers made lecherous remarks to her in the elevator; she took the stairs after that. When she became a state legislator in 1983, the lessons became more explicit when she asked the House speaker on the dais his advice for getting legislation passed.
2016-11-02.headline_main: Why Sexual Harassment Persists in Politics

2016-11-02.abstract: A crop of tech start-ups is looking to capture a slice of the funeral sector and end-of-life care. Many of them are founded by millennials, who have grown up online.
2016-11-02.snippet: A crop of tech start-ups is looking to capture a slice of the funeral sector and end-of-life care. Many of them are founded by millennials, who have grown up online.

2016-11-02.lead_paragraph: The Obama administration’s Syria policy has collapsed under the weight of a brutal assault on Aleppo by the forces of President Bashar al-Assad and Russia. Shrugging off global condemnation, Russia and Mr. Assad have dispatched their aircraft to attack schools and hospitals, singling out civilian targets to make the city uninhabitable and force its remaining population to flee.

Trump any route to the presidency.

2016-11-02.abstract: Many who served in Iraq and Afghanistan are proud of their service but exhausted by its burdens, and they distrust the political class that reshaped their lives.
2016-11-02.snippet: Many who served in Iraq and Afghanistan are proud of their service but exhausted by its burdens, and they distrust the political class that reshaped their lives.
2016-11-02.lead_paragraph: The roster of retired military officers endorsing Hillary Clinton in September glittered with decoration and rank. One former general led the American surge in Anbar, one of the most violent provinces in Iraq. Another commanded American-led allied forces battling the Taliban in Afghanistan. Yet another trained the first Iraqis to combat Islamic insurgents in their own country.

2016-11-02.abstract: A warming planet is responsible for the glorious colors of fall lasting so late in the year, scientists say, but they warn it could have a negative effect on the foliage over the longer term.

2016-11-02.abstract: Carla Körbes, edging away from her recent retirement, will perform three short works as part of Vail Dance Festival: ReMix at City Center.
2016-11-02.snippet: Carla Körbes, edging away from her recent retirement, will perform three short works as part of Vail Dance Festival: ReMix at City Center.
2016-11-02.lead_paragraph: When the Pacific Northwest Ballet principal dancer Carla Körbes announced in 2014 that she would retire at the end of the next season, at 33, it came as a bit of a shock. Ms. Körbes, whose performances were a marvel of musicality and clarity, surely had many more years of dancing ahead of her. New Yorkers were especially stricken — they had had only a few glimpses of her in the past decade.
2016-11-02.headline_main: The Ballerina Who Got Away Comes Back

2016-11-02.abstract: Cleveland is at home, with its best pitcher on the mound. The Cubs counter with Kyle Hendricks, who has a 1.31 E.R.A. in four postseason starts.
2016-11-02.snippet: Cleveland is at home, with its best pitcher on the mound. The Cubs counter with Kyle Hendricks, who has a 1.31 E.R.A. in four postseason starts.
2016-11-02.lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — The last time the Cleveland Indians won the World Series, in 1948, they had two Hall of Famers in the rotation, another in the bullpen, and three more in the starting lineup. The Indians team that will try to win this World Series, in Game 7 on Wednesday night against the Chicago Cubs, is different.
2016-11-02.headline_main: A Game 7, and the Indians Ask Corey Kluber to Beat the Cubs Again

2016-11-02.abstract: This German artist has turned his lens on tulip fields.
2016-11-02.snippet: This German artist has turned his lens on tulip fields.
2016-11-02.lead_paragraph: The German artist Andreas Gursky’s photography has given us aerial views of cattle in muddy Colorado stockyards and a serpentine Grand Prix racetrack in Bahrain. Now he has turned his lens on tulip fields. These works, along with several others never before exhibited in the United States, will be on view at Gagosian Gallery in Chelsea starting Thursday, Nov. 10.
2016-11-02.headline_main: Andreas Gursky’s Vibrant Photography at Gagosian

2016-11-02.abstract: In this adaptation of the movie “The Band’s Visit,” an Egyptian band that arrives in Israel ends up stranded in a remote village after a mix-up at the border.
2016-11-02.snippet: In this adaptation of the movie “The Band’s Visit,” an Egyptian band that arrives in Israel ends up stranded in a remote village after a mix-up at the border.
2016-11-02.lead_paragraph: In 2001, the composer and lyricist David Yazbek, who wrote for “Late Night With David Letterman” for a stint in the early 1980s, told a Toronto newspaper: “I’d always wondered if I could write a song that could get the kind of laughs that a good sketch could get.” His career in musical theater has made that possible, starting in 2000 with his delightful Broadway debut “The Full Monty,” a charming musical that was funnier than the 1997 movie. He has since worked in many mediums, including television and cabaret, but has written a new musical about every five years. His latest, which starts previews Off Broadway at the Atlantic Theater Company on Friday, Nov. 11, is another adaptation, this time of the movie “The Band’s Visit,” about an Egyptian group that arrives in Israel to play a show but ends up stranded in a remote village after a mix-up at the border. Itamar Moses wrote the book, and David Cromer, who replaced Hal Prince, directs a cast that includes John Cariani and Tony Shalhoub. (atlantictheater.org)
2016-11-02.headline_main: Atlantic Theater Company Has a New Musical From David Yazbek

2016-11-02.abstract: Jonah Bokaer’s choreography links each dancer to someone in the Italian dramatist Luigi Pirandello’s “Six Characters in Search of an Author.”
2016-11-02.snippet: Jonah Bokaer’s choreography links each dancer to someone in the Italian dramatist Luigi Pirandello’s “Six Characters in Search of an Author.”
2016-11-02.lead_paragraph: Life can involve game upon game. Jonah Bokaer, a former member of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company, relishes choreographic games. And “Rules of the Game,” his new dance production, is a puzzle of artistic layers. It takes its title from a work by the great Italian dramatist Luigi Pirandello, as well as another play that is being rehearsed by actors in Pirandello’s “Six Characters in Search of an Author,” who find themselves invaded by characters from still another, but unfinished, drama. Mr. Bokaer said that although his creation is plotless, his choreography subtly links each dancer to someone in “Six Characters.” It haunts the production, designed by Daniel Arsham (with new music by Pharrell Williams), with Pirandello ghosts. Mr. Bokaer’s program, which celebrates 10 years of collaborating with Mr. Arsham, also includes “Recess,” a solo, and — more games — “Why Patterns,” in which dancers interact with multitudes of table tennis balls. (Thursday, Nov. 10, through Saturday at 7:30 p.m., BAM Howard Gilman Opera House, Fort Greene; 718-636-4100, bam.org.)
2016-11-02.headline_main: ‘Rules of the Game,’ a Multilayered Dance, Is Coming to BAM

2016-11-02.abstract: Investments in sensor and radar technologies and increased staffing might be the best and most cost-efficient way to patrol America’s borders with Mexico and Canada.
2016-11-02.snippet: Investments in sensor and radar technologies and increased staffing might be the best and most cost-efficient way to patrol America’s borders with Mexico and Canada.
2016-11-02.lead_paragraph: GRAND FORKS, N.D. — Cameras on drones stare down at the Canadian border from as high as 28,000 feet, scanning vast stretches of mountains, rivers and forests for potential terrorists and drug smugglers.
2016-11-02.headline_main: Drones, So Useful in War, May Be Too Costly for Border Duty

2016-11-02.abstract: These R&B stalwarts tap the emotional well as they bring their “King and Queen of Hearts Tour” to New York.
2016-11-02.snippet: These R&B stalwarts tap the emotional well as they bring their “King and Queen of Hearts Tour” to New York.
2016-11-02.lead_paragraph: Depending on the artist, when the personal bleeds aggressively into the professional, it can be a recipe for either messiness or motivation. For Mary J. Blige, the veteran R&B belter who’s at her best when emotionally charged, heartbreak is inspiration. This summer, she filed for divorce from her husband of more than a decade and longtime manager, but instead of cowering from tabloid headlines, she has worked them into her live show. A recent single, “Thick of It,” from her coming album “Strength of a Woman,” is similarly defiant: “Who’s gonna love you like I do? Who will you trust? I gave you too much.” That combination of vulnerability and resilience can be expected when Ms. Blige and Maxwell, the progressive soul seducer, headline Madison Square Garden on Thursday, Nov. 10, as part of their “King and Queen of Hearts Tour.” “I don’t hold back,” Ms. Blige said recently, “and there’s no way I am going to start changing now.” (ticketmaster.com)
2016-11-02.headline_main: Mary J. Blige and Maxwell at the Garden

2016-11-02.abstract: An anti-Clinton tweet is just the latest example. This language reminds women of what we’ve been through.
2016-11-02.snippet: An anti-Clinton tweet is just the latest example. This language reminds women of what we’ve been through.
2016-11-02.lead_paragraph: One night, after the Democratic convention, I caught a train back to downtown Philadelphia. Some men boarded the train a few stops after me, shouting about Hillary Clinton. I took out my earphones to listen. “She’s a slut who belongs in jail,” one of them said.
2016-11-02.headline_main: Trump Adviser’s Slur Is a Sign of Things to Come

2016-11-02.abstract: Yael Stone plays a police detective investigating a vicious killing with sexual undercurrents in a suburb of Sydney, Australia.
2016-11-02.snippet: Yael Stone plays a police detective investigating a vicious killing with sexual undercurrents in a suburb of Sydney, Australia.
2016-11-02.lead_paragraph: Fans of “Orange Is the New Black” know her as Lorna Morello, the hard-on-the-ears, sweetly delusional Litchfield Penitentiary inmate whose romantic travails have kept Netflix viewers in stitches for four seasons. But somewhere beneath Morello’s ruby-red lipstick, cockeyed accent and histrionics lurks the Australian actress Yael Stone. And in “Deep Water,” a crime thriller debuting Monday, Nov. 7, on Acorn TV, she’s virtually unrecognizable. Her face scrubbed bare and her vowels subdued, Ms. Stone plays Tori Lustigman, a police detective investigating a vicious killing with sexual undercurrents in a suburb of Sydney. But when a clue links the case to a similar one from 26 years earlier, Tori uncovers 70 possible murders of gay men spanning decades along New South Wales’s glorious shoreline — and the possibility that the culprit is back at it. “Every day, Tori, you come to work prepared to give up your life to protect others,” her boss says. “But you’ve got a son. Why would you do that?” Some secrets can’t be washed away.
2016-11-02.headline_main: ‘Deep Water,’ a Crime Thriller, Comes to Acorn TV

2016-11-02.abstract: The central bank held steady on rates, but its statement reinforced expectations that officials do not plan to wait much longer to raise them.
2016-11-02.snippet: The central bank held steady on rates, but its statement reinforced expectations that officials do not plan to wait much longer to raise them.
2016-11-02.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve on Wednesday continued its slow march toward higher interest rates, signaling that it remains on track to raise its benchmark interest in December for the first time this year but holding off on an increase this month.

2016-11-02.abstract: Ms. Poitras’s so-called 9/11 Trilogy will be shown, and she will take questions after “The Oath” and “Citizenfour.” Also coming up: the Doc NYC festival.
2016-11-02.snippet: Ms. Poitras’s so-called 9/11 Trilogy will be shown, and she will take questions after “The Oath” and “Citizenfour.” Also coming up: the Doc NYC festival.
2016-11-02.lead_paragraph: With the surreal election season about to end, documentaries move to the fore, starting at the Museum of the Moving Image in Queens with “Pushing the Envelope,” a program of nonfiction films that won or were nominated for Cinema Eye Honors. On Sunday, Nov. 6, Laura Poitras’s so-called 9/11 Trilogy will be shown. “My Country, My Country” follows an Iraqi physician who runs for office; “The Oath” introduces a Yemeni cabdriver who was once Osama bin Laden’s bodyguard, and his brother-in-law, a prisoner at Guantánamo. “Citizenfour,” of course, is her Academy Award-winning account of meeting with the former N.S.A. contractor Edward J. Snowden in Hong Kong. Ms. Poitras (and the cinematographer Kirsten Johnson) will take questions after “The Oath” and “Citizenfour.” (718-784-0077; movingimage.us)
2016-11-02.headline_main: Laura Poitras and Her Films at the Museum of the Moving Image

2016-11-02.abstract: Magnetic inks might be a fast and cheap way to create flexible batteries, sensors and wearable circuits and make smart clothing more skin-like.
2016-11-02.snippet: Magnetic inks might be a fast and cheap way to create flexible batteries, sensors and wearable circuits and make smart clothing more skin-like.
2016-11-02.lead_paragraph: A sports bra that monitors your workout. A suit that lets you swap business cards digitally. A beanie hat that tracks your newborn’s vitals. Smart garments like these hint at a future coming up fast, with wearable electronics integrated into our clothing or even our skin, capable of constantly monitoring our biology and tracking our social interactions.
2016-11-02.headline_main: Wearable Devices That Could Heal Themselves When They Break

2016-11-02.snippet: Carnegie Hall celebrated the composer’s 80th birthday with a concert that warned of technological hubris and showed no fear of seeming dated.
2016-11-02.lead_paragraph: An inventor and master of Minimalism, Steve Reich turned 80 on Oct. 3. And proving that a composer in late career need not grasp at obvious innovation, he celebrated on Tuesday in the soaring Stern Auditorium at Carnegie Hall with three works — even a brand-new one — unafraid of seeming dated.
2016-11-02.headline_main: Review: Traces of Anachronism in an All-Steve Reich Evening
