2016-11-02.abstract: After playing Frankie Valli and Barry Mann on Broadway, Mr. Spector brings his autobiographical “Jukebox Life” to Feinstein’s/54 Below.
2016-11-02.snippet: After playing Frankie Valli and Barry Mann on Broadway, Mr. Spector brings his autobiographical “Jukebox Life” to Feinstein’s/54 Below.
2016-11-02.lead_paragraph: Scattered throughout Jarrod Spector’s opening-night performance of “Jukebox Life,” his entertaining autobiographical show at Feinstein’s/54 Below on Tuesday, were video clips of Mr. Spector as a child performer. There he is as an eager 3-year-old vaudevillian belting the Jolson standard “Toot, Toot, Tootsie! (Goodbye)” with the enthusiasm of the very young Michael Jackson, and as a 10-year-old singing “Mack the Knife.” His parents, he explained, were obsessed with Bobby Darin. Not surprisingly, the grown-up Mr. Spector has a knack for mimicry.
2016-11-02.headline_main: Review: Jarrod Spector’s Jersey Tour, Valli to the Boss and More

2016-11-02.abstract: Music that takes its themes from this election is popping up in albums from Delfeayo Marsalis, Marcus Roberts and Ted Nash, who will perform his work next week.
2016-11-02.snippet: Music that takes its themes from this election is popping up in albums from Delfeayo Marsalis, Marcus Roberts and Ted Nash, who will perform his work next week.
2016-11-02.lead_paragraph: Nine months ago, when the term “election fatigue” had a much more hypothetical ring, the jazz pianist Marcus Roberts released a digital EP titled “Race for the White House.” It consisted of a handful of compositions inspired by the presidential field, each a character portrait in brief.
2016-11-02.headline_main: Swinging the Vote: Jazz Inspired by the Presidential Race

2016-11-02.abstract: The attack, determined to be arson, reinforced fears of potential violence as a polarizing and racially charged presidential race nears its conclusion.
2016-11-02.snippet: The attack, determined to be arson, reinforced fears of potential violence as a polarizing and racially charged presidential race nears its conclusion.
2016-11-02.lead_paragraph: GREENVILLE, Miss. — A predominantly African-American church here was badly burned on Tuesday evening, with the words “Vote Trump” spray-painted on the side of the building, an episode that comes amid rising concerns over possible violence in the final days of a polarizing and racially charged presidential race.

2016-11-02.abstract: National Geographic focuses on climate change through a documentary featuring Leonardo DiCaprio and a series taking David Letterman to India’s unlit slums.
2016-11-02.snippet: National Geographic focuses on climate change through a documentary featuring Leonardo DiCaprio and a series taking David Letterman to India’s unlit slums.
2016-11-02.lead_paragraph: Remember that wave of angst and suspicion among environmentalists when the Murdoch family’s 21st Century Fox paid $725 million to form a for-profit joint venture with National Geographic? The logic of the move for the venerable publishing, education and science society lay in creating a predictable and large flow of money to support its work. The fears centered on the prospect that the Fox News approach to issues like climate change would spill across National Geographic, from the magazine to the TV programming. There were tough staff cuts right away, but where in media companies (including this one) is that not the case these days?
2016-11-02.headline_main: In New TV Fare, National Geographic Sustains Its Climate Focus

2016-11-02.abstract: Athi-Patra Ruga staged “Over the Rainbow” — and introduced his newest avatar, Versatile Queen Ivy — for Performa’s fall gala.
2016-11-02.snippet: Athi-Patra Ruga staged “Over the Rainbow” — and introduced his newest avatar, Versatile Queen Ivy — for Performa’s fall gala.
2016-11-02.lead_paragraph: Draped in billowing, Champagne-colored satin with a haphazard stack of tiaras strapped to his head, the artist Athi-Patra Ruga sprawled on a dance-studio floor in Brooklyn last Saturday, holding court. “There are so many South Africas, and that’s the story of South Africa,” he proclaimed to those listening, the director and chief curator of Performa RoseLee Goldberg among them. He then paused to collect his thoughts; in Ruga time, both a stray millisecond sans speech and a minute-long interruption for dramatic effect seem entirely intentional. “Maybe,” he determined, “I should start with the whole ‘rainbow’ thing.”
2016-11-02.headline_main: A Performance Artist Tackles South African Identity, for a New York Audience

2016-11-02.lead_paragraph: GRANTVILLE, Pa. — It didn’t take long for Jack Morris to regret voting for President Obama. A few months after Mr. Morris, a lifelong Republican, cast his first vote for a Democrat in 2008, he learned that the carpet company where he worked planned to lay off 36 people in Pennsylvania and move his job to Maryland.
2016-11-02.headline_main: Some Who Saw Change in Obama Find It Now in Donald Trump

2016-11-02.abstract: Ms. Parker was 15 when she was drawn to a newspaper photo of a boy at an arts college; later, his play would draw her to New York.
2016-11-02.snippet: Ms. Parker was 15 when she was drawn to a newspaper photo of a boy at an arts college; later, his play would draw her to New York.
2016-11-02.lead_paragraph: I was 15. My dad brought me the newspaper, open to an article about an arts college. A whole department was devoted to what I secretly wanted to pursue, drama, but I was drawn to a photo of a boy. He was close to my age, with unruly blond hair, and looking like a badass while riding a unicycle and juggling. When I showed up for my first day of college two years later, seeing this boy in the flesh was like spotting a superhero in a cafeteria, eating cereal. There he is, I thought. Peter Hedges. That dreamy newspaper boy who juggles.
2016-11-02.headline_main: Mary-Louise Parker: The First Time I Performed in New York (With Actual Egg on My Face)

2016-11-02.lead_paragraph: Does anyone remember when Rolling Rock beer ran a campaign on highway billboards back in 2008, promising that the company would project its logo onto the next full moon? 2016-11-02.headline_main: Review: ‘The Attention Merchants’ Dissects the Battle for Clicks and Eyeballs

2016-11-03.abstract: While Joe Heck was serving his party in Congress, Catherine Cortez Masto was fighting for Nevadans battered by the housing crisis.
2016-11-03.snippet: While Joe Heck was serving his party in Congress, Catherine Cortez Masto was fighting for Nevadans battered by the housing crisis.
2016-11-03.lead_paragraph: The Senate race in Nevada between Catherine Cortez Masto, a Democrat, and Representative Joe Heck, a Republican, is gripping on several levels. Nevada is the only state where Republicans have a solid chance of winning a Democratic Senate seat this year. The seat has belonged for 30 years to Harry Reid, the current minority leader, who is not seeking re-election. A Republican victory would thus be not only a loss for the Democrats but a personal embarrassment for a venerable power broker. It would also be a triumph for the Koch brothers, who say they’re seeking poetic justice after years of being denounced by Mr. Reid for their conservative politics, and are spending lots of money to make that happen.
2016-11-03.headline_main: Filling Harry Reid’s Nevada Senate Seat

2016-11-03.abstract: With its bohemian flair and cultural mix, Brick Lane and the surrounding streets have become a destination for vintage lovers and trend seekers alike.
2016-11-03.snippet: With its bohemian flair and cultural mix, Brick Lane and the surrounding streets have become a destination for vintage lovers and trend seekers alike.
2016-11-03.lead_paragraph: The sinuous, narrow streets and low-slung buildings around Brick Lane in London’s East End were once a part of a rough-and-tumble neighborhood. Nowadays, seedy has given way to charming, as scores of young Londoners gather on the sidewalks or sit on the curbs, happily eating takeout curry from a number of places. Indie rock music wafts through the air, adding to the festive vibe. With its bohemian flair and appealing mix of cultures, Brick Lane and the surrounding streets have become a destination for vintage lovers and trend-seekers alike.
2016-11-03.headline_main: Five Places to Shop Around Brick Lane in London

2016-11-03.abstract: The new phase of turning agreements into a real reduction of emissions starts on Monday at the next major United Nations climate change summit conference.
2016-11-03.snippet: The new phase of turning agreements into a real reduction of emissions starts on Monday at the next major United Nations climate change summit conference.
2016-11-03.lead_paragraph: The Paris climate agreement is, obviously, a very big deal: Last year, nearly 200 nations agreed to take on the challenge of a warming world. Their stated goal was to hold the increases in world temperature since the beginning of the industrial revolution to well below 2 degrees Celsius.
2016-11-03.headline_main: A Global Climate Deal Was Reached. Next Up Is Pollution Monitoring.

2016-11-03.snippet: The de Blasio administration has shut down access to records that had been available to the news media for decades.
2016-11-03.lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio recently called on the State Legislature to rewrite a 40-year-old law that has been interpreted as barring the public release of just about any information from the employment histories of police officers — even some who have committed crimes. The law, the only one of its kind in the nation, is indeed overly broad. But Mr. de Blasio, who ran for office as a champion of transparency, has more latitude in interpreting it than he has thus far used.

It’s true that Donald Trump would have less public service experience than any president in American history, but knowledge is lame. Maybe the Know-Nothing Party in the 19th century captured this spirit in its name — and Trump is the apotheosis of knowing-nothing. In my journalistic career, I’ve never met a national candidate as ill informed, evasive or puerile as Donald Trump.

2016-11-03.snippet: The international community cannot let the war crimes tribunal wither as African nations start to defect.
2016-11-03.lead_paragraph: Since it began operations in 2002, the International Criminal Court has secured just four convictions, fueling the perception that it has been largely ineffectual as a tribunal of last resort for the world’s worst criminals. Making matters worse, Gambia, Burundi and South Africa have announced their intention to leave the court, which some African leaders see as a vestige of colonialism because it has so far tried cases only from  their continent.

2016-11-03.abstract: A simplified take on a Chinese takeout dish that became a New York restaurant classic.
2016-11-03.snippet: A simplified take on a Chinese takeout dish that became a New York restaurant classic.
2016-11-03.lead_paragraph: “It’s just a complete rip-off of mapo tofu,” the chef Tien Ho said. Ho was once David Chang’s chief lieutenant at Momofuku Ssam Bar in New York, and he was talking about the origins of one of the restaurant’s greatest hits: spicy pork sausage and rice cakes, born in 2006. “We would always order mapo tofu from that Sichuan place on St. Mark’s, after work,” he said, “and Chang thought we could make something like it for the restaurant.”
2016-11-03.headline_main: Not All Ragùs Are Italian

2016-11-03.abstract: It’s typically insulting to call a show formulaic, but sometimes the genius is the formula.
2016-11-03.snippet: It’s typically insulting to call a show formulaic, but sometimes the genius is the formula.
2016-11-03.lead_paragraph: During an interview I did with Conan O’Brien a while back, we drifted onto the topic of rules: when it was prudent, as a creative person, to flout conventions, and when it made sense to obey them. As O’Brien saw it, only ever flouting, without a healthy dose of obeying, was unsustainable and, on balance, unfunny. To illustrate, he told me a story, one that didn’t make it into the piece I wrote but stuck with me nonetheless: A well-known comedian with a raucous persona, interested in developing his own talk show, once sought O’Brien’s advice. “He showed me a prototype of what it would be: He comes out, he runs through the audience, he’s never in one place. He’s everywhere, he’s nowhere, he’s wearing different clothes, spray-painting on the walls — total anarchy,” O’Brien recalled. “And I said, O.K., here’s my take: You’re a brilliantly funny person, but you need to be constrained, because when you break those constraints, it’s enormously satisfying.”
2016-11-03.headline_main: Letter of Recommendation: ‘Pinky and the Brain’

2016-11-03.abstract: Should the right to free speech trump our desire to end the use of hateful words?
2016-11-03.snippet: Should the right to free speech trump our desire to end the use of hateful words?
2016-11-03.lead_paragraph: Lawmakers in South Africa want to make hate speech a crime. Backers of the draft law say racist language can violate human rights and is not compatible with the nation’s values. Opponents say that criminalizing hate speech will erode freedom of expression and do little to heal the country’s racial wounds.
2016-11-03.headline_main: Do Laws That Ban Offensive Words Make the World a Better Place?

2016-11-03.abstract: Nineteenth-century diversions could offer some clues about the medium’s potential.
2016-11-03.snippet: Nineteenth-century diversions could offer some clues about the medium’s potential.
2016-11-03.lead_paragraph: The Scottish scientist David Brewster was one of those 19th-century characters with no real equivalent today. An ordained minister in the Church of Scotland, he took an early interest in astronomy and became for a time one of the world’s leading experts on the science of optics. He also harbored a great fondness for popular amusements, and at some point in the early part of the century, he began frequenting a theatrical horror show in the West End of London called the Phantasmagoria. He went in part as a debunker, a skeptic hoping to reveal the secret craft behind the spectacle. But he also sensed that something profound was lurking in the trickery. He suspected that the showmen were exploiting some intrinsic quirks in the human sensory system — perhaps, he hoped, rendering them more intelligible to the scientist. Brewster called the world of scientifically produced illusion “natural magic.”
2016-11-03.headline_main: Want to Know What Virtual Reality Might Become? Look to the Past

2016-11-03.abstract: This film is so giddily enjoyable and visually transfixing, you might forget that it’s part of Marvel’s strategy for world domination.
2016-11-03.snippet: This film is so giddily enjoyable and visually transfixing, you might forget that it’s part of Marvel’s strategy for world domination.
2016-11-03.lead_paragraph: Most Marvel movies open like Robert Downey Jr.’s stand-up routine in “Iron Man” before it goes south. They deliver quips and silky come-hither nonsense, only to end up like a big green monster stuck on rewind: “Hulk smash!” again and again, ad infinitum. In between start and finish, there are moments of levity and discovery in the machined product, but too often you can’t see the movie for Marvel’s action plan. Its latest, the giddily enjoyable “Doctor Strange,” is part of Marvel’s strategy for world domination, yet it’s also so visually transfixing, so beautiful and nimble that you may even briefly forget the brand.
2016-11-03.headline_main: Review: ‘Doctor Strange’ and His Most Excellent Adventure

But instead of dropping bills into a collection plate, the congregants at a large Pentecostal church rose and filed toward the deacons clutching hand-held card-reading machines. With a swipe, they were done.

2016-11-03.snippet: State schools like Alabama are following a new survival strategy: lure top students, boost reputation, raise tuition, go big.
2016-11-03.lead_paragraph: It’s only fitting that the admissions tour for the University of Alabama starts in Bryant-Denny Stadium. On game days, the campus’s iconic quad — a painterly expanse of lawn, majestic trees and bell tower — becomes a crimson and white tent city of numbered tailgating plots, some with electricity.
2016-11-03.headline_main: How the University of Alabama Became a National Player

2016-11-03.abstract: Doing more with less is the new norm. Some public universities are even finding fresh ways to ease students’ burden.
2016-11-03.snippet: Doing more with less is the new norm. Some public universities are even finding fresh ways to ease students’ burden.
2016-11-03.lead_paragraph: Higher education has been an easy target for budget cuts since the 2008 recession, forcing many public universities to lay off faculty and staff members, postpone investment in new facilities and raise tuition and fees (up an average 31 percent for in-state students). State support for public two- and four-year colleges — funding is nearly $10 billion below what it was just before the recession — has begun to recover, though officials at the nation’s flagship universities say that doing more with less is the new norm. Some are even finding fresh ways to ease the financial burden on students.
2016-11-03.headline_main: Bottom Line: How State Budget Cuts Affect Your Education

2016-11-03.abstract: Schools are tacking more and more extra charges onto students’ bills, much of it for basic educational services. Some call it “backdoor tuition.”
2016-11-03.snippet: Schools are tacking more and more extra charges onto students’ bills, much of it for basic educational services. Some call it “backdoor tuition.”
2016-11-03.lead_paragraph: The parade of fees on college campuses never seems to end. There are extra charges to start college, such as orientation fees and freshman fees, and extra charges to finish, such as senior fees and commencement fees. There are nickel-and-dime fees, like $8.50 at Indiana University to drop a class after two days, and large ones, like $3,049 to major in digital media and animation at Alfred State College, State University of New York.
2016-11-03.headline_main: Those Hidden College Fees

2016-11-03.abstract: The new movie in the “Star Wars” universe looks to be an international affair, with actors from many countries, and a story with some familiar themes.
2016-11-03.snippet: The new movie in the “Star Wars” universe looks to be an international affair, with actors from many countries, and a story with some familiar themes.
2016-11-03.lead_paragraph: Yes, a new movie in the “Star Wars” universe is coming to theaters Dec. 16. Yes, that movie, “Rogue One: A Star Wars Story,” will have rebels and droids and Stormtroopers. And yes, the Death Star factors in heavily. But it is the first stand-alone story for the big screen, meaning that it doesn’t directly continue the saga unfolding in the previous films. Here’s what else we know, culled from a variety of sources.
2016-11-03.headline_main: What We Know About ‘Rogue One’

2016-11-03.lead_paragraph: The premiere of “Rogue One,” the first stand-alone “Star Wars” film, is six weeks away, and fans have gathered online to speculate about what treasures the film will hold. What’s the deal with the set photo of a shaggy alien that looks a little like a robo-sasquatch? What are the chances that all the rebel heroes will survive to the end? Is Darth Vader going to murder any of them personally? Oh, and how is this movie going to treat women?

2016-11-03.abstract: A.O. Scott joins to talk about the coming-of-age film. We also discuss Solange’s “A Seat at the Table” and how to unwind.
2016-11-03.snippet: A.O. Scott joins to talk about the coming-of-age film. We also discuss Solange’s “A Seat at the Table” and how to unwind.
2016-11-03.lead_paragraph: Every once in a while a movie shows up that everyone agrees is perfect. This year, that unanimously adored film is Barry Jenkins’s “Moonlight,” about one Miami boy’s coming-of-age. His name is Chiron. He’s poor. He’s black. And he’s gay. The miracle of the movie is how it’s interested in none of that. The only condition it cares about is the human condition. Not many movies about black men share that concern.
2016-11-03.headline_main: The Striking Humanity of ‘Moonlight’

2016-11-03.lead_paragraph: Among the unfortunate headlines about Boko Haram and email scams, it is easy to overlook that Nigeria boasts seven national parks and some of the richest biodiversity in West Africa. Nearly all of that flora and fauna is concentrated in Cross River State in the country’s southeast corner, abutting Cameroon. There, the Nigerian government hopes to have the magnificent Cross River National Park listed as a Unesco World Heritage Site.

2016-11-03.lead_paragraph: MONTREAL — “Canada is back,” says Justin Trudeau, the charismatic and bilingual prime minister of Canada, at international gatherings, seeking to showcase the imprint he wants to put on Canadian foreign policy in contrast to that of his predecessor, Stephen Harper. The prime minister has used very precise terms in his speeches: justice, environmental care, democracy and human rights. He even dared to invoke some of them during his official visit to China in September, although the Chinese did not applaud him for it.

2016-11-03.lead_paragraph: I have never seen someone who looked like me on a mainstream television show. I have never seen someone who looked like me, playing anything but a villain in movies, or in an ad or on a billboard. I am invisible. That is, until I walk down the street. That is, until strangers stare just a little too long and rudely whisper, “look at her eyes.”

2016-11-03.abstract: Her novel “Chanson Douce” is loosely based on the real-life killing of two children in New York while in the care of their nanny in 2012.

2016-11-03.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Leïla Slimani, a French-Moroccan novelist, was awarded France’s top literary accolade, the Prix Goncourt, on Thursday for her book “Chanson Douce” (“Sweet Song”), a thriller that opens with the killing of two young children by their caretaker.
2016-11-03.headline_main: Leïla Slimani Wins Prix Goncourt, France’s Top Literary Award

2016-11-03.abstract: Britain voted in June to leave the European Union, but the process did not begin until the government invoked a previously unused treaty provision.
2016-11-03.snippet: Britain voted in June to leave the European Union, but the process did not begin until the government invoked a previously unused treaty provision.
2016-11-03.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain voted in June to leave the European Union. But the process truly began on March 29, when the government invoked a treaty provision — Article 50 — that set out the basics of a withdrawal.
2016-11-03.headline_main: Article 50: Reviewing the Road Map for ‘Brexit’

2016-11-03.abstract: It’s a country where men use misogyny to destroy their enemies — and get away with it.
2016-11-03.snippet: It’s a country where men use misogyny to destroy their enemies — and get away with it.
2016-11-03.lead_paragraph: Machismo isn’t quite what it used to be. Backlash and hashtags now hold politicians accountable for their so-called locker-room talk in much of the world. Yet the Philippines remains a glaring example of how men use language and law to try to emasculate opponents and maintain power.
2016-11-03.headline_main: What ‘Locker-Room Talk’ Sounds Like in the Philippines

2016-11-03.abstract: Researchers at the Boston University C.T.E. Center said Kevin Turner, who died in March, had the fourth and highest stage of the degenerative brain disease.
2016-11-03.snippet: Researchers at the Boston University C.T.E. Center said Kevin Turner, who died in March, had the fourth and highest stage of the degenerative brain disease.
2016-11-03.lead_paragraph: BOSTON — The former running back Kevin Turner, one of the lead plaintiffs in the landmark N.F.L. settlement over concussions and brain trauma, had the most advanced form of chronic traumatic encephalopathy, the degenerative brain disease linked to repeated head hits, researchers said Thursday.
2016-11-03.headline_main: Lead Plaintiff in N.F.L. Concussion Settlement Had Advanced C.T.E.

2016-11-03.abstract: The search giant faces three cases accusing it of hampering consumer choice and crippling competitors, all of which it denies.
2016-11-03.snippet: The search giant faces three cases accusing it of hampering consumer choice and crippling competitors, all of which it denies.
2016-11-03.lead_paragraph: To many Europeans, Google represents Silicon Valley’s perceived stranglehold on the digital world. But on Thursday, the American search giant tried to portray itself as a stalwart of online competition as it responded to European antitrust charges that it had restricted consumers’ choices and hamstrung its competitors.
2016-11-03.headline_main: Google Rebuts Antitrust Claims in Europe

2016-11-03.abstract: A leader of Britain’s art revival mines the intoxicating atmosphere before ‘Brexit’ unmoored the art world in this show at MoMA PS1.
2016-11-03.snippet: A leader of Britain’s art revival mines the intoxicating atmosphere before ‘Brexit’ unmoored the art world in this show at MoMA PS1.
2016-11-03.lead_paragraph: No one Pauline Kael knew voted for Richard M. Nixon, and no one I know voted for “Brexit.” I lived in London for a little over three years, and that catastrophic British referendum of June 23, and the political meltdown, legal uncertainty and racist violence it has unleashed, have obliterated a place I thought I knew, and left the British art world unmoored.
2016-11-03.headline_main: Mark Leckey Captures the Exuberance of Pre-‘Brexit’ Britain

2016-11-03.abstract: Freddie Mercury, David Bowie and Alice Cooper send signals to a semi-closeted gay teen in the ’70s.

2016-11-03.lead_paragraph: In early 1976, I saw Freddie Mercury stage one of the greatest charades in rock history. He was appearing with his band Queen at the Beacon Theater at a pivotal time, just three months after the release of “Bohemian Rhapsody” but a season before the song entranced the pop mainstream.

That figure accounted for the biggest share of what he described as his income for the year.

A combination of factors contributed to its savagery, among them a mobile population, crumbling public health systems, official neglect and hazardous burial practices.
2016-11-03.headline_main: Ebola Evolved Into Deadlier Enemy During the African Epidemic

2016-11-03.abstract: Overall vehicle sales are down, but affluent Russians spur a demand for more expensive cars and Western-style dealerships.
2016-11-03.snippet: Overall vehicle sales are down, but affluent Russians spur a demand for more expensive cars and Western-style dealerships.
2016-11-03.lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia — The automotive history of the former Soviet Bloc resonates with cars like the funky Lada, the futuristic Tatra, the clunky but lovable Trabant and the luxurious Volga. Then there was the tanklike Zil — always in black — that shuttled Nikita S. Khrushchev and Alexei N. Kosygin through Red Square.
2016-11-03.headline_main: In Russia, a Western Taste for High-End Auto Sales

2016-11-03.abstract: It’s the best way to make sense of the continent’s epic scope, wild splendor and bloody colonial history.
2016-11-03.snippet: It’s the best way to make sense of the continent’s epic scope, wild splendor and bloody colonial history.
2016-11-03.lead_paragraph: JUST A FEW HOURS INTO our train ride, we know the passengers in the cabins on either side of ours: On one side are two young Canadians on a monthslong, round-the-world backpacking trip. On the other are four middle-aged women on a trading expedition from their towns in Zambia to Dar es Salaam, where they’ll buy supplies for their shops, including clothes and spare parts for cars. They’re not waiting to get to Dar to get started: At every whistle-stop town along the way, vendors try to sell things through the window — often produce at prices far below those in the Tanzanian metropolis. So the women are stocking up on items they can sell for a profit when we arrive in a day or two: tomatoes, oranges, passion fruit, boiled peanuts and, just this morning, roasted caterpillars.
2016-11-03.headline_main: The History of Southern Africa, by Train

2016-11-03.lead_paragraph: The widespread use of self-driving cars promises to bring substantial benefits to transportation efficiency, public safety and personal well-being. Car manufacturers are working to overcome the remaining technical challenges that stand in the way of this future. Our research, however, shows that there is also an important ethical dilemma that must be solved before people will be comfortable trusting their lives to these cars.

2016-11-03.lead_paragraph: The Fashion Group International held its annual Night of Stars gala on Oct. 27 at Cipriani Wall Street, where luminaries like Tommy and Dee Hilfiger were honored. The Central Park Conservancy autumn gala took place Oct. 27 under a clear tent at the park’s Naumburg Bandshell. Performa hosted its fall gala on Tuesday at the Altman Building and honored the curator, art critic and poet Okwui Enwezor. And Lincoln Center honored Laurie M. Tisch at its fall gala on Tuesday at the Jazz at Lincoln Center Frederick P. Rose Hall.

2016-11-03.lead_paragraph: We asked students what they would do if they were in charge, what their concerns and hopes for the future would be. Empathy and forgiveness — a plea for more — and climate change were recurring themes, as well as issues political and personal. Here are condensed selections. Add your own ideas in the comments section at the bottom of this page (student submissions will be highlighted). Photos and drawings that interpret the question can be submitted via email, to edlife@nytimes.com.

2016-11-03.lead_paragraph: In the crucible of cancer treatment, the bonding of patients with physicians often makes the unendurable endurable. The difficulty of finding and then keeping the right oncologist can therefore be fraught. Yet this problem, not uncommon today, is on track to grow worse.

2016-11-03.abstract: Honey Hi combines the best of all the health food trends that have become synonymous with West Coast wellness.
2016-11-03.snippet: Honey Hi combines the best of all the health food trends that have become synonymous with West Coast wellness.
2016-11-03.lead_paragraph: Dietary dogma is so strong in Los Angeles that even Dodgers Stadium offers vegan and gluten-free options for fervent-but-sensitive gamegoers. And down the road at Honey Hi in Echo Park, Eastsiders are catching a new wave of nutrition. It’s not strictly vegetarian, vegan, paleo, raw, plant-based, ayurvedic or superfoodist. The restaurant’s guiding principle is what they call a radical inclusivity. But according to its co-owner Kacie Carter, a chef and nutritionist, Honey Hi isn’t a movement, it’s simply “a little cafe with delicious food that makes you feel good.”
2016-11-03.headline_main: A Healthy Dressing Recipe From L.A.’s Newest Feel-Good Cafe

2016-11-03.abstract: Jean Colonna — who launched his business in 1987 — is a spiritual ancestor of some of the most exciting designers currently working.
2016-11-03.snippet: Jean Colonna — who launched his business in 1987 — is a spiritual ancestor of some of the most exciting designers currently working.
2016-11-03.lead_paragraph: Even during his heyday of the early- to mid-’90s, the French designer Jean Colonna was an insider name — but today, his style is all over the runways. In 1993, The Times dubbed him “the popularist of Drugstore Cowboy dressing”: a pithy acknowledgment of his aesthetic, which relied heavily on synthetic fabrics, especially pleather, machine-made lace and machine-sewn sequins, animal prints and brash color combinations of black with violet, hot pink or lipstick red. It looked trashy — it did then, and it does now.
2016-11-03.headline_main: The ’90s Designer Making a Big Comeback — All Over the Runways

2016-11-03.snippet: This new festival, the first for children from the Film Society of Lincoln Center, offers a mix of contemporary works and classics, with movies for teenagers, too.
2016-11-03.lead_paragraph: You wouldn’t expect someone who had just created a movie festival for children — especially one that began on Thursday with a sneak preview of DreamWorks Animation’s cheerful-looking “Trolls” — to heave a sigh and exclaim, “Oh, my God, so many dark films!” Yet that was how Florence Almozini, associate director of programming for the Film Society of Lincoln Center, recently characterized her latest venture.
2016-11-03.headline_main: My First Film Fest: A Mix of Dark Themes and Sunny Attitude

2016-11-03.abstract: The choreographer Gina Gibney work since 2013, “Folding In,” is being performed by her company and ends with five dancers curled up on the floor.

2016-11-03.lead_paragraph: Behind the scenes, Gina Gibney is a force in the New York dance world, presiding over two dance centers along lower Broadway. She’s long been a choreographer, too, and this year she celebrates the 25th anniversary of Gibney Dance. With that comes “Folding In,” her first work since 2013.

2016-11-03.headline_main: Iggy Pop’s Life Drawing Class

2016-11-03.abstract: In February, the rocker posed nude for a group of students from New York art schools. This week, their portraits open in a show at the Brooklyn Museum.
2016-11-03.snippet: In February, the rocker posed nude for a group of students from New York art schools. This week, their portraits open in a show at the Brooklyn Museum.
2016-11-03.lead_paragraph: Ever since James Newell Osterberg Jr. emerged from a Detroit trailer park and reinvented himself as the snarling, bleached-blond, Dionysian rock god Iggy Pop, he has been one of the most iconic figures in music. With his sinewy frame and defiant stare, Iggy’s image has been immortalized by the likes of photographer Mick Rock (on the cover of his band The Stooges’ third album, “Raw Power”) as well as the artists Peter Hujar and Gerard Malanga. “I knew him from the imagery before the music, actually,” recalls the Turner Prize-winning British artist Jeremy Deller. “Even in photos you can tell he has a presence and is clearly quite a character.” For Deller, it was Iggy’s baring of his torso and soul onstage that struck him: “He’s not stopped performing,” Deller says. “From the age of 20 to 69, it’s been a continuous piece of performance art and documentation of his body. It’s interesting to me for a man to parade his body so much, and parade it as it changes.”
2016-11-03.headline_main: Iggy Pop: Musician, Icon — and Now, Live Nude Model

2016-11-03.abstract: Cheating at the polls basically doesn’t happen. But that hasn’t stopped generations of Americans from using it to keep minorities from voting.
2016-11-03.snippet: Cheating at the polls basically doesn’t happen. But that hasn’t stopped generations of Americans from using it to keep minorities from voting.
2016-11-03.lead_paragraph: Early voting is underway, and according to Donald J. Trump, so is voter fraud. Almost daily, he proclaims that “large-scale voter fraud” is happening and that the election is “rigged.” Politicians across the spectrum have criticized this nonsense as divorced from reality, deleterious to our democracy and unprecedented in our elections.
2016-11-03.headline_main: The Voter Fraud Lie We Can’t Shake

2016-11-03.abstract: A generation shaped by transparency, digital storytelling and social media redefines philanthropy.
2016-11-03.snippet: A generation shaped by transparency, digital storytelling and social media redefines philanthropy.
2016-11-03.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It was an otherwise routine bus ride through the Costa Rican countryside several years ago that changed the way Chase Adam thought about what makes people give.
2016-11-03.headline_main: Connections to a Cause: The Millennial Way of Charity

2016-11-03.abstract: Mike Colter describes how the character he plays has changed his wardrobe.
2016-11-03.snippet: Mike Colter describes how the character he plays has changed his wardrobe.
2016-11-03.lead_paragraph: Mike Colter plays the coolest superhero going these days, on the binge-worthy Netflix show “Luke Cage.” Mr. Colter, who grew up in St. Matthews, S.C., let us in on his favorite clothing, explained how his role as a Marvel character has changed his wardrobe, and revealed why he prefers boots with zippers.
2016-11-03.headline_main: ‘Luke Cage’ Made Him a Fashion Hero

2016-11-03.abstract: The bartender’s lucky walnut may not show up in the box score, but. ...
2016-11-03.snippet: The bartender’s lucky walnut may not show up in the box score, but. ...
2016-11-03.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Fifth inning, Game 7 of the World Series, and the Chicago Cubs were comfortably ahead by four runs. What more auspicious moment could there be for an out-of-town visitor to sneak into a friendly bar full of happy fans who were watching their team coast to victory?
2016-11-03.headline_main: In a Bar in Chicago, the Real M.V.P.s of the Series Got It Done

2016-11-03.abstract: Known largely for a forward-looking house he designed in Paris, Chareau gets his due in an illuminating show at the Jewish Museum that features his interiors, furniture and art collection.
2016-11-03.snippet: Known largely for a forward-looking house he designed in Paris, Chareau gets his due in an illuminating show at the Jewish Museum that features his interiors, furniture and art collection.
2016-11-03.lead_paragraph: Discovering the existence of the Maison de Verre in Paris can be a major aesthetic epiphany. When you see a photograph of this translucent structure in glass, steel and expanses of glass brick — completed in 1932 — the impression is of startling modernity, something very much of its time yet strikingly ahead of it, too, like Picasso’s “Les Demoiselles d’Avignon” or Duchamp’s “The Large Glass.”
2016-11-03.headline_main: The Virtual Splendor of Paris’s Glass House

2016-11-03.abstract: Four virtual reality environments at the Jewish Museum delve into every nook and cranny of the designer’s creations, with Gallic touches.
2016-11-03.snippet: Four virtual reality environments at the Jewish Museum delve into every nook and cranny of the designer’s creations, with Gallic touches.
2016-11-03.lead_paragraph: The spare simplicity of the introductory galleries of the Jewish Museum’s new exhibition on the interior designer Pierre Chareau — even the inventive moving silhouettes on scrims there — do not prepare you for the fully immersive virtual reality experiences in the show’s second-to-last gallery.
2016-11-03.headline_main: Going Head to Head With Pierre Chareau

2016-11-03.snippet: Green-Wood Cemetery in Brooklyn will pay tribute to those who tried but failed to make it to the White House with a tour of graves of also-rans.
2016-11-03.lead_paragraph: LET us now consider a particular presidential candidate who made a fortune in business and real estate, who reveled in being famous, who had never held elective office before and who urged his supporters to cancel their subscriptions to a newspaper that had called him an idiot.
2016-11-03.headline_main: Green-Wood Cemetery, Where Presidential Aspirants Enjoy an Afterlife

2016-11-03.lead_paragraph: Opinion columnist Andrew Rosenthal on James Comey, the post-election prognosis, and other news. Susan Lehman is host.

2016-11-03.abstract: An exhibition of centuries-old beads, spheres and pendants, with elaborately carved tableaus, will travel from Toronto to New York to Amsterdam.
2016-11-03.snippet: An exhibition of centuries-old beads, spheres and pendants, with elaborately carved tableaus, will travel from Toronto to New York to Amsterdam.
2016-11-03.lead_paragraph: Dutch woodcarvers once sculpted slivers of boxwood into biblical scenes smaller than walnut shells, and for a few decades in the 1400s and 1500s, elite clients, including Henry VIII, vied to own the miniature works. Yet no one seems to have recorded much about the sculptors’ techniques or even their names. In notes from the 1630s about an antique boxwood sphere with portraits of martyred saints, a Dutch art collector lamented, “It is regrettable that the maker of this ingenious piece has not made himself known with any sign.”
2016-11-03.headline_main: Unlocking the Secrets of Boxwood Miniatures

2016-11-03.abstract: A tour finds traces in Buffalo of the Pan-American Exposition of 1901, featuring dazzling technology, cultural exploitation and the death of President McKinley.
2016-11-03.snippet: A tour finds traces in Buffalo of the Pan-American Exposition of 1901, featuring dazzling technology, cultural exploitation and the death of President McKinley.
2016-11-03.lead_paragraph: BUFFALO — THE Pan-American Exposition of 1901 was meant to celebrate America’s ingenuity and dominance over the Western Hemisphere — you know, when America was “great again.” Eight million people paid about 50 cents each to see buildings edged in light bulbs, sprawled across 350 acres at the suburban northern edge of this city. They also flocked to the nearby Niagara Falls to watch daredevils try to survive the rapids.
2016-11-03.headline_main: Echoes of an Exposition, and an Assassination

2016-11-03.abstract: Adrian Grenier stars in this black comedy from Richard Bates Jr.
2016-11-03.snippet: Adrian Grenier stars in this black comedy from Richard Bates Jr.
2016-11-03.lead_paragraph: “For as long as I can remember, I’ve been waiting for my parents to die, so I could commit suicide without feeling an overwhelming sense of guilt.” With this opening line, “Trash Fire” lets you know that its writer-director is committed to commanding your attention. And also that he has seen, and admires, “Goodfellas,” which begins with a similar phrase.
2016-11-03.headline_main: Review: In ‘Trash Fire,’ a Familiar Formula Fails

2016-11-03.abstract: Two troupes, Nrityagram and Kerala Kalamandalam Kathakali, appeared in New York as part of the White Light Festival’s “Sounds of India” series.
2016-11-03.snippet: Two troupes, Nrityagram and Kerala Kalamandalam Kathakali, appeared in New York as part of the White Light Festival’s “Sounds of India” series.
2016-11-03.lead_paragraph: “You’ve been there?” friends said in envy after Wednesday’s Nrityagram Dance Ensemble performance in the Gerald W. Lynch Theater. Yes, I’ve seen Nrityagram in India, at its home village near Bangalore and in Chennai — and yet the New York audience is in no way shortchanged. These are among the world’s greatest dancers; on Wednesday they gave as complete and fulfilling a vision of their art as any I have seen anywhere.
2016-11-03.headline_main: Review: Dance Arrives From India. If Only It Could Stay Longer.

2016-11-03.abstract: The Fox News anchor and author of “Settle for More” says “Bridget Jones’s Diary” reads “like my own journals from pretty much every phase of my life and made me laugh so hard I cried.”

2016-11-03.lead_paragraph: No sooner did last Thanksgiving end than here we are again, deciding what to serve, how to cook it and what to drink. It worked out pretty well in 2015, didn’t it?

2016-11-03.abstract: The New York Times is inviting readers to take advantage of its reporting, analysis and commentary from the lead-up through the aftermath of the 2016 election.

Readers will have unlimited access to NYTimes.com for 72 hours from 12:01 a.m. ET on Monday, November 7 until 11:59 p.m. ET on Wednesday, November 9.

2016-11-03.abstract: Works created by this German-born artist, who died 40 years ago, have acquired a new energy in the art world.
2016-11-03.snippet: Works created by this German-born artist, who died 40 years ago, have acquired a new energy in the art world.
2016-11-03.lead_paragraph: Last year, abstracts by the German-born artist Josef Albers were selling for $150,000 to $250,000 at auction: not bad for a guy who died 40 years ago.
2016-11-03.headline_main: Delivering Fresh Attention to Josef Albers

2016-11-03.abstract: The bronze sculptures, which he considered to be related to his “Iliam” paintings already at the museum, are gifts of the Cy Twombly Foundation.
2016-11-03.snippet: The bronze sculptures, which he considered to be related to his “Iliam” paintings already at the museum, are gifts of the Cy Twombly Foundation.
2016-11-03.lead_paragraph: The Philadelphia Museum of Art is one of the nation’s pre-eminent destinations for the work of Cy Twombly, who died in 2011 and whose monumental Homeric painting cycle “Fifty Days at Iliam” has been on permanent display there since 1989. Now, a group of five important bronze sculptures by Twombly, which he considered to be related to the paintings, will enter the museum’s collection, gifts of the Cy Twombly Foundation.
2016-11-03.headline_main: 5 Twombly Sculptures to Join His Paintings at Philadelphia Museum

2016-11-03.abstract: The 18th-century artist’s rebellion occurred largely on paper, in strokes of red and splashes of brown that went counter to his training.
2016-11-03.snippet: The 18th-century artist’s rebellion occurred largely on paper, in strokes of red and splashes of brown that went counter to his training.
2016-11-03.lead_paragraph: Among the 18th century’s lesser-known declarations of independence was that of Jean-Honoré Fragonard, the Rococo artist who was a rising star of the French Academy system when he decided, rather abruptly, that he’d had enough of it. As we see in “Fragonard: Drawing Triumphant — Works From New York Collections” at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, this rebellion took place largely on paper, in sprightly strokes of red chalk and splashes of brown wash that were, in form and spirit, the opposite of the history paintings he had been trained to produce.
2016-11-03.headline_main: Rococo Bad Boy Rebels in ‘Fragonard: Drawing Triumphant’

2016-11-03.abstract: Top energy policy makers and corporate leaders say it will be challenging to meet even the deal’s modest goals to reduce emissions and greenhouse gases.
2016-11-03.snippet: Top energy policy makers and corporate leaders say it will be challenging to meet even the deal’s modest goals to reduce emissions and greenhouse gases.
2016-11-03.lead_paragraph: PARIS — When the landmark Paris Agreement to address climate change officially goes into effect on Friday, the Eiffel Tower and Arc de Triomphe will be floodlit green to celebrate the occasion. Now comes the hard work: figuring out the details.
2016-11-03.headline_main: The Paris Agreement on Climate Change Is Official. Now What?

2016-11-03.abstract: An unexpectedly moving look at the elements of the confinement industry that hide in plain sight.
2016-11-03.snippet: An unexpectedly moving look at the elements of the confinement industry that hide in plain sight.
2016-11-03.lead_paragraph: In “The Prison in Twelve Landscapes,” a meditation on mass incarceration in the United States, the Canadian filmmaker Brett Story arranges a series of oblique, geographical vignettes into an unsettling mural of systemic damage.

2016-11-03.abstract: Linas Phillips’s film revolves around a developmentally disabled 40-year-old virgin — a bully who uses his condition to guilt others into excusing his bad behavior.
2016-11-03.snippet: Linas Phillips’s film revolves around a developmentally disabled 40-year-old virgin — a bully who uses his condition to guilt others into excusing his bad behavior.
2016-11-03.lead_paragraph: The engine of unpleasantness that drives “Rainbow Time” is a sex-crazed, 40-year-old virgin who answers to the nickname Shonzi (played by the writer and director, Linas Phillips). Denied sufficient oxygen at birth, Shonzi is developmentally delayed; he’s also a bully who’s not above using his mental status to guilt those around him into excusing his offensive behavior.
2016-11-03.headline_main: Review: In ‘Rainbow Time,’ Big Brother’s Watching (and Lusting)

2016-11-03.abstract: Heather Graham plays a woman in 1990s New York who begins to learn about her boyfriend only after he’s dead, in this film directed by Anthony Edwards.
2016-11-03.snippet: Heather Graham plays a woman in 1990s New York who begins to learn about her boyfriend only after he’s dead, in this film directed by Anthony Edwards.
2016-11-03.lead_paragraph: “My Dead Boyfriend” desperately tries to look and sound like a quirky indie hit, but that’s not an achievable goal when you have an unlikable lead character indifferently rendered by a name star.
2016-11-03.headline_main: Review: ‘My Dead Boyfriend’ Shares a Life, After the Fact

2016-11-03.abstract: This documentary is about the Japanese group X Japan, which, like so many bands around the world, found fame, then fell apart. But this one rose again.
2016-11-03.snippet: This documentary is about the Japanese group X Japan, which, like so many bands around the world, found fame, then fell apart. But this one rose again.
2016-11-03.lead_paragraph: If “We Are X” proves anything, it’s that rock bands the world over can experience similar trials: acrimony and fatalities, but also, sometimes, glorious comebacks. This fascinating and assured documentary, directed by Stephen Kijak (“Stones in Exile”), tells the story of the group X Japan, a cultural institution in its native country, framed around the group’s 2014 reunion concert at Madison Square Garden.
2016-11-03.headline_main: Review: ‘We Are X’ Explores the Travails and Triumphs of a Rock Band

2016-11-03.abstract: Lee Child shakes up his book series by taking his famously solitary character and turning him into a team player, in “Night School.”
2016-11-03.snippet: Lee Child shakes up his book series by taking his famously solitary character and turning him into a team player, in “Night School.”
2016-11-03.lead_paragraph: “Night School” is the 21st book in Lee Child’s Jack Reacher series, but who’s counting? Most of us can merely marvel at the continuing allure of Reacher, think “you’ve come a long way, baby” and leave it at that.
2016-11-03.headline_main: Review: It’s 1996, and Jack Reacher Is Playing Nice With Others

2016-11-03.abstract: The Times Opinion columnist Andrew Rosenthal on James Comey, the postelection prognosis and other news. Susan Lehman is the host.
2016-11-03.snippet: The Times Opinion columnist Andrew Rosenthal on James Comey, the postelection prognosis and other news. Susan Lehman is the host.
2016-11-03.lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this podcast, Andrew Rosenthal, a Times Op-Ed columnist, talks about the news — the good, the bad and that which makes him mad.
2016-11-03.headline_main: Good, Bad and Mad: Andrew Rosenthal on the News

2016-11-03.abstract: Tony Stone’s documentary portrait of an irascible 68-year-old Vermont farmer has a cosmic dimension, evoking the natural world and the big questions of life.
2016-11-03.snippet: Tony Stone’s documentary portrait of an irascible 68-year-old Vermont farmer has a cosmic dimension, evoking the natural world and the big questions of life.
2016-11-03.lead_paragraph: The irascible 68-year-old Vermont farmer and focus of Tony Stone’s wondrous documentary portrait, “Peter and the Farm,” is a man who contains multitudes. With his snowy beard and imperious bearing, Peter Dunning, at his most eloquent, conveys the authority of a biblical prophet but without a religious platform. As he surveys the 187-acre farm he has tended for more than 35 years, he also suggests a latter-day Prospero ruefully aware that his powers are waning.
2016-11-03.headline_main: Review: Tending the Tempest Within in ‘Peter and the Farm’

2016-11-03.abstract: Find out if your vote can survive the great, flawed adventure of American democracy.

2016-11-03.abstract: Akram Khan’s choreography informs “Chotto Desh,” in which an exchange between a man and a youth summons stories Mr. Khan heard from his grandparents.
2016-11-03.snippet: Akram Khan’s choreography informs “Chotto Desh,” in which an exchange between a man and a youth summons stories Mr. Khan heard from his grandparents.
2016-11-03.lead_paragraph: The man in the photograph at right is angled slightly to one side, his arm curved and his fingers — held together, sharply separated from the thumb — pointing down into what appears to be an upside-down fish. Above him floats a bee, and a snake curls languorously over a branch, appearing to watch his activities with interest.
2016-11-03.headline_main: Lending a Hand (and Fingers, and Fingertips) to Myths

2016-11-03.abstract: Jeff Nichols’s “Loving” is a fictionalization of the story of Mildred and Richard Loving, an interracial couple whose civil rights case went to the Supreme Court.
2016-11-03.snippet: Jeff Nichols’s “Loving” is a fictionalization of the story of Mildred and Richard Loving, an interracial couple whose civil rights case went to the Supreme Court.
2016-11-03.lead_paragraph: There are few movies that speak to the American moment as movingly — and with as much idealism — as Jeff Nichols’s “Loving,” which revisits the era when blacks and whites were so profoundly segregated in this country that they couldn’t always wed. It’s a fictionalization of the story of Mildred and Richard Loving, a married couple who were arrested in 1958 because he was white, she was not, and they lived in Virginia, a state that banned interracial unions. Virginia passed its first anti-miscegenation law in 1691, partly to prevent what it called “spurious issue,” or what most people just call children.
2016-11-03.headline_main: Review: In ‘Loving,’ They Loved. A Segregated Virginia Did Not Love Them Back.

2016-11-03.abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
2016-11-03.snippet: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

2016-11-03.headline_main: Cubs, Clinton, Mosul: Your Thursday Evening Briefing

2016-11-03.abstract: This DreamWorks film, voiced by stars like Anna Kendrick and Justin Timberlake, follows the adventures of a colorful group and their nemesis.
2016-11-03.snippet: This DreamWorks film, voiced by stars like Anna Kendrick and Justin Timberlake, follows the adventures of a colorful group and their nemesis.
2016-11-03.lead_paragraph: Exuberant, busy and sometimes funny, DreamWorks Animation’s “Trolls” is determined to amuse. You remember Trolls — not the rude lurkers online writing nasty remarks, but those little toys with round tummies, beatific expressions and abundant hair shooting upward. Here they’re players in a fairy-tale Cold War parable.
2016-11-03.headline_main: Review: The ‘Trolls’ Embark on a High-Haired Rescue Mission

2016-11-03.abstract: Also, the etiquette of breast-feeding, where’s that wedding invitation, and the private reference letter.
2016-11-03.snippet: Also, the etiquette of breast-feeding, where’s that wedding invitation, and the private reference letter.
2016-11-03.lead_paragraph: My friend and I have the same birthday, so I know he remembers when it is. In our 20s, we exchanged gifts. But as we aged, he stopped acknowledging my birthday (and is generally less likely to pick up the phone to keep in touch). This hurts my feelings. Still, he was incredibly supportive when my dad died last year. And if I ever have an important issue to talk through, he will spend as much time with me as I could possibly ask. So I’m conflicted. And our shared birthday is coming up. What would you do?
2016-11-03.headline_main: The Joys and Pains of Shared Birthdays

2016-11-03.abstract: Nicolas Cage, Willem Dafoe and Christopher Matthew Cook star in this crime movie about some bad guys with hate in their hearts.
2016-11-03.snippet: Nicolas Cage, Willem Dafoe and Christopher Matthew Cook star in this crime movie about some bad guys with hate in their hearts.
2016-11-03.lead_paragraph: Despite its slim running time — barely over an hour and a half — “Dog Eat Dog” somehow feels like six different movies. The first one, which depicts an especially appalling double murder through the speedy, sickly colorful perspective of an extended drug binge, is probably the least effective of the batch. But it lets you know that the filmmakers are not coming at you from a benevolent place, and that impression never lets up.
2016-11-03.headline_main: Review: ‘Dog Eat Dog’ Is a Pulpy Tale With Nasty, Bumbling Crooks

2016-11-03.abstract: The New-York Historical Society is exhibiting memorabilia from four presidential campaigns, including items that were watchable, wearable, drinkable and playable.
2016-11-03.snippet: The New-York Historical Society is exhibiting memorabilia from four presidential campaigns, including items that were watchable, wearable, drinkable and playable.
2016-11-03.lead_paragraph: IN an age of social media, it is easy to forget about old-fashioned presidential campaign memorabilia: posters, fliers, advertisements. The New-York Historical Society has not forgotten. Its exhibition of memorabilia from four presidential campaigns includes items that were watchable, wearable, drinkable and playable.
2016-11-03.headline_main: A Blast from Campaigns Past ... A Grab Bag of Vintage Swag

2016-11-03.abstract: This documentary from Sergey Yastrzhembsky treats the unpleasant subject of the elephants and ivory smuggling with the harshness it deserves.
2016-11-03.snippet: This documentary from Sergey Yastrzhembsky treats the unpleasant subject of the elephants and ivory smuggling with the harshness it deserves.
2016-11-03.lead_paragraph: The animals seem more humane than people in “Ivory. A Crime Story.” This roughly constructed yet passionate documentary isn’t shy about showing the massacre of elephants or about calling out the groups implicit in the killings. That bluntness and courage usually overrides the uneven filmmaking.
2016-11-03.headline_main: Review: ‘Ivory. A Crime Story,’ or the Plight of African Elephants

2016-11-03.abstract: This documentary, filmed in Africa and China, ruminates on the high stakes of poachers killing these animals for their tusks.
2016-11-03.snippet: This documentary, filmed in Africa and China, ruminates on the high stakes of poachers killing these animals for their tusks.
2016-11-03.lead_paragraph: After learning that a beloved wild elephant has been slaughtered by poachers, Craig Millar, a conservationist, wonders aloud “how we got to this stage, as a human race, when we just lay waste to anything we value — anything we see just gets consumed.” Still, he vows to fight on. “I don’t know if it’s ever going to make a difference, and if we’re ever going to do enough, but we’ve got to try.”
2016-11-03.headline_main: Review: ‘The Ivory Game’ Follows the Fight to Protect Elephants

2016-11-03.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Margaret Pinkston, a 69-year-old housekeeper who lives on the South Side, was waiting for a friend to bring over her breakfast tray at the Valois Cafeteria on Thursday morning when she leaned in conspiratorially. “I’m going to be honest,” she said, lowering her voice. “I don’t know one person who wasn’t rooting for the Cubs.”

With a giant band and brass section, the pop star blew through an extra twangy version of “Daddy Lessons,” the southern-fried track from her latest album, “Lemonade,” even working in a section of the Dixie Chicks’ own “Long Time Gone” in the middle. The Nashville crowd was on its feet.
2016-11-03.headline_main: Beyoncé’s C.M.A. Awards Performance Becomes the Target of Backlash

2016-11-04.abstract: What do the Clinton Foundation and F.B.I. infighting have to do with the renewed investigation? Let’s work it all out.
2016-11-04.snippet: What do the Clinton Foundation and F.B.I. infighting have to do with the renewed investigation? Let’s work it all out.
2016-11-04.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A week ago, the F.B.I. director, James B. Comey, jolted the presidential race by sending a letter to Congress saying the bureau had discovered new emails that might be relevant to Hillary Clinton’s use of a private server. The disclosure set off widespread criticism of Mr. Comey and unleashed a hurricane of news about Mrs. Clinton’s family foundation, Russia and F.B.I. infighting. Let’s sort it all out.
2016-11-04.headline_main: Sorting Through the Clinton Email Case and What the F.B.I.’s Options Are

2016-11-04.abstract: President Obama sees a possible solution to a dispute over environmental dangers and over yet another insult to American Indian heritage.
2016-11-04.snippet: President Obama sees a possible solution to a dispute over environmental dangers and over yet another insult to American Indian heritage.
2016-11-04.lead_paragraph: President Obama has pointed a way out of a dangerous standoff over an oil pipeline being built in North Dakota. He told an interviewer on Tuesday that the Army Corps of Engineers was looking for a new pipeline route, presumably away from the Standing Rock Sioux Reservation, whose members and allies have been protesting the project for months, saying it threatens the tribe’s sacred lands and water supply.
2016-11-04.headline_main: Time to Move the Standing Rock Pipeline

2016-11-04.snippet: Some workers at Trader Joe’s stores, including one who says he was fired for lacking a “genuine” smile, have complained about their treatment and of safety lapses.
2016-11-04.lead_paragraph: To explain their infatuation with Trader Joe’s, fans of the offbeat grocery chain typically cite three factors: low prices, an appealing selection of high-end products and, perhaps above all, irrepressibly friendly employees.

2016-11-04.snippet: Lucio Schiavone, one of the craftsmen who helped renovate the Brooklyn attraction in the late 1980s, is retiring after 26 years.
2016-11-04.lead_paragraph: For the past 26 years, when children have raced through the doors of the carousel at Prospect Park in Brooklyn, Lucio Schiavone has gently called out, “Tickets, tickets please.” Once they have all settled, he rings a brass bell, presses his palm against a big red button and then perches himself on a tall stool to watch.
2016-11-04.headline_main: Longtime Prospect Park Carousel Operator to Stop Making His Rounds

2016-11-04.abstract: Mary Wittenberg, former president of New York Road Runners, who directed the race for 10 years, will be running it for the first time.
2016-11-04.snippet: Mary Wittenberg, former president of New York Road Runners, who directed the race for 10 years, will be running it for the first time.
2016-11-04.lead_paragraph: On Sunday, Mary Wittenberg, the former president of New York Road Runners, will tour New York City’s five boroughs on foot — one of about 50,000 entrants in the New York City Marathon, a race she directed for 10 years but has never run. Wittenberg, 54, is a longtime resident of the Upper East Side, where she lives with her husband and two sons. Since taking over Virgin Sport, a company started by Richard Branson, in 2015, she has learned to merge training trips with work trips. A onetime competitive marathoner, Wittenberg spoke about preparing once again for the other side of the starting line.
2016-11-04.headline_main: Seeing the New York City Marathon From the Other Side of the Starting Line

2016-11-04.lead_paragraph: ARCADIA, Calif. — There is no racetrack on earth with a backside kitchen as chic as Clocker’s Corner at Santa Anita Park. This open-air bistro beneath the rouge-tipped San Gabriel Mountains is where the toned and the tan bask each morning in eternal sunshine as tens of millions of dollars of horse flesh circles the oval before them.
2016-11-04.headline_main: Much Is on the Line for California Chrome at the Breeders’ Cup

2016-11-04.lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — For law enforcement officers here, it feels like a still-raw wound being torn open anew. Less than eight months after a drunken driver killed two police officers in a fiery crash, two other officers were shot to death in separate episodes on Wednesday.
2016-11-04.headline_main: ‘Cowardly’ Killings of Officers Strike a Raw Nerve in Iowa

2016-11-04.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Five years ago, when Frank Jernigan, a retired Google software engineer, and his husband bought a 50th-floor apartment in downtown San Francisco for $4 million, they felt on top of the world. And judging by the commanding view of San Francisco Bay from the plate glass windows of their living room, they were.
2016-11-04.headline_main: San Francisco Files Lawsuit Against Sinking Millennium Tower

2016-11-04.lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — “No hablo español perfectamente,” Senator Tim Kaine of Virginia told an audience of 150 guests here on Thursday, during a political event billed as historic by the Hillary Clinton campaign. For the first time, a candidate on a United States presidential ticket delivered a speech entirely in Spanish, a language that is a synonym for immigration in this state.
2016-11-04.headline_main: Well, Señor Kaine, Hablaste Español Muy Bien

2016-11-04.abstract: In Lynn Nottage’s latest play, the bonds among working-class friends and family unravel as the local economy falls apart.
2016-11-04.snippet: In Lynn Nottage’s latest play, the bonds among working-class friends and family unravel as the local economy falls apart.
2016-11-04.lead_paragraph: In Lynn Nottage’s scorching play “Sweat,” the bonds among a group of working-class friends and family are frayed to the breaking point by the pressure of an eroding economic future. Keenly observed and often surprisingly funny — but ultimately heartbreaking — the work traces the roots of a tragedy with both forensic psychological detail and embracing compassion. Ms. Nottage, a Pulitzer Prize winner for “Ruined,” is writing at the peak of her powers, and the superb cast and the director, Kate Whoriskey, rise to the occasion.
2016-11-04.headline_main: Review: The Jobs Are Gone in ‘Sweat.’ So Are People’s Hopes.

2016-11-04.abstract: We choose to believe what we want. Perhaps a third of American adults now believe a few Big Lies.
2016-11-04.snippet: We choose to believe what we want. Perhaps a third of American adults now believe a few Big Lies.
2016-11-04.lead_paragraph: We can say with absolute certainty that the Chicago Cubs ended a 108-year spell of futility and won the World Series. The Curse of the Billy Goat is dead. We also know with absolute certainty that on the dawn following the last out, the sun rose over Chicago, my dad’s hometown, at 7:26 a.m.
2016-11-04.headline_main: The Post-Truth Presidency

2016-11-04.abstract: Hillary Clinton is the bigger change agent this year, because she can get things done in government.
2016-11-04.snippet: Hillary Clinton is the bigger change agent this year, because she can get things done in government.
2016-11-04.lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago I met a guy in Idaho who was absolutely certain that Donald Trump would win this election. He was wearing tattered, soiled overalls, missing a bunch of teeth and was unnaturally skinny. He was probably about 50, but his haggard face looked 70. He was getting by aimlessly as a handyman.
2016-11-04.headline_main: The Banality of Change

2016-11-04.abstract: Republican leaders have spent decades trashing democratic norms in pursuit of economic benefits for their donor class.
2016-11-04.snippet: Republican leaders have spent decades trashing democratic norms in pursuit of economic benefits for their donor class.
2016-11-04.lead_paragraph: As far as anyone can tell, Paul Ryan, the speaker of the House — and the leader of what’s left of the Republican establishment — isn’t racist or authoritarian. He is, however, doing all he can to make a racist authoritarian the most powerful man in the world. Why? Because then he could privatize Medicare and slash taxes on the wealthy.
2016-11-04.headline_main: Who Broke Politics?

2016-11-04.abstract: There has never been a better time to be alive, and yet in the richest countries, there is a growing sense of unease and helplessness because people no longer feel useful.
2016-11-04.snippet: There has never been a better time to be alive, and yet in the richest countries, there is a growing sense of unease and helplessness because people no longer feel useful.
2016-11-04.lead_paragraph: In many ways, there has never been a better time to be alive. Violence plagues some corners of the world, and too many still live under the grip of tyrannical regimes. And although all the world’s major faiths teach love, compassion and tolerance, unthinkable violence is being perpetrated in the name of religion.
2016-11-04.headline_main: Dalai Lama: Behind Our Anxiety, the Fear of Being Unneeded

2016-11-04.abstract: The impact of third-party candidates on federal and state elections is as significant as it is overlooked.
2016-11-04.snippet: The impact of third-party candidates on federal and state elections is as significant as it is overlooked.
2016-11-04.lead_paragraph: With just a few days before Election Day and all eyes fixed on the two leading candidates, it’s easy to overlook a remarkable fact: The Libertarian candidate for president, Gary Johnson, may tilt the election for Hillary Clinton. And if he does, it wouldn’t be the first time — not even close. The impact of third-party candidates on federal and state elections is as significant as it is overlooked.
2016-11-04.headline_main: Gary Johnson, Queen Maker

2016-11-04.abstract: Has a teacher ever helped you think differently about yourself and your abilities?
2016-11-04.snippet: Has a teacher ever helped you think differently about yourself and your abilities?
2016-11-04.lead_paragraph: Sometimes we develop ideas about ourselves as a student that are at best, unhelpful, and at worst, destructive. For example, we may think we’re just not good at a subject, like math. Or we may assume, no matter how hard we try, that we’ll fail anyway. Some studies show that teachers can have a lasting impact on students’ academic futures by changing their mind-sets.
2016-11-04.headline_main: Has a Teacher Ever Changed Your Mind-Set?

2016-11-04.abstract: When her only child outgrows cuddling, a single mother realizes that her daily life is almost entirely without physical affection, or even touch, from anyone.
2016-11-04.snippet: When her only child outgrows cuddling, a single mother realizes that her daily life is almost entirely without physical affection, or even touch, from anyone.
2016-11-04.lead_paragraph: There is a moment when your child gets too adolescent to cuddle. For me, that moment arrived when my 14-year-old son, Joe, headed to theater camp for a month. He was so eager to get there, he asked me to drop him off at the entrance. But there are papers that need signing when you entrust your child to strangers. Nonetheless, I was hoping for a goodbye hug.
2016-11-04.headline_main: My U-Turn From Isolation to Intimacy

2016-11-04.abstract: For design-obsessed travelers, Airbnb offers the chance to try something different for a night, from a Frank Lloyd Wright house to a tepee.
2016-11-04.snippet: For design-obsessed travelers, Airbnb offers the chance to try something different for a night, from a Frank Lloyd Wright house to a tepee.
2016-11-04.lead_paragraph: Shirley Criddle and her husband, Markus Flatscher, are 20th-century design enthusiasts. Their Chicago home is filled with vintage furniture by the likes of Oscar Niemeyer and Paul McCobb, and Mr. Flatscher idolizes Frank Lloyd Wright, whom he considers one of the greatest architects of all time.
2016-11-04.headline_main: Using Airbnb to Sample Someone Else’s Style

2016-11-04.abstract: After more than a decade away, a foreign correspondent comes back to take stock of his divided homeland.
2016-11-04.snippet: After more than a decade away, a foreign correspondent comes back to take stock of his divided homeland.
2016-11-04.lead_paragraph: I heard it often, traveling around Europe as a journalist. I even heard it from an immigration officer at Gatwick Airport outside London, who teased me as he looked at my passport. I was an American abroad, which meant being held accountable for the strange and fevered state of my homeland, which meant facing some version of the question “What is going on in the United States?” Sometimes the query had an air of schadenfreude, but just as often there was a hint of real concern. The rest of the world already seemed to be going off the rails. It couldn’t afford to have America follow.
2016-11-04.headline_main: An American in a Strange Land

After taking in the competition, run your idea by a few friends. Huggins, who is 38 and played piano for the Joffrey Ballet School during its practices in New York, now plays a baby grand, which he pushes on a dolly over the streets of Greenwich Village. “Come up with something unique,” he says. “People who come to New York, they want to see something unique.”

Trump took a brief break from stumping the other day to open a new Trump hotel, in Washington, D.C., he has rarely paused in nearly 18 months of political campaigning in selling the American electorate hard on his latest, most ambitious, mega-development: the Wall. As if lifted from a real estate brochure, the adjectives, stitched together, soothe and seduce: “An impenetrable, physical, tall, powerful, beautiful, southern” — the “southern” rather innocuously tucked in, like a house advertising “southern exposure” — “border wall.”
2016-11-04.headline_main: The Walls in Our Heads

2016-11-04.lead_paragraph: When Bob Weinstein first received the script for “Bad Santa,” he felt that a gift had been dropped in his lap. Universal had set the project aside, and Mr. Weinstein snapped it up for his company at the time, Miramax: “I asked a Universal executive, ‘Why’d you guys pass on it?’ And he said, ‘It was the most foul, disgusting, misogynistic, anti-Christmas, anti-children thing we could imagine.’” Mr. Weinstein recalled. “That’s exactly why I bought it.”
2016-11-04.headline_main: How the First ‘Bad Santa’ Boozed Down the Chimney

2016-11-04.abstract: Christopher Gray, one of Forbes’s “30 Under 30” and Oprah Winfrey’s “SuperSoul 100,” shares advice for students hoping to launch a sustainable social venture.
2016-11-04.snippet: Christopher Gray, one of Forbes’s “30 Under 30” and Oprah Winfrey’s “SuperSoul 100,” shares advice for students hoping to launch a sustainable social venture.
2016-11-04.lead_paragraph: Christopher Gray’s first job title after graduation was C.E.O. As the son of a single mother who lost her job during the recession, he knew he would need considerable financial aid to pay for college. After seven strenuous months of searching for scholarships, dodging scams and writing (and recycling) essays on leadership and community service, he raised $1.3 million. Then, as a student at Drexel University in Philadelphia, he turned his experience into a social enterprise — an app called Scholly that matches students with a personalized list of scholarships. Scholly soared to No. 1 in the iOS App Store after Mr. Gray pitched it on “Shark Tank.” In three years, Scholly has been downloaded over a million times and has helped students raise more than $50 million.
2016-11-04.headline_main: Launching a Start Up — Scholly — and Finding Scholarships

2016-11-04.abstract: His banana sculpture is ready for its close-up at the Parker Palm Springs.
2016-11-04.snippet: His banana sculpture is ready for its close-up at the Parker Palm Springs.
2016-11-04.lead_paragraph: Next month, the ’50s-era Parker Palm Springs Hotel unveils a top-to-bottom renovation, plus a massive 7-foot-tall bronze banana soon to sit on the main lawn. The designer Jonathan Adler, whose wide-ranging lifestyle empire has made pottery, furniture, lighting and even handbags, says of his first public foray into sculpture, “I felt this urge to make something that was timeless, but also relevant and provocative in the age of Instagram.” (Indeed, the peels, which function as seating, seem ready for their social-media close-up.) But Adler could also be describing the rest of the hotel, which he’s updated in his inimitable cheeky and cheery fashion. Given the town’s increasing popularity, travelers have no shortage of hotel options, so he sought to make this one “the perfect fantasy of what a Palm Springs house should be.”
2016-11-04.headline_main: A Very Jonathan Adler Hotel

2016-11-04.abstract: From the archives of The International Herald Tribune: A British flotilla flees the Batavier Line steamer Oldambt, a Dutch ship, from a German fleet intent on taking it to Zeebrugge, in November 1916.
2016-11-04.snippet: From the archives of The International Herald Tribune: A British flotilla flees the Batavier Line steamer Oldambt, a Dutch ship, from a German fleet intent on taking it to Zeebrugge, in November 1916.
2016-11-04.lead_paragraph: LONDON — A despatch from Amsterdam announces that the Batavier Line steamer Oldambt, which left Rotterdam for London on Wednesday evening, was stopped outside the Dutch territorial limit by a fleet of German torpedo boats and submarines. The Germans placed a crew on board the Oldambt for the purpose of taking the steamer into Zeebrugge, but before they could get under way a flotilla of British torpedo boats steamed up, whereupon the Germans took flight, having first placed bombs in the engine-room of the Oldambt.
2016-11-04.headline_main: 1916: British Flotilla Frees Dutch Ship From Pirate Fleet

2016-11-04.lead_paragraph: For the past two years or so, my daily comings and goings have taken me past a building on my Brooklyn Heights block ripped down to the studs by a developer with the ambition of returning it to the market as a five-story brownstone for $18 million. Renovations are ubiquitous in Brooklyn — home improvement is as distinguishing an element here as surgically taut faces are on Park Avenue — but this project possessed a team of workmen so big it seemed as though a regional airport were under construction. Greeting the foreman, an Irishman with intense eyes who appeared to have landed in the world of HVAC from the world of James Joyce, became such an integral part of my morning habit that I would worry about him on the days he wasn’t out front, poring over blueprints on the hood of his car.
2016-11-04.headline_main: Destroying an 11-Apartment Structure to Build a Mansion

2016-11-04.abstract: John Simpson was hired by the Oxford English Dictionary when he was 22 years old. He became the O.E.D.’s chief editor.
2016-11-04.snippet: John Simpson was hired by the Oxford English Dictionary when he was 22 years old. He became the O.E.D.’s chief editor.
2016-11-04.lead_paragraph: John Simpson, whose memoir, “The Word Detective,” is reviewed this week, was 22 years old and a freshly minted master of medieval studies when he was hired by the Oxford English Dictionary, in 1976. Even though he didn’t know it at the time, he would soon learn that the O.E.D. — a “historical dictionary,” to distinguish it from its merely lexicographic brethren — hired “a lot of medievalists,” he said in a phone interview. “If you know the early stuff, you can look forward to what happens later.” What won’t get you hired by the O.E.D. are moony declarations of how much you “love words.” Such ardor, after all, might come at the expense of being able to treat words as objects for analysis. In “The Word Detective,” Simpson recalls he was also wary of inveterate typers (“We normally asked for handwritten letters”), poor spellers (of course) and those who claim to “enjoy” crossword puzzles. He reserved particular opprobrium for cover letters that included the job-application cliché “hone” (“I honed my lexicographic skills through a passionate love of words and my enjoyment of crossword puzzles”).
2016-11-04.headline_main: Look It Up
