2016-11-06.abstract: The conductor has, to no small extent, defined New York’s classical music scene, from “Tristan und Isolde” at the Met and his engagements at Carnegie Hall.
2016-11-06.snippet: The conductor has, to no small extent, defined New York’s classical music scene, from “Tristan und Isolde” at the Met and his engagements at Carnegie Hall.
2016-11-06.lead_paragraph: In an airy practice room atop Carnegie Hall recently, Simon Rattle, one of the most sought-after conductors in the world, was leading a rehearsal. It felt, at times, like a master class with a group of young musicians who were preparing an unusual take on a standard work: Hans Zender’s orchestration of Schubert’s song cycle “Winterreise.”
2016-11-06.headline_main: Simon Rattle: The Maestro With the Busy Baton

2016-11-06.abstract: Seated beside one another on a No. 1 train, a teenager and a much older man find they have something in common.
2016-11-06.snippet: Seated beside one another on a No. 1 train, a teenager and a much older man find they have something in common.
2016-11-06.lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:
2016-11-06.headline_main: Bonding Over Broken Wrists

2016-11-06.abstract: The 34-year-old ran away from the field before the midway point and was never challenged. Ghirmay Ghebreslassie, 20, won the men’s race, becoming the youngest winner ever.
2016-11-06.snippet: The 34-year-old ran away from the field before the midway point and was never challenged. Ghirmay Ghebreslassie, 20, won the men’s race, becoming the youngest winner ever.
2016-11-06.lead_paragraph: Mary Keitany, a 34-year-old mother of two, went out for a run on Sunday morning. She started at the foot of the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge on Staten Island and worked her way through the city.
2016-11-06.headline_main: Mary Keitany of Kenya Wins 3rd Straight New York City Marathon

2016-11-06.abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
2016-11-06.snippet: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
2016-11-06.lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.
2016-11-06.headline_main: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Nov. 7

2016-11-06.abstract: Quarterback Eli Manning threw four touchdown passes, and the Giants’ defense made a late stand to preserve a victory against Philadelphia.
2016-11-06.snippet: Quarterback Eli Manning threw four touchdown passes, and the Giants’ defense made a late stand to preserve a victory against Philadelphia.
2016-11-06.lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Last season, the Giants not only were a bad team but also seemed hopelessly star-crossed, losing four close games in the final 75 seconds of play. But this season, the Giants, who reached the midpoint of their schedule Sunday, have already protected leads in the final minutes of four tense games, winning each by 5 points or fewer.
2016-11-06.headline_main: Giants Become the Aggressors to Change Their Trajectory From Last Season

2016-11-06.abstract: Members of the former Seattle supergroup that began a quarter-century ago have reconnected and are on their first tour.
2016-11-06.snippet: Members of the former Seattle supergroup that began a quarter-century ago have reconnected and are on their first tour.
2016-11-06.lead_paragraph: UPPER DARBY, Pa. — Last Thursday afternoon, at the Tower Theater outside Philadelphia, the five members of Temple of the Dog were onstage grappling with a common problem faced by men in their early 50s: trying to remember just how they did things in their 20s. The next night, the roughly 3,000-seat hall would be packed, the rock band’s first headlining concert appearance since, well, pretty much ever, but in rehearsal the band’s only audience was stagehands and lighting techs. After plowing through the crunching riffs of “Pushin Forward Back,” however, something didn’t sound quite right.
2016-11-06.headline_main: Temple of the Dog Reunites, Headliners at Last on a Mini-Tour

2016-11-06.abstract: Catrine Clay’s book explores Carl Jung’s tortured soul, his wife’s challenging discoveries and their role in the early years of psychoanalysis.
2016-11-06.snippet: Catrine Clay’s book explores Carl Jung’s tortured soul, his wife’s challenging discoveries and their role in the early years of psychoanalysis.
2016-11-06.lead_paragraph: Carl Jung called his separate selves “Personality No. 1” and “Personality No. 2.” No. 1 was a magnificent extrovert, performing his brilliance, steamrolling his colleagues, blowing away admirers with gusts of charm. No. 2, on the other hand, was a kettle of insecurities: introverted, anxious, tortured by voices and dark waking fantasies. At least once in his adult life, he seemed to suffer an episode of psychosis; as a young boy, images both psychedelic and profane would rudely obtrude on his thoughts, including a vision of God seated on a throne high above a cathedral and shattering its roof with a well-aimed bullet of ordure.
2016-11-06.headline_main: Review: ‘Labyrinths,’ Emma and Carl Jung’s Complex Marriage

2016-11-06.abstract: The Knicks continued to score at a sufficient pace, but Utah shot 50 percent from the field and took 35 free throws in rallying from a double-digit deficit.
2016-11-06.snippet: The Knicks continued to score at a sufficient pace, but Utah shot 50 percent from the field and took 35 free throws in rallying from a double-digit deficit.
2016-11-06.lead_paragraph: Derrick Rose heaved his head up and rolled his eyes back, letting out a groan audible enough to demonstrate his disgust.
2016-11-06.headline_main: Defensive Lapses Cost Knicks Against the Jazz

2016-11-06.abstract: The Young People’s Chorus of New York performed recently commissioned works on Friday at National Sawdust in Brooklyn.
2016-11-06.snippet: The Young People’s Chorus of New York performed recently commissioned works on Friday at National Sawdust in Brooklyn.
2016-11-06.lead_paragraph: Even professional contemporary-music ensembles don’t often perform six world premieres on a single night. But on Friday at National Sawdust in Brooklyn, some 90 teenagers between the ages of 14 and 18 did just that. The excellent Young People’s Chorus of New York City presented the next installment of Transient Glory, its program that commissions composers to write challenging works for young voices.
2016-11-06.headline_main: Review: For This Young Chorus, It’s Never Too Early for Six World Premieres

2016-11-06.abstract: Marco Armiliato conducted this production, which starred Liudmyla Monastyrska in the title role and managed to make the stage seem crowded.
2016-11-06.snippet: Marco Armiliato conducted this production, which starred Liudmyla Monastyrska in the title role and managed to make the stage seem crowded.
2016-11-06.lead_paragraph: To re-encounter “Aida” at the Metropolitan Opera in the 1988 production by Sonja Frisell is again to wonder what Franco Zeffirelli had proposed for his staging that made the Met shy away from the expense. For starters, perhaps, elephants as well as horses in this ancient Egyptian setting?
2016-11-06.headline_main: Review: An ‘Aida’ at the Met That May Not Be Zeffirelli’s, but It’s Big

2016-11-06.abstract: Join runners on the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge, near the start of the 40th New York City Marathon, which travels through all five boroughs of the city.
2016-11-06.snippet: Join runners on the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge, near the start of the 40th New York City Marathon, which travels through all five boroughs of the city.
2016-11-06.lead_paragraph: Join runners on the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge, near the start of the 40th New York City Marathon, which travels through all five boroughs of the city.
2016-11-06.headline_main: Shadow Runners in the N.Y.C. Marathon

2016-11-06.abstract: Bruce Haight wears his professional hat today.
2016-11-06.snippet: Bruce Haight wears his professional hat today.
2016-11-06.lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — The theme of today’s puzzle will come as no surprise to those of you who know what constructor Bruce Haight does for a living. As he says below in his notes, he’s an ophthalmologist, so he was born to make a puzzle like this one. Frankly, I’m surprised he didn’t submit it sooner.
2016-11-06.headline_main: Prayer Hands or Heart Eyes

2016-11-06.abstract: Making light of the presidential race was easier in previous cycles, marketers said. This year? Ease the pain.
2016-11-06.snippet: Making light of the presidential race was easier in previous cycles, marketers said. This year? Ease the pain.
2016-11-06.lead_paragraph: HEFTY is “trashing” the campaign, Excedrin is curing headaches caused by the caustic debates, and Ringling Brothers wants to remind the public that it is the real circus, despite what the last few months may have seemed like.
2016-11-06.headline_main: Ads Focus on Relief From the Presidential Campaign

2016-11-06.abstract: Researchers in a new project are installing microphones in the city to build an aural map and, perhaps, eventually reduce noise pollution.
2016-11-06.snippet: Researchers in a new project are installing microphones in the city to build an aural map and, perhaps, eventually reduce noise pollution.
2016-11-06.lead_paragraph: On Thursday, microphones mounted outside two buildings in Manhattan went live.
2016-11-06.headline_main: To Create a Quieter City, They’re Recording the Sounds of New York

2016-11-06.abstract: Bonfires, blazing crosses and firecrackers are all part of the celebration in an English town that takes a centuries-old tradition very seriously.
2016-11-06.snippet: Bonfires, blazing crosses and firecrackers are all part of the celebration in an English town that takes a centuries-old tradition very seriously.
2016-11-06.lead_paragraph: LEWES, England — Though it is never flattering to be burned in effigy, Donald J. Trump was in good company on Saturday when his image went up in flames not far from those of the British prime minister, Theresa May, and of a 17th-century pope.
2016-11-06.headline_main: Where Burning Effigies (Not Just Guy Fawkes’s) Is Part of the Fun

2016-11-06.abstract: Technology that allows the police to analyze and share data helps prevent crime. But those sophisticated tools may put civil liberties in danger, too.
2016-11-06.snippet: Technology that allows the police to analyze and share data helps prevent crime. But those sophisticated tools may put civil liberties in danger, too.
2016-11-06.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — People talk about online security as a cat-and-mouse game of good guys and bad guys. It’s true for good old-fashioned crime, too.
2016-11-06.headline_main: The Risk to Civil Liberties of Fighting Crime With Big Data

2016-11-06.abstract: Hillary Clinton’s aides, helped by data models and experience in the elections of 2008 and 2012, have long shifted their focus away from the “Bubba” voters.
2016-11-06.snippet: Hillary Clinton’s aides, helped by data models and experience in the elections of 2008 and 2012, have long shifted their focus away from the “Bubba” voters.
2016-11-06.lead_paragraph: PUEBLO, Colo. — After obliging a request for a selfie from a woman in the lobby, Bill Clinton left his hotel here on Friday and rode to his rally, where he made the case that Hillary Clinton cared more about restoring jobs to forgotten workers than Donald J. Trump did.
2016-11-06.headline_main: Bill Clinton Evokes Past, but From the Periphery of His Wife’s Campaign

2016-11-07.abstract: McFadden won the women’s wheelchair race by almost two minutes for her fourth consecutive sweep of the world’s four major marathons.
2016-11-07.snippet: McFadden won the women’s wheelchair race by almost two minutes for her fourth consecutive sweep of the world’s four major marathons.
2016-11-07.lead_paragraph: As Tatyana McFadden churned the hand rings of her racing chair, she climbed the slope of the Queensboro Bridge. Head down, legs tucked underneath, her bent elbows jutted into the air like the hind legs of a grasshopper. It was Mile 16, one of the toughest climbs of the New York City Marathon, the critical spot where triceps scream and biceps throb.
2016-11-07.headline_main: Disappointed in Rio, Tatyana McFadden Returns to Form in New York City Marathon

2016-11-07.abstract: Mary Keitany of Kenya won her third straight New York City Marathon, and Tatyana McFadden became a five-time women’s wheelchair champion.
2016-11-07.snippet: Mary Keitany of Kenya won her third straight New York City Marathon, and Tatyana McFadden became a five-time women’s wheelchair champion.
2016-11-07.lead_paragraph: Mary Keitany of Kenya won her third straight New York City Marathon, and Tatyana McFadden became a five-time women’s wheelchair champion.
2016-11-07.headline_main: A Day of Finishes Both Dramatic and Determined

2016-11-07.abstract: To conquer the world’s six major marathons, running’s extremists must balance their passion with everyday life.
2016-11-07.snippet: To conquer the world’s six major marathons, running’s extremists must balance their passion with everyday life.
2016-11-07.lead_paragraph: Six of the world’s largest and most prestigious marathons — in Tokyo, Boston, London, Berlin, Chicago and New York City — band together and call themselves the World Marathon Majors. Some people try to run all six in the same year.
2016-11-07.headline_main: When Gluttony Dons Racing Shoes

2016-11-07.abstract: This race has been a rematch between two boomer factions: one yearning for the return of an idealized postwar America, the other calling to tear down whatever societal barriers remain.
2016-11-07.snippet: This race has been a rematch between two boomer factions: one yearning for the return of an idealized postwar America, the other calling to tear down whatever societal barriers remain.
2016-11-07.lead_paragraph: They came of age in the 1960s and ’70s, in the traumatic aftermath of the assassinations of John F. Kennedy and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. They fought and protested a war together, argued over Nixon and Kissinger together, laughed at Archie Bunker together. As children, they practiced air-raid drills; as adults, they cheered the fall of the Berlin Wall.
2016-11-07.headline_main: In Boomers’ Sunset, Election Reawakens an Old Divide

2016-11-07.abstract: While the president remains popular, there is disappointment in his failures, coupled with criticism that his caution may have contributed to Europe’s problems now.
2016-11-07.snippet: While the president remains popular, there is disappointment in his failures, coupled with criticism that his caution may have contributed to Europe’s problems now.
2016-11-07.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — When a Democratic presidential candidate named Barack Obama stood at the Berlin Victory Column in 2008 espousing his vision of hope and change, he was surrounded by 200,000 exuberant Europeans, eager to give him a chance.
2016-11-07.headline_main: Europeans View Obama’s Exit With a Mix of Admiration and Regret

2016-11-07.abstract: Global markets are bracing as Americans head to the polls, while in Europe, HSBC and UniCredit prepare to share their third-quarter results with analysts.
2016-11-07.snippet: Global markets are bracing as Americans head to the polls, while in Europe, HSBC and UniCredit prepare to share their third-quarter results with analysts.
2016-11-07.lead_paragraph: Here’s a look at what’s coming this week:
2016-11-07.headline_main: Traders Hold Their Breath as the U.S. Chooses a President

2016-11-07.abstract: Merger and acquisition talks have been active, but the deals’ advisers get paid on completion. This year, antitrust officials thwarted some large mergers.
2016-11-07.snippet: Merger and acquisition talks have been active, but the deals’ advisers get paid on completion. This year, antitrust officials thwarted some large mergers.
2016-11-07.lead_paragraph: Wall Street bonuses are expected to decline for the third consecutive year, reflecting a period of busted mergers, limited trading activity and muted hedge fund returns.
2016-11-07.headline_main: Wall Street Bonuses Are Expected to Sink for 3rd Straight Year

2016-11-07.abstract: Plunging print ad sales and an explosion of online outlets spreading inaccurate information threaten to diminish, and in some cases extinguish, the impact of traditional media companies.
2016-11-07.snippet: Plunging print ad sales and an explosion of online outlets spreading inaccurate information threaten to diminish, and in some cases extinguish, the impact of traditional media companies.
2016-11-07.lead_paragraph: The last year has turned the United States into a country of information addicts who compulsively check the television, the smartphone and the good old-fashioned newspaper with a burning question: What fresh twist could our national election drama and its executive producer, Donald J. Trump, possibly have in store for us now?
2016-11-07.headline_main: Media’s Next Challenge: Overcoming the Threat of Fake News

2016-11-07.abstract: The specter of accusations against Mr. Cosby has surfaced in many of the efforts to revise state laws.
2016-11-07.snippet: The specter of accusations against Mr. Cosby has surfaced in many of the efforts to revise state laws.
2016-11-07.lead_paragraph: Lise-Lotte Lublin started a petition and testified before lawmakers in Nevada last year, part of a successful effort to extend that state’s statute of limitations for sexual assault.
2016-11-07.headline_main: After Bill Cosby, States Shift on Statutes of Limitations in Sexual Assault Cases

2016-11-07.abstract: The international police organization’s system of wanted notices has extended Russia’s reach. In one case, a Russian involved in anticorruption work was detained in Cyprus in connection with the supposed theft of a $1.55 drawing.
2016-11-07.snippet: The international police organization’s system of wanted notices has extended Russia’s reach. In one case, a Russian involved in anticorruption work was detained in Cyprus in connection with the supposed theft of a $1.55 drawing.
2016-11-07.lead_paragraph: VILNIUS, Lithuania — Facing trial in Russia over the theft of a street-art drawing valued by its creator at $1.55, Nikita Kulachenkov, a Russian forensic accountant involved in anticorruption work, fled to Lithuania to avoid what he decided was a doomed battle against trumped-up charges.
2016-11-07.headline_main: How Moscow Uses Interpol to Pursue Its Enemies

2016-11-07.abstract: Supporters of the AT&T-Time Warner deal have pointed to the success of a similar one between Comcast and NBCUniversal, where both sides are thriving.
2016-11-07.snippet: Supporters of the AT&T-Time Warner deal have pointed to the success of a similar one between Comcast and NBCUniversal, where both sides are thriving.
2016-11-07.lead_paragraph: Minions, the impish fire hydrant-shaped yellow misfits who exist to serve the world’s most evil villains, would appear to be unlikely mascots for corporate synergy at Comcast, one of the world’s largest media conglomerates.
2016-11-07.headline_main: How Comcast and NBCUniversal Used Minions to Fuse an Empire

2016-11-07.abstract: He created some of the earliest electronic pop albums and was one of the first musicians to use the Moog synthesizer after it appeared in the 1960s.
2016-11-07.snippet: He created some of the earliest electronic pop albums and was one of the first musicians to use the Moog synthesizer after it appeared in the 1960s.
2016-11-07.lead_paragraph: Jean-Jacques Perrey, the electronic music pioneer whose jubilant compositions turned up in settings as disparate as Disneyland and “The Simpsons,” died on Friday in Lausanne, Switzerland. He was 87.
2016-11-07.headline_main: Jean-Jacques Perrey, Electronic Music Pioneer, Dies at 87

2016-11-07.abstract: Racing across the electoral map, Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Trump begged voters to see Tuesday’s vote as a choice of almost apocalyptic significance.
2016-11-07.snippet: Racing across the electoral map, Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Trump begged voters to see Tuesday’s vote as a choice of almost apocalyptic significance.
2016-11-07.lead_paragraph: They campaigned urgently, even frantically, at airfields and arenas, on a college campus in Wisconsin and in a Philadelphia church. Hillary Clinton and Senator Tim Kaine, their prospects brightened by news that the F.B.I. had found no new troublesome emails in a review of Mrs. Clinton’s private server, pleaded with Americans on Sunday to get out and vote as if their very way of life were on the line.
2016-11-07.headline_main: Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump Scramble to Make Their Final Pleas

2016-11-07.abstract: Ignacio Piatti scored each of his goals in the second half, and Montreal moved on to the Eastern Conference finals after sweeping both legs of its series against the Red Bulls.
2016-11-07.snippet: Ignacio Piatti scored each of his goals in the second half, and Montreal moved on to the Eastern Conference finals after sweeping both legs of its series against the Red Bulls.
2016-11-07.lead_paragraph: HARRISON, N.J. — Yet another promising autumn ended in familiar, exasperating fashion for the Red Bulls, who were knocked out of the M.L.S. Eastern Conference semifinals Sunday after a second successive defeat, 2-1, to a supposedly inferior opponent that had dropped its last seven matches at the stadium in Harrison.
2016-11-07.headline_main: Impact Top Red Bulls on Piatti’s Two Goals and Advance in M.L.S. Playoffs

2016-11-07.abstract: A defining marker of the 2016 presidential race is that it is the first time a foreign power used cyberweapons to influence an election in the United States.
2016-11-07.snippet: A defining marker of the 2016 presidential race is that it is the first time a foreign power used cyberweapons to influence an election in the United States.
2016-11-07.lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, N.H. — The 2016 presidential race will be remembered for many ugly moments, but the most lasting historical marker may be one that neither voters nor American intelligence agencies saw coming: It is the first time that a foreign power has unleashed cyberweapons to disrupt, or perhaps influence, a United States election.
2016-11-07.headline_main: Under the Din of the Presidential Race Lies a Once and Future Threat: Cyberwarfare

2016-11-07.abstract: Friends and family members of Manuel Rosales, who was killed in a shootout with officers last week, spoke of his many personal struggles.
2016-11-07.snippet: Friends and family members of Manuel Rosales, who was killed in a shootout with officers last week, spoke of his many personal struggles.
2016-11-07.lead_paragraph: The red Jeep wedged between a parked truck and a patrol car, the bloodied body hanging out the window and the evidence markers scattered across the sidewalk — they all told of a fleeing ex-convict trapped on a dead-end street, and a heavy firefight that followed, leaving a New York City police sergeant and his assailant, Manuel Rosales, dead.
2016-11-07.headline_main: Gunman Who Killed Police Sergeant Had History of Desperation and Defiance

2016-11-07.abstract: A new podcast from The New York Times and Stephen J. Dubner, the host of “Freakonomics Radio,” turns the idea of a quiz show inside out. In our first episode: the hidden dangers of going to the polls.
2016-11-07.snippet: A new podcast from The New York Times and Stephen J. Dubner, the host of “Freakonomics Radio,” turns the idea of a quiz show inside out. In our first episode: the hidden dangers of going to the polls.
2016-11-07.lead_paragraph: People on both sides of the aisle are concerned that this election might pose an existential threat to society. But did you know there’s one particularly dangerous time of day to vote? It has nothing to do with voter intimidation — but everything to do with how you get to the polls. Hear about the hazards of Election Day — and other types of “Strange Danger” — on the debut episode of Tell Me Something I Don’t Know with its host, Stephen J. Dubner.
2016-11-07.headline_main: Listening to This New Podcast Could Save Your Life on Election Day

2016-11-07.abstract: As the 2016 campaign rumbles into its final hours, there are other things going on around the country on Election Day almost as important as the White House race.
2016-11-07.snippet: As the 2016 campaign rumbles into its final hours, there are other things going on around the country on Election Day almost as important as the White House race.
2016-11-07.lead_paragraph: Forget the fight for the White House, if just for a moment. As the 2016 campaign rumbles into its final hours, there are other things going on around the country on Election Day that are just as important and engaging. Well, almost.
2016-11-07.headline_main: Beyond White House Race, Host of Issues on the Ballot

2016-11-07.abstract: Israel, Iran and anti-Semitism play a part in decisions at the polls, but so do Hillary Clinton’s experience and Donald J. Trump’s charisma.
2016-11-07.snippet: Israel, Iran and anti-Semitism play a part in decisions at the polls, but so do Hillary Clinton’s experience and Donald J. Trump’s charisma.
2016-11-07.lead_paragraph: DELRAY BEACH, Fla. — Some pro-Clinton videos circulating in this part of South Florida do not feature Barack Obama, Bernie Sanders or Elizabeth Warren. Instead, the praise comes from Shimon Peres, Henry Kissinger and the son of Yitzhak Rabin.
2016-11-07.headline_main: Jewish Voters, Prized in Swing State Florida, Tell What Drives Them

2016-11-07.abstract: Quotation of the day for Monday, November 7, 2016.
2016-11-07.snippet: Quotation of the day for Monday, November 7, 2016.
2016-11-07.lead_paragraph: “Based on our review, we have not changed our conclusion that we expressed in July with respect to Secretary Clinton.”
2016-11-07.headline_main: Quotation of the Day

2016-11-07.abstract: Angry at Mr. Trump and energized by Democratic outreach efforts, Latinos are turning out in droves, and could be the difference in the outcome in highly contested states.
2016-11-07.snippet: Angry at Mr. Trump and energized by Democratic outreach efforts, Latinos are turning out in droves, and could be the difference in the outcome in highly contested states.
2016-11-07.lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump maligned undocumented immigrants as murderers and rapists. Hillary Clinton hired a woman who had lived undocumented for many years as her national director of Latino outreach.
2016-11-07.headline_main: Fear of Donald Trump Helps Democrats Mobilize Hispanics

2016-11-07.abstract: Officer Henry Walburger was fatally shot in Manhattan in July 1964 after responding to a burglary call, a reminder then and now that not every officer killing has a reason or motive.
2016-11-07.snippet: Officer Henry Walburger was fatally shot in Manhattan in July 1964 after responding to a burglary call, a reminder then and now that not every officer killing has a reason or motive.
2016-11-07.lead_paragraph: The call came in at 6:40 a.m., a burglary in progress in the Village. Two police officers, with 80 minutes left on their midnight tour, responded to the address on East 12th Street in Manhattan.
2016-11-07.headline_main: The Dangers in Every 911 Call for Police Officers

2016-11-07.abstract: Even if Mr. Trump loses, his candidacy has emboldened groups whose views have long been thought to be well outside the political mainstream.
2016-11-07.snippet: Even if Mr. Trump loses, his candidacy has emboldened groups whose views have long been thought to be well outside the political mainstream.
2016-11-07.lead_paragraph: Ten years ago, Jim Gilchrist was waging a lonely battle.
2016-11-07.headline_main: Donald Trump’s Extremist Supporters Feel Like Winners Either Way

2016-11-07.abstract: Outlandish politics are not limited to the top of the ticket. Consider these contentious, crazy — if somewhat less consequential — campaigns.
2016-11-07.snippet: Outlandish politics are not limited to the top of the ticket. Consider these contentious, crazy — if somewhat less consequential — campaigns.
2016-11-07.lead_paragraph: Campaign 2016 is nearly over, to the relief of many Americans exhausted by the contentious, crazy and very consequential race between Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump. But the year of outlandish politics is not limited to the top of the ticket. Consider these contentious, crazy and somewhat less consequential races.
2016-11-07.headline_main: The Drama Down the Ballot: 2016’s Other Wild Races

2016-11-07.abstract: He popularized nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy, a tool used to understand chemical structures, and was a leader in understanding how organic reactions occurred.
2016-11-07.snippet: He popularized nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy, a tool used to understand chemical structures, and was a leader in understanding how organic reactions occurred.
2016-11-07.lead_paragraph: John D. Roberts, an organic chemist who pioneered the use of nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy and other techniques to reveal the structures of molecules and the dance of atoms as they rearrange in chemical reactions, died on Oct. 29 at his home in Pasadena, Calif. He was 98.
2016-11-07.headline_main: John D. Roberts Dies at 98; He Revolutionized the Field of Organic Chemistry

2016-11-07.abstract: Jordan Seavey’s play follows a couple who comes together, breaks apart and just about everything in between.
2016-11-07.snippet: Jordan Seavey’s play follows a couple who comes together, breaks apart and just about everything in between.
2016-11-07.lead_paragraph: A couple comes together, breaks apart and just about everything in between in “Homos, or Everyone in America,” a daringly frank, funny and affecting new play by Jordan Seavey that’s really — despite the second part of the title — about urban gay life in America, its complexities, its pleasures and, sadly, its dangers. How it applies to “everyone” else isn’t altogether clear.
2016-11-07.headline_main: Review: ‘Homos, or Everyone in America,’ Urban Gay Life in Bittersweet Focus

2016-11-07.abstract: Melissa Errico stars in an adaptation of this midcentury musical that includes elements of thievery, racism and whimsy.
2016-11-07.snippet: Melissa Errico stars in an adaptation of this midcentury musical that includes elements of thievery, racism and whimsy.
2016-11-07.lead_paragraph: Though Og the leprechaun doesn’t look a day over 25, no one in the audience at the Irish Repertory Theater gasps when he confesses he’s 459 years old. But there might be some murmurs of incredulity should the sweet colleen he’s been duetting with step forward to declare she’s a 46-year-old mother of three who first played this part on this stage in 2004.
2016-11-07.headline_main: Review: ‘Finian’s Rainbow’ and the Perils of a Pot of Gold

2016-11-07.abstract: The world as Maeve understood it is gone, as the show again forces viewers to reflect on how their own lives are constructed, too.
2016-11-07.snippet: The world as Maeve understood it is gone, as the show again forces viewers to reflect on how their own lives are constructed, too.
2016-11-07.lead_paragraph: Perhaps the bleakest in a catalog loaded with bleak albums, Radiohead’s “Kid A” closes with “Motion Picture Soundtrack,” a song that obliquely suggests the end of a relationship but is, more broadly, about disillusionment and death. “It’s not like the movies,” singer Thom Yorke laments. “They fed us on little white lies.”

2016-11-07.lead_paragraph: Fantasies are great precisely because they aren’t real. It’s fun to imagine finding a partner as eager for commitment as you are. And it’s fun to picture how different life would be if you were bold enough to go after that ex. But our fantasies don’t often take into account the ripple effects. This week’s episode of “Insecure” explores some uncomfortable territory about how the dreams we cling to can reveal troubling truths about ourselves.

The current pipeline path is being bitterly, and appropriately, opposed by the Standing Rock Sioux and a growing array of allies for threatening sacred sites and the environment in lands and waters that were never ceded under treaties.

2016-11-07.lead_paragraph: You have a gazillion choices when it comes to sea salt, but the salt that’s hand-harvested from natural ponds in Sonora, at the edge of the Sea of Cortez in Mexico, has a soft texture that sets it apart. It’s on the coarse side, rustic, with a slightly bitter finish and is fairly moist. It comes in homespun bags that are hand-embroidered with mermaids, seashells and other motifs by women in a Sonoran village, work that permits these craftswomen to earn money yet stay at home with their children. Consider a modest sprinkling of this salt on your pumpkin pie (especially if store-bought). The bags make a lovely gift for a host: Sal del Mar, $14 to $15 for a 16-ounce cloth bag, saldelmar.com.

2016-11-07.abstract: Researchers studied fossilized leaves from the Patagonia region to conclude it took about 4 million years for insects to recover following the Chicxulub asteroid.
2016-11-07.snippet: Researchers studied fossilized leaves from the Patagonia region to conclude it took about 4 million years for insects to recover following the Chicxulub asteroid.
2016-11-07.lead_paragraph: The asteroid that smashed into the Earth near Chicxulub, Mexico, some 66 million years ago annihilated the dinosaurs and obliterated about 75 percent of all plant and animal species on Earth. The devastation affected insects living thousands of miles north and south of the impact zone as well.
2016-11-07.headline_main: After Dinosaur Extinction, Some Insects Recovered More Quickly

2016-11-07.abstract: It can be difficult for a judge to decide an appropriate sentence in cases in which the defendant shows remorse and the financial harm is difficult to measure.
2016-11-07.snippet: It can be difficult for a judge to decide an appropriate sentence in cases in which the defendant shows remorse and the financial harm is difficult to measure.
2016-11-07.lead_paragraph: One of the vexing issues in white-collar crime is figuring out the appropriate sentence for someone who usually has an otherwise spotless record and poses no physical threat to the community. Recent cases show how hard it is to determine a just punishment for defendants who have so much going for them yet engaged in criminal conduct.
2016-11-07.headline_main: Determining a Punishment That Fits the Crime

2016-11-07.abstract: She has remained loyal to her father. Will that cost her?
2016-11-07.snippet: She has remained loyal to her father. Will that cost her?
2016-11-07.lead_paragraph: Ivanka Trump can do it all. Throughout this interminable campaign, she has been able, with very little backlash, to promote for her $100 million apparel brand, which she markets with the female empowerment hashtag #womenwhowork, and also support her father, whose campaign is rife with misogynistic language, and who has been accused of sexual harassment by more than a dozen women.

2016-11-07.abstract: “On the Inside,” curated by Tatiana von Fürstenberg, was a labor of love intended to empower one of society’s most marginalized communities.
2016-11-07.snippet: “On the Inside,” curated by Tatiana von Fürstenberg, was a labor of love intended to empower one of society’s most marginalized communities.
2016-11-07.lead_paragraph: “I made a pledge to do an act of love every day for 30 days between Martin Luther King Day and Valentine’s Day of 2012. It was a simple online pledge — it had to be an act of love not for friends and family,” explains the filmmaker and musician Tatiana von Fürstenberg. It was this promise that ultimately led her to create an arts initiative empowering LGBTQ prisoners — people who, as von Fürstenberg notes, “discovered art on their own and have been making art, sometimes before they were incarcerated and sometimes after they were incarcerated.” “On the Inside,” the first group show of prisoner work she’s curated through the initiative by prisoners around the country, is on view now at Abrons Arts Center.
2016-11-07.headline_main: A Moving, Diverse Show of Drawings by Incarcerated LGBTQ Artists

2016-11-07.abstract: Members of the soccer team respond to a lewd “scouting report.”
2016-11-07.snippet: Members of the soccer team respond to a lewd “scouting report.”
2016-11-07.lead_paragraph: You may have heard that Harvard cancelled the rest of its men’s soccer season after reports that male players had discussed female players in crude sexual terms. Six members of one Harvard women’s soccer team wrote this brilliant op-ed for The Harvard Crimson, and I’m republishing it here with permission. I admired the op-ed for its cogency and eloquence, but also because I thought it might be effective in changing mores. —Nicholas Kristof
2016-11-07.headline_main: A Letter from the Harvard Women’s Soccer Team

2016-11-07.abstract: A former longtime political reporter for The Times reflects on Election Days past.
2016-11-07.snippet: A former longtime political reporter for The Times reflects on Election Days past.
2016-11-07.lead_paragraph: The plight of a political journalist on Election Day is akin to that of a pilot or a police officer: hours of boredom, minutes of terror. For most of the day, there is nothing to do. The only thing that matters is how you perform in a few frantic post-midnight moments, often with your bosses literally looking over your shoulder in a packed newsroom as you type.
2016-11-07.headline_main: Covering Elections: ‘Hours of Boredom, Minutes of Terror’

2016-11-07.abstract: Early voting data unequivocally indicates that Hillary Clinton will benefit from Hispanic turnout that is vastly exceeding numbers from four years ago.
2016-11-07.snippet: Early voting data unequivocally indicates that Hillary Clinton will benefit from Hispanic turnout that is vastly exceeding numbers from four years ago.
2016-11-07.lead_paragraph: Hispanic voters were largely credited with President Obama’s victory in 2012, but they weren’t  as crucial  as many believed. Mr. Obama didn’t even need to win the Hispanic vote to put him over the top, thanks to high black turnout and support among white voters in the North. The turnout among Hispanic voters didn’t surge, even though exit polls implied that it had.
2016-11-07.headline_main: This Time, There Really Is a Hispanic Voter Surge

2016-11-07.abstract: A special survey suggests there are more Trump supporters than other polls indicate. But they also seem unlikely to actually vote.
2016-11-07.snippet: A special survey suggests there are more Trump supporters than other polls indicate. But they also seem unlikely to actually vote.
2016-11-07.lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton is favored to become the next president of the United States. Yet many in Donald J. Trump’s camp remain undaunted, arguing that hidden supporters will carry him to the White House. As the polls have narrowed in the last few days, the question of whether pollsters could be missing Trump voters has become paramount. Do these unseen supporters exist?
2016-11-07.headline_main: Are There Really Hidden Trump Voters?

2016-11-07.abstract: Ms. Smith takes on a familiar theme: how family and politics affect identity. But her portrait of a famous singer and would-be humanitarian is clumsy and tedious.
2016-11-07.snippet: Ms. Smith takes on a familiar theme: how family and politics affect identity. But her portrait of a famous singer and would-be humanitarian is clumsy and tedious.
2016-11-07.lead_paragraph: Doubles — pairs of friends, rivals and families; contrasting ideologies and views of the world — animate Zadie Smith’s novels, as surely as doubles and doppelgängers haunt many Hitchcock movies. Her astonishing debut novel, “White Teeth” (2000), recounted the story of two World War II vets — polar opposites and best friends — and their extended families, opening out into a teeming, Bruegel-esque portrait of a multicultural London. “On Beauty” (2005), another magical big-city novel (set mainly in Boston), also depicted two very different families with intertwined lives. And the disappointing “NW” (2012) used the diverging stories of two childhood friends to look at the potent and ever shifting dynamics of money and class.
2016-11-07.headline_main: Zadie Smith’s ‘Swing Time’ Explores Friends’ Diverging Paths

2016-11-07.snippet: Kate Zernike, a Times reporter who covered the Bridgegate trial, takes a spirited look back at the courtroom characters and antics.
2016-11-07.lead_paragraph: Start with a premise that should have seemed absurd: political operatives shut down access lanes to the world’s busiest bridge to punish a Democratic mayor who did not endorse a Republican governor who wanted to be leader of the free world. It was bound to be a colorful story — and trial — even without the New Jersey swamp setting and larger-than-life central figure, Gov. Chris Christie.
2016-11-07.headline_main: Captain Licorish, Agent Pickles, Swamp Justice: Highlights from the Bridgegate Trial

2016-11-07.abstract: “Chotto Desh,” at the New Victory Theater, is a time capsule by Akram Khan, and it starts with the voice of a 12-year-old Bangladeshi boy on a help line.
2016-11-07.snippet: “Chotto Desh,” at the New Victory Theater, is a time capsule by Akram Khan, and it starts with the voice of a 12-year-old Bangladeshi boy on a help line.
2016-11-07.lead_paragraph: In Bengali, “chotto” means “small.” And so “Chotto Desh,” the title of the Akram Khan work at the New Victory Theater, means “small homeland” but also signifies a smaller version of this celebrated British choreographer’s 2011 solo “Desh.” It’s smaller in the sense that it’s an adaptation for children, but that doesn’t mean it’s inferior. If anything, this adaptation is an improvement.
2016-11-07.headline_main: Review: Capturing Childhood’s Wonder in Dance and Mime

2016-11-07.abstract: For all its outrage and rancor, Trump’s campaign has, from the beginning, been mostly about grieving.
2016-11-07.snippet: For all its outrage and rancor, Trump’s campaign has, from the beginning, been mostly about grieving.
2016-11-07.lead_paragraph: At recent rallies, Donald Trump’s warm-up playlist, the one the candidate famously insists on choosing himself, has featured “Funeral for a Friend/Love Lies Bleeding,” the opening medley from Elton John’s 1973 album “Goodbye Yellow Brick Road.” Like a lot of the playlist, it’s an endearingly perverse song for a political event, opening with a somber minor-key dirge performed on a chorus of analog synthesizers. The track played at least a couple of times at the Giant Center arena in Hershey, Pa., on Friday night, as we waited for Trump to arrive, and whenever the dolorous synths cut through the fried-dough-scented air, I felt as if I were at some hybrid of a monster-truck rally and a requiem Mass.
2016-11-07.headline_main: Donald and the Dead

2016-11-07.abstract: There will be cold spots and scattered showers but not enough to affect voter participation, forecasters say.
2016-11-07.snippet: There will be cold spots and scattered showers but not enough to affect voter participation, forecasters say.
2016-11-07.lead_paragraph: If any events are likely to affect voter turnout on Election Day, the weather won’t be one of them. Cold and rain are predicted in some key states on Tuesday, but nationwide the weather is expected to be mild enough to have little impact, forecasters say.
2016-11-07.headline_main: Election Day Weather Not Expected to Hurt Voter Turnout

2016-11-07.abstract: Reports from North Carolina and elsewhere suggest a constitutional right still in need of protection.
2016-11-07.snippet: Reports from North Carolina and elsewhere suggest a constitutional right still in need of protection.
2016-11-07.lead_paragraph: Tomorrow, and the early voting leading up to it, mark the first presidential election since the Supreme Court clipped the protective wings of the Voting Rights Act. In 2013, speaking for a conservative majority of five, Chief Justice John Roberts effectively eliminated the safeguards created by a provision of the law called Section 5, saying that Congress could no longer require states and counties with a history of racial discrimination to get the approval of the Department of Justice before changing local voting rules and practices. Roberts said things had “changed dramatically” since the 1960s, and these jurisdictions, which are mostly in the South, didn’t need oversight from the D.O.J. anymore. They could be trusted to treat minority voters fairly on their own.
2016-11-07.headline_main: The Supreme Court Ruled That Voting Restrictions Were a Bygone Problem. Early Voting Results Suggest Otherwise.

2016-11-07.abstract: A White House correspondent’s valiant attempts to get inside the first lady’s bubble.
2016-11-07.snippet: A White House correspondent’s valiant attempts to get inside the first lady’s bubble.

2016-11-07.abstract: The designer Silvia Avanzi launched Gray Matters with the help of a company that counts Dior and Fendi as clients.
2016-11-07.snippet: The designer Silvia Avanzi launched Gray Matters with the help of a company that counts Dior and Fendi as clients.
2016-11-07.lead_paragraph: Before putting pencil to paper — and nappa-leather uppers to outsoles — the designer Silvia Avanzi spent two years developing and fine-tuning the concept behind her shoe line. “I asked myself, ‘What do women want today, and what do we need, really?’ We feel everything has been done and redone,” she recalls, “and I’m not the type of person who simply wants women to spend money. I want her to be happy with her purchases.” Using “a marketing-trained brain,” the fashion branding and advertising vet noticed a gap: avant-garde heels. From there, Gray Matters — her line of sleek glove shoes, mules and flatforms that launched in stores last month — began to take shape.
2016-11-07.headline_main: Brand to Know: Simple Architectural Heels, Made in Italy

2016-11-07.abstract: The characters in Caroline V. McGraw’s play run up against a problem that makeup can’t fix.
2016-11-07.snippet: The characters in Caroline V. McGraw’s play run up against a problem that makeup can’t fix.
2016-11-07.lead_paragraph: Caroline V. McGraw’s wry and artful “Ultimate Beauty Bible,” produced by Page 73 at the New Ohio Theater, is a play for anybody who has ever believed that the right lipstick, the right shoes, the right lover might meaningfully alter the course of one’s existence. Which is a lot of us.
2016-11-07.headline_main: Review: Makeup Tips Galore, but Not How to Handle Cancer, in ‘Ultimate Beauty Bible’

It has been called a diplomatic graveyard, having frustrated generations of negotiators. It has been compared — in complexity and duration, not bloodshed — to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.
2016-11-08.headline_main: Cyprus: Why One of the World’s Most Intractable Conflicts Continues

2016-11-08.abstract: Carmen Irizarry, 60, was killed by her drug-addicted partner in the Bronx, but her 9-year-old granddaughter, Heaven, escaped, avoiding the grim tally of children killed by the people closest to them.
2016-11-08.snippet: Carmen Irizarry, 60, was killed by her drug-addicted partner in the Bronx, but her 9-year-old granddaughter, Heaven, escaped, avoiding the grim tally of children killed by the people closest to them.
2016-11-08.lead_paragraph: The girl named Heaven lay curled up asleep next to her grandmother on the mattress they shared on the living room floor. The woman, Carmen Irizarry, had been the 9-year-old’s legal guardian for years, a stand-in for the girl’s troubled mother. Now, Heaven’s protector was sick, breathing from an oxygen tank after a long hospital stay for acute lung disease. It was early in the morning of May 11, quiet in the half-light in the eighth-floor apartment in the South Bronx.
2016-11-08.headline_main: Grandmother’s Killing Lays Bare a Dilemma in Child Welfare Work

2016-11-08.lead_paragraph: I must be the most maladapted pothead in Maine. Since 2013, I have had a Maine medical marijuana authorization card, for treating painful nerve damage in my elbows and hands. The thing is, though, I don’t actually like being high; it makes me feel a little sad, a little disengaged. I like everything about marijuana, you could say, except the being stoned part. Fortunately for me, the cannabis crème I use on my joints doesn’t mess with my head.
2016-11-08.headline_main: The Marijuana Election

2016-11-08.snippet: Among the faithful the day before the election.
2016-11-08.lead_paragraph: SARASOTA, Fla. — People started lining up at 4 a.m. to catch one last glimpse of their hero. It was Donald J. Trump’s first campaign stop on his Monday push through battleground states, and his supporters here in Florida seemed to understand that the whole country would be watching them. So, what are the Trump voters in Florida thinking, and where does this movement — or whatever we should call it — go after Tuesday?

2016-11-08.abstract: Athol Fugard has directed his own masterwork at the Signature Theater, which returns to the stage at a time when it feels painfully pertinent.
2016-11-08.snippet: Athol Fugard has directed his own masterwork at the Signature Theater, which returns to the stage at a time when it feels painfully pertinent.
2016-11-08.lead_paragraph: There is good reason that “‘Master Harold’ … and the Boys” ranks among the South African writer Athol Fugard’s most celebrated and popular plays. As the sterling new production that opened on Monday at the Signature Theater attests, this quiet drama remains a powerful indictment of the apartheid system and the terrible human cost of the racism it codified and legalized. At a time when systemic racism and its roots are once again a subject of national discussion in America, it feels particularly, and sorrowfully, pertinent.
2016-11-08.headline_main: Review: ‘“Master Harold” … and the Boys,’ a Searing Indictment of Racism

2016-11-08.abstract: Some citizens have needed judges’ help just to cast ballots.
2016-11-08.snippet: Some citizens have needed judges’ help just to cast ballots.
2016-11-08.lead_paragraph: CHAPEL HILL, N.C. — The casting of a ballot is the most fundamentally American act that any of us takes. It connects us to the Enlightenment ideals of the country’s founding — the once-radical notion that human beings should think for themselves, rather than merely obey kings and priests. “Dare to know!” Immanuel Kant wrote, offering a motto for the Enlightenment. “Have the courage to use your own understanding!”
2016-11-08.headline_main: The Real Voter Fraud

2016-11-08.snippet: The exhausting parade of ugliness provides lessons that political leaders should heed beyond Tuesday’s elections.

2016-11-08.abstract: Forget Trump-Clinton for a second. The nationalization of American politics is having pernicious consequences at every level of government.
2016-11-08.snippet: Forget Trump-Clinton for a second. The nationalization of American politics is having pernicious consequences at every level of government.
2016-11-08.lead_paragraph: Arthur Brooks: So we finally made it to Election Day, Gail. The apocalyptic campaign is finished, and we’ve been given the Sign of the End Times — the Cubs winning the World Series. Now it’s Judgment Day.
2016-11-08.headline_main: It’s Better When All Politics Is Local

2016-11-08.abstract: Satellite images help insurers predict when drought is likely to kill cattle, so they can aid herders whose own lives depend on their livestock.
2016-11-08.snippet: Satellite images help insurers predict when drought is likely to kill cattle, so they can aid herders whose own lives depend on their livestock.
2016-11-08.lead_paragraph: Andrew Mude, a Kenyan economist, has a way of explaining satellites. When he’s talking to pastoralists in his country’s north — people who roam the earth with a dozen head of cattle and very little else — he talks about the stars that don’t act like other stars. “They’re actually taking pictures of the ground,” Mude says. Herders, a stargazing people, understand.
2016-11-08.headline_main: Up in the Sky, Help to Keep Africans From Starving

2016-11-08.lead_paragraph: Courtney Larson really wanted to have children. But after marrying her college sweetheart, Cameron Larson, in 2009, she learned she had fertility issues. The Larsons, who are Mormon, prayed, but, unable to get pregnant after a year, they turned to medical treatments, including intrauterine insemination. After several attempts — and thousands of dollars — she became pregnant.
2016-11-08.headline_main: What Does Life With Quadruplets Look Like?

2016-11-08.snippet: The 2016 campaign has been about changing demographics and shifting party coalitions as much as the two main candidates.
2016-11-08.lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s victory in the presidential race on Tuesday night capped a remarkable election in which several Democratic Senate candidates fell short and Republicans retained their majority in the House of Representatives. Here are some key takeaways from a stunning result that upended conventional expectations and set the stage for a drastic reordering of politics in Washington:
2016-11-08.headline_main: Presidential Election Live: Donald Trump’s Victory

2016-11-08.abstract: Amid criticism, officials have shelved new rules that would limit the number of fairs, spread them into more areas of the city and require a greater diversity of offerings.
2016-11-08.snippet: Amid criticism, officials have shelved new rules that would limit the number of fairs, spread them into more areas of the city and require a greater diversity of offerings.
2016-11-08.lead_paragraph: They hold the promise of vibrancy, the allure of a city thoroughfare repurposed with the tent-lined look of a traveling circus. But the street fairs that can sometimes clog the corridors of Manhattan are also the bane of many, from drivers caught in the resulting snarl to those grown weary of the fairs’ banal ubiquity.
2016-11-08.headline_main: Plan to Rein In New York’s Street Fairs Prompts Unexpected Backlash

2016-11-08.abstract: Crowded into ramshackle homes on a remote peninsula at the bend of a river is one of the largest communities of nuns in the world.
2016-11-08.snippet: Crowded into ramshackle homes on a remote peninsula at the bend of a river is one of the largest communities of nuns in the world.
2016-11-08.lead_paragraph: YARCHEN GAR, China — Even by the standards of the phenomenal sights of Tibet, Yarchen Gar is a wonder on the high plateau: thousands of ramshackle homes clustered on a remote peninsula at the bend of a river, each one the domicile of a nun who has come here to study Tibetan Buddhism.
2016-11-08.headline_main: In Remote Settlement High on Tibetan Plateau, Buddhist Spirituality Soars

2016-11-08.abstract: Video and photos taken by a Times reporter, Anne Barnard, show both scenes of destruction and a seemingly normal city: people just continuing on with their daily lives.
2016-11-08.snippet: Video and photos taken by a Times reporter, Anne Barnard, show both scenes of destruction and a seemingly normal city: people just continuing on with their daily lives.
2016-11-08.lead_paragraph: I took this video while on what often felt like a surreal bus ride through war-torn Syria. The video begins on the edge of the city of Aleppo, its western, government-held half. The area we drove through is all government held but has been intensely fought over, again and again, and has changed hands several times. The route we took connects the city to a key supply route — whoever controls the road determines if the eastern, rebel-held part of the city is besieged or not.
2016-11-08.headline_main: My Journey Into Aleppo: Watching a Moonscape of War Turn Into a Functioning City

2016-11-08.abstract: A recent conference of Russian exiles was perhaps a preview of what Russia will look like when it decides what to be next.
2016-11-08.snippet: A recent conference of Russian exiles was perhaps a preview of what Russia will look like when it decides what to be next.
2016-11-08.lead_paragraph: Vilnius, Lithuania — If only because nothing lasts forever, because no one lives forever, the Putin era in Russia will eventually end. President Vladimir V. Putin is 64 years old, and those who oppose his regime are focusing their attention on imagining what will happen after him — especially since his government’s ongoing crackdown makes it so difficult to focus on the present.
2016-11-08.headline_main: What Russia After Putin?

2016-11-08.abstract: The golden age of lighthouse construction is long gone, but in its wake are beautiful vistas and stories that bring modern Irish history to life.
2016-11-08.snippet: The golden age of lighthouse construction is long gone, but in its wake are beautiful vistas and stories that bring modern Irish history to life.
2016-11-08.lead_paragraph: To get to the Clare Island Lighthouse in County Mayo, in the west of Ireland, you climb up to the island’s northern cliffs along a road of stones, past damp sheep chewing grass, around the bend through an alley of fuchsia hedges in bloom. Keep walking until you reach the lighthouse and slip your key in the lock, hang your parka by the door and take a seat beside the peat-burning fireplace. Someone may be nearby to take your drink order, and the reward for a long walk will be a cold gin and tonic and the soft heat of the fire.
2016-11-08.headline_main: Keeping the Fire of Irish Lighthouses Alive

2016-11-08.lead_paragraph: In a breezy neighborhood west of downtown Vancouver, there’s a tree-lined stretch of Denman Street where you’ll find what amounts to a global buffet: Korean, Chinese, Vietnamese, Middle Eastern, Spanish, African fusion, Italian, Mexican, Pacific Northwest (lest we forget where we are) — the list of cuisines served in this profusion of mostly small and unassuming restaurants is long.

2016-11-08.abstract: From the archives of The International Herald Tribune: Ten ballet dancers from the Cuban National Ballet, including one of its stars, Eduardo Recal, defect and ask for political asylum in France while touring in Paris in November 1966.
2016-11-08.snippet: From the archives of The International Herald Tribune: Ten ballet dancers from the Cuban National Ballet, including one of its stars, Eduardo Recal, defect and ask for political asylum in France while touring in Paris in November 1966.
2016-11-08.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Ten dancers skipped away from the Cuban National Ballet this weekend and asked for political asylum in France because of “the arbitrary persecution which has developed in our country.” It was the largest group of artists to defect here in recent years. It was also an embarrassing blow to the Havana government, which had given the successful company a proud sendoff when it left to open in the prestigious Fourth International Dance Festival last Wednesday.

In New York City on Election Day, voters who spilled out of polling sites snaked through schoolyards and around entire city blocks.

Designed by Jenny Goodman, a founder of Tilit, a company on the Lower East Side that specializes in chef’s gear, this apron is made from soft gray recycled hemp and cotton. It has an adjustable halter strap and a waistline tie that slips through one side to create the wrap effect. Ten dollars from the sale of every gray apron is being donated to the Bad Bitches Grant Fund in Charleston, S.C., for women’s culinary education. The company also makes good-looking aprons for men: Wrap Apron, $75, tilitnyc.com.

2016-11-08.lead_paragraph: I have never been in a men’s locker room, but the news in recent weeks has offered a lesson in what to expect. First it was Donald Trump, who passed off the debasing remarks he was caught on tape making about women as mere “locker room talk.” Now it’s the Harvard men’s soccer team that was found to have crudely sexualized members of the women’s team, systematically and continually over many years. Once again, there are some who pass this behavior off as the stuff of “locker rooms.” Like who, you might ask? The New York Times, for one.
2016-11-08.headline_main: Why ‘Locker Room Talk’ is No Excuse

2016-11-08.abstract: New restaurants from Pichet Ong and Jared Sippel, and other New York openings.
2016-11-08.snippet: New restaurants from Pichet Ong and Jared Sippel, and other New York openings.
2016-11-08.lead_paragraph: CHAAN TENG The versatile chef Pichet Ong is best known for his Asian-fusion desserts, especially at Spice Market (which closed recently). But this Bangkok native has done plenty on the savory side, with Thai and Western food. His latest venture, for which he is the creative director, is in Hell’s Kitchen, turning out Chinese dishes, a cuisine that’s not new to him since he’s part Chinese and has worked at 66, Jean-Georges Vongerichten’s Chinese restaurant in TriBeCa. “It’s never been a better time to open a Chinese restaurant now with the awareness of ingredients,” he said. And he’s having some fun making his own versions of the old standards: chicken skin dumplings, moo shu pulled beef, crispy mapo tofu, Singapore chile crab cakes and General Tso fried chicken. Desserts like flourless chocolate cake with green tea are not the usual banal afterthoughts. The room has atmosphere to spare, with lacy dark wood trellis work and Portuguese tile on the walls and underfoot. (Opens Thursday): 698 Ninth Avenue (48th Street), 212-235-1886, chaantengnyc.com.
2016-11-08.headline_main: Spice Market Chef Puts His Spin on Chinese Food at Chaan Teng

2016-11-08.abstract: The founder of Blackcreek Mercantile & Trading Co. created a space for his own designs alongside equally elemental works by artist friends.
2016-11-08.snippet: The founder of Blackcreek Mercantile & Trading Co. created a space for his own designs alongside equally elemental works by artist friends.
2016-11-08.lead_paragraph: For most people, wood is an unsexy material — the workaday stuff of foundations and flooring and furniture — but for the sculptor and designer Joshua Vogel, it is one of the most dynamic and vital substances on earth. For more than a decade, Vogel has been making deceptively simple wooden objects — tiny salt spoons, elegant sawhorse tables — according to the most rigorous principles of craftsmanship. Under the name Blackcreek Mercantile and Trading Co., which is perhaps best known for a range of understated black cutting boards, he and a small team craft by hand one-of-a-kind pieces that honor the unique qualities of the wood they carve, from the curve of a branch to artful cracks. “When I founded my studio,” Vogel explained on a recent Saturday, “I felt like I needed to break everything back down to one part, one piece, and then start over again. I wanted to focus on these very basic, pure aspects of woodworking and also the wood itself.”
2016-11-08.headline_main: A New Shop for Simple, Handmade Housewares

Two years ago, Mr. Iglehart, 42, won a Tony Award for best featured actor in a musical  as the Genie in “Aladdin.” His show on Monday evening was a casually friendly career survey devoid of the preening grandiosity that often accompanies such autobiographies.

2016-11-08.snippet: As a large population of modern humans interbred with a smaller number of Neanderthals, natural selection purged Neanderthal DNA from the genomes of their descendants.
2016-11-08.lead_paragraph: Neanderthals and modern humans diverged from a common ancestor about half a million years ago. Living in colder climes in Eurasia, Neanderthals evolved barrel chests, large skulls and strong hands. In Africa, modern humans acquired shorter faces, a prominent chin and slender limbs. Then, roughly 50,000 years ago, the two species encountered one another and interbred, as modern humans spread out of Africa.
2016-11-08.headline_main: Why You Don’t Have Much Neanderthal DNA in Your Genome

Surveying our political scene a few years ago, Lesley remarked to me: “You Americans kick around your country like it’s a football. But it’s not a football. It’s a Fabergé egg. You can break it.”

Anthony’s grave in Rochester and at the corner of President and Clinton Streets in Brooklyn. 2016-11-09.abstract: President Park Geun-hye has always appeared above the fray, which is why she has fallen so hard.
2016-11-09.snippet: President Park Geun-hye has always appeared above the fray, which is why she has fallen so hard.
2016-11-09.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — President Park Geun-hye of South Korea was destined to be a political leader. She grew up in the presidential residence as a daughter of South Korea’s longest-ruling dictator, Park Chung-hee. After her mother died in a 1974 assassination attempt against her father, Ms. Park became the country’s de facto first lady. She later was a lawmaker for 15 years, crafting an image as a deft politician while helping to build a conservative party with national security and economic growth as its core message. She became the country’s first female president in 2013.
2016-11-09.headline_main: South Korea’s President Must Go

2016-11-09.lead_paragraph: She may have first become famous as an actress, but these days, Jessica Alba, 35, is equally well known as a founder of the Honest Company, a Los Angeles-based brand selling nontoxic personal care and household products. Now the company, which some retail analysts have valued at $1.7 billion, is expanding its range of products in travel-friendly sizes — there are more than 50 options in the line, and more are in the works — and is also planning to sell them at kiosks in airports in the United States.

2016-11-09.lead_paragraph: “It’s like time travel, how the island looked decades ago before the restorations began.” That’s how my guide, Beno Atan, described our trek as we carefully picked our way through a vast stretch of basketball-size lava rocks on the isolated north coast of Rapa Nui, or Easter Island as it was named by a Dutch navigator who sailed there on Easter Sunday 1722.
2016-11-09.headline_main: Rapa Nui Is Remote. And Then There’s Its Isolated North Coast

2016-11-09.lead_paragraph: LONDON — On top of all its other troubles, Britain got another shock today. The Beatles may never tour together again. There are rumors that these four frenetic symbols of modern Britain, pioneers of the undisguised beat and controversial mop tops, may appear together no more. Their astute manager, Brian Epstein, while declining to kill the rumors about future tours, said tonight that the Beatles were not splitting up as a group. He noted that the foursome already has a movie commitment for next year.

2016-11-09.abstract: The pianist Barry Harris; the drummer Jimmy Cobb; the trumpeter Jimmy Owens; and the saxophonists George Coleman and Jimmy Heath will play Flushing Town Hall.
2016-11-09.snippet: The pianist Barry Harris; the drummer Jimmy Cobb; the trumpeter Jimmy Owens; and the saxophonists George Coleman and Jimmy Heath will play Flushing Town Hall.
2016-11-09.lead_paragraph: Great jazz musicians don’t age out of their art. In many cases they just get better, trading impetuousness and flash for a deeper, more judicious, more emotionally resonant style. This has long been a reason to applaud the National Endowment for the Arts Jazz Masters program, a lifetime achievement award presented to a handful of artists every year since 1982. A concert at Flushing Town Hall on Friday, Nov. 18, will feature five such jazz masters: the pianist Barry Harris; the drummer Jimmy Cobb; the trumpeter Jimmy Owens; and the saxophonists George Coleman and Jimmy Heath. Three are in their 80s — Mr. Heath recently turned 90, and Mr. Owens will be 73 in a few weeks — and all have remained active in the clubs, in the studio and in the classroom. They’ll perform in an all-star group with one younger outlier, the bassist David Wong. Not counting him, there will be well over 300 years of professional experience onstage. (8 p.m., 137-35 Northern Boulevard, Queens, 718-463-7700 x222, flushingtownhall.org.)
2016-11-09.headline_main: The Old (Jazz) Masters, They Keep Getting Better

2016-11-09.abstract: “Southern Accent: Seeking the American South Contemporary Art,” at the Nasher Museum of Art at Duke University, includes 60 artists.
2016-11-09.snippet: “Southern Accent: Seeking the American South Contemporary Art,” at the Nasher Museum of Art at Duke University, includes 60 artists.
2016-11-09.lead_paragraph: When people think about contemporary American art, they tend to think only in coastal terms: New York and Los Angeles. Big mistake. There are alternative histories being written through the huge amounts of work going on elsewhere in this country. “Southern Accent: Seeking the American South in Contemporary Art,” at the Nasher Museum of Art at Duke University in Durham, N.C., gives a rich and complex sense of this.
2016-11-09.headline_main: Forget the Coasts. Look to the Hinterlands.

2016-11-09.abstract: William Kentridge’s staging of the opera will include puppetry.
2016-11-09.snippet: William Kentridge’s staging of the opera will include puppetry.
2016-11-09.lead_paragraph: In his brilliant productions for the Metropolitan Opera of Shostakovich’s “The Nose” and Berg’s “Lulu,” the South African artist William Kentridge filled the house’s enormous stage with animations, activity and dazzling sets. Mr. Kentridge will reveal another, smaller, dimension to his artistry in his production of Monteverdi’s opera “The Return of Ulysses” for Lincoln Center’s White Light Festival. His staging of the opera, based on Homer’s tale, will use puppetry from Handspring Puppet Company posed before animated images. Monteverdi’s great score will be performed by a cast of singers and the Ricercar Consort, under Philippe Pierlot. (7:30 p.m., Monday, Nov. 14, through Wednesday, Gerald W. Lynch Theater at John Jay College, 212-721-6500; whitelightfestival.org)
2016-11-09.headline_main: Monteverdi’s ‘Ulysses’ at the White Light Festival

2016-11-09.abstract: The people behind the sounds of Elvis Presley, the Beatles, Johnny Cash and more are part of this series exploring the recording process.

2016-11-09.lead_paragraph: The performer is often only the public face of a well-known song; its body is formed in the studio. That part of the creative process is explored in the richly detailed PBS series “Soundbreaking: Stories From the Cutting Edge of Recorded Music,” an eight-parter that begins Monday, Nov. 14.

2016-11-09.abstract: The troupe moves to sounds as varied as Bach and Jeff Buckley at New York city Center.
2016-11-09.snippet: The troupe moves to sounds as varied as Bach and Jeff Buckley at New York city Center.
2016-11-09.lead_paragraph: If the world’s dance companies occupied the shelves of a bar, Nederlands Dans Theater would sit comfortably on the top like a fine liquor — smooth, complex, potent. In 2011, Paul Lightfoot became the artistic director after serving as the company’s house choreographer, along with his creative (and romantic) partner Sol León, since 2002. On this visit, the company presents their works “Stop-Motion,” where dancers slide through white dust like ghosts on a ski slope, and “Safe as Houses,” where they are chased by a massive rotating wall to the sounds of Bach. Also on the program are new creations by the sharp associate choreographers Crystal Pite and Marco Goecke. She sets the action on a long table and clads her dancers in suits and ties, like a corporate thriller; he interprets the acoustic love songs of Jeff Buckley. On Tuesday, Nov. 15, the company will offer a preview as part of the Guggenheim’s Works and Process series. (Wednesday through Saturday, New York City Center; nycitycenter.org)
2016-11-09.headline_main: Smooth, Complex, Potent: Nederlands Dans Theater

2016-11-09.abstract: A tribute to Mr. Hanks at the Museum of Modern Art includes a screening of his 1984 comedy “Bachelor Party.”
2016-11-09.snippet: A tribute to Mr. Hanks at the Museum of Modern Art includes a screening of his 1984 comedy “Bachelor Party.”
2016-11-09.lead_paragraph: Tom Hanks has been getting plenty of work lately, in films like “Sully” and “Inferno” and as part of a notorious “Saturday Night Live” election skit. The Museum of Modern Art remembers a time when he was still on his way to becoming a household name when it shows “Bachelor Party,” his 1984 comedy, on Sunday, Nov. 13, as part of “Tom Hanks: A Tribute.” Mr. Hanks played half of a couple headed toward the altar (Tawny Kitaen played his fiancée) when the event of the film’s title disrupts things. “Mr. Hanks’s suave smart-alecky manner owes a lot to Bill Murray, but he’s funny and engaging even if he isn’t doing anything new,” Janet Maslin wrote in her review for The New York Times. The film shows at 5:30 p.m. At 2:30 that same afternoon, “Big” (1988) will be screened; on Monday, at 4 p.m., comes “A League of Their Own” (1992). (Roy and Niuta Titus Theaters; moma.org.)
2016-11-09.headline_main: Early Tom Hanks, Headed for a Raucous Party

2016-11-09.abstract: An early work by Ms. Parks, “The Death of the Last Black Man in the Whole Entire World, a.k.a. The Negro Book of the Dead,” opens Signature’s season.
2016-11-09.snippet: An early work by Ms. Parks, “The Death of the Last Black Man in the Whole Entire World, a.k.a. The Negro Book of the Dead,” opens Signature’s season.
2016-11-09.lead_paragraph: How do you portray an abyss that has swallowed up a cultural past? More urgently, how do you fill it? Knotty questions abound in Suzan-Lori Parks’s “The Death of the Last Black Man in the Whole Entire World, a.k.a. The Negro Book of the Dead,” which opens on Sunday, Nov. 13. The script for this genre-defying work from 1990 specifies that the set include “an exact replica of the Great Hole in History,” into which entire chapters of the African-American experience have disappeared.
2016-11-09.headline_main: Suzan-Lori Parks, Defying Genres

2016-11-09.abstract: Natalia Osipova and Sergei Polunin will appear together in “Natalia Osipova and Artists” at New York City Center this week.
2016-11-09.snippet: Natalia Osipova and Sergei Polunin will appear together in “Natalia Osipova and Artists” at New York City Center this week.
2016-11-09.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Natalia Osipova and Sergei Polunin are ballet’s wunder-couple. She is the former Bolshoi ballerina of the steel-sprung jump and artless impetuosity who has been a principal guest artist with American Ballet Theater, and who surprised the dance world by decamping, first to the Mikhailovsky Ballet in 2011, then to the Royal Ballet here. He is the Ukrainian-born, wildly gifted former Royal Ballet dancer who became a principal at 19, then caused a sensation by walking out in 2012 amid mutual allegations of ill treatment. The British press ate up the mildly salacious rumors of drug abuse, tattoos and high living that ensued, and Mr. Polunin — about whom a documentary film has recently been made — became famous beyond the dance world, hitting a viral streak (close to 17 million views to date) on YouTube in a solo filmed by David LaChapelle.
2016-11-09.headline_main: A Star Ballet Couple Take a Contemporary Turn
