2016-11-10.abstract: Get out of your usual shopping habits and follow our tips on where to shop and what to eat in Greenpoint, NoLIta, the Lower East Side and Clinton Hill.
2016-11-10.snippet: Get out of your usual shopping habits and follow our tips on where to shop and what to eat in Greenpoint, NoLIta, the Lower East Side and Clinton Hill.
2016-11-10.lead_paragraph: New York offers some of the world’s most famous stores, but if you want to break the chain habit, it’s also home to many locally owned businesses. It’s worth going to neighborhoods just a bit off the usual path. If you want to spend the day exploring, with a mix of stores and great food, these four neighborhoods will keep you satisfied.
2016-11-10.headline_main: A Guide to Exploring Four Dynamic New York Neighborhoods

2016-11-10.abstract: A reader recounts her father’s clever solution in his Bay Area garden.
2016-11-10.snippet: A reader recounts her father’s clever solution in his Bay Area garden.
2016-11-10.lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
2016-11-10.headline_main: How to Deter the Deer

2016-11-10.abstract: If he chooses, the new president could move on steel to back up his campaign rhetoric. China has fewer options but could aim at jetliners and carmakers.
2016-11-10.snippet: If he chooses, the new president could move on steel to back up his campaign rhetoric. China has fewer options but could aim at jetliners and carmakers.
2016-11-10.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — As a candidate, Donald J. Trump aimed some of his most blistering words at China, declaring that “we already have a trade war” and suggesting ominously that “we have the power over China, economic power.”
2016-11-10.headline_main: In China-U.S. Trade War, Trump Would Have Weapons

2016-11-10.abstract: Readers discuss an Upshot article about access to care in the United States, Canada and other countries.
2016-11-10.snippet: Readers discuss an Upshot article about access to care in the United States, Canada and other countries.
2016-11-10.lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
2016-11-10.headline_main: Comparing Health Systems: The U.S. and the Rest

2016-11-10.abstract: Led by William Christie, Juilliard415, the school’s period-instrument band, and singers from its vocal arts program performed sprightly works by Jean-Philippe Rameau.
2016-11-10.snippet: Led by William Christie, Juilliard415, the school’s period-instrument band, and singers from its vocal arts program performed sprightly works by Jean-Philippe Rameau.
2016-11-10.lead_paragraph: “If Italy sang,” the early-music guru William Christie said in a master class at the Juilliard School’s Paul Hall on Tuesday afternoon, “Paris and France danced.” The comment seemed germane to the moment, with an excellent group of period-instrumentalists from the school’s historical performance program poised to play Jean-Féry Rebel’s “Les Caractères de la Danse,” a madcap tour of 18th-century French dance forms.
2016-11-10.headline_main: Review: Juilliard’s Fast Takes on French Baroque

2016-11-10.abstract: Researchers are trying to determine whether medical abortions can be done safely through an online consultation with a doctor and drugs shipped to a woman’s home.
2016-11-10.snippet: Researchers are trying to determine whether medical abortions can be done safely through an online consultation with a doctor and drugs shipped to a woman’s home.
2016-11-10.lead_paragraph: When the abortion pills arrived in her mailbox this summer, she felt anxious but also in control, knowing she could end her pregnancy entirely in the privacy of her own home.
2016-11-10.headline_main: A Study Tests the Safety of Women Using Abortion Pills Sent by Mail

2016-11-10.abstract: A look at this duo’s songwriting, told through videos.
2016-11-10.snippet: A look at this duo’s songwriting, told through videos.
2016-11-10.lead_paragraph: The history of musical theater is rich with collaborations between lyricists and composers, who jointly write the songs that power the shows. Over the last decade, Benj Pasek and Justin Paul have established a strong reputation for the versatility and intelligence of their work, and now, with their first original musical opening on Broadway (“Dear Evan Hansen”) and a major Hollywood movie for which they wrote the lyrics opening around the country (“La La Land”), they have fully emerged as a significant new creative force. Here is a video sampler of material from their growing songbook:
2016-11-10.headline_main: A Pasek and Paul Primer

2016-11-10.abstract: After the election, reading the travel tea leaves.
2016-11-10.snippet: After the election, reading the travel tea leaves.
2016-11-10.lead_paragraph: With Donald J. Trump set to become the 45th president of the United States, the spirit of openness that has permeated everything from our increasingly global economy to how we travel may be poised to change.
2016-11-10.headline_main: What Impact Will Trump Have on Tourism?

2016-11-10.abstract: Meet the songwriters Benj Pasek and Justin Paul of “Dear Evan Hansen” and “La La Land.”
2016-11-10.snippet: Meet the songwriters Benj Pasek and Justin Paul of “Dear Evan Hansen” and “La La Land.”
2016-11-10.lead_paragraph: They met at 18, the worst dancers in a college ballet class, and sought refuge in a basement practice room, taking a first stab at songwriting with a tune about adolescents playing hooky and footsie at a suburban diner.
2016-11-10.headline_main: What It’s Like to Make It in Showbiz With Your Best Friend

2016-11-10.abstract: Kent Osborne returns as the starring character in this sequel to the 2011 film “Uncle Kent.”
2016-11-10.snippet: Kent Osborne returns as the starring character in this sequel to the 2011 film “Uncle Kent.”
2016-11-10.lead_paragraph: “Nobody Saw the First One. So He’s Back for a Second.” That tag line appears on a poster for “Uncle Kent 2,” and it’s not entirely accurate. As it happens, I  saw the somber and weirdly self-congratulatory 2011 film “Uncle Kent,” directed by Joe Swanberg and starring Kent Osborne as the title character. “Uncle Kent 2,” directed (for the most part) by Todd Rohal from Mr. Osborne’s script, is a funnier and more imaginative film than its predecessor, but it’s still what you might call a niche proposition.
2016-11-10.headline_main: Review: ‘Uncle Kent 2,’ How’s Your Tolerance for Hipster Milquetoasts?

2016-11-10.abstract: Although engineered in America, the Envision is assembled in China and embodies Buick’s mission of coddling passengers in a quiet, comfortable cocoon.
2016-11-10.snippet: Although engineered in America, the Envision is assembled in China and embodies Buick’s mission of coddling passengers in a quiet, comfortable cocoon.
2016-11-10.lead_paragraph: THE new Buick Envision might seem like any other two-row crossover sport utility vehicle available in the United States, but for a crucial distinction. It is the first mainstream vehicle to come to this country from China.
2016-11-10.headline_main: Video Review: Buick Envision, a Crossover With a Chinese Heritage

2016-11-10.abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
2016-11-10.snippet: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
2016-11-10.lead_paragraph: Good morning.
2016-11-10.headline_main: Donald Trump, Shinzo Abe, Interpol: Your Friday Briefing

2016-11-10.abstract: For more than 40 years, the founder of 10 Corso Como has built a collection of over 650 photographs representing 70-plus artists.
2016-11-10.snippet: For more than 40 years, the founder of 10 Corso Como has built a collection of over 650 photographs representing 70-plus artists.
2016-11-10.lead_paragraph: For more than 40 years, the founder of 10 Corso Como has built a collection of over 650 photographs representing 70-plus artists.
2016-11-10.headline_main: Photographs from Carla Sozzani’s Personal Collection

2016-11-10.abstract: Carla Sozzani of 10 Corso Como never planned to exhibit her collection of 650-plus photos — but then Azzedine Alaïa called.
2016-11-10.snippet: Carla Sozzani of 10 Corso Como never planned to exhibit her collection of 650-plus photos — but then Azzedine Alaïa called.
2016-11-10.lead_paragraph: As a longtime editor and the creator of 10 Corso Como, Milan’s high-end retail and dining complex, Carla Sozzani is a well-known figure in the fashion world; and as the founder of the gallery there that bears her name, she’s been a longtime force in the art world as well. What many don’t know is that she is also a passionate collector of photography. For more than 40 years, she has built a collection of over 650 works, mostly in black and white, representing more than 70 artists from the 19th century to today: big names like Helmut Newton, Alfred Stieglitz, August Sanders and Irving Penn, but also lesser-known photographers like Xanti Schawinsky, an experimental artist from the 1920s.
2016-11-10.headline_main: Stunning, Rare Images Collected by a Fashion-World Force

2016-11-10.abstract: Nicolas Cage stars in the movie, which manages to make one of World War II’s great disasters dull going — even with the shark attacks.
2016-11-10.snippet: Nicolas Cage stars in the movie, which manages to make one of World War II’s great disasters dull going — even with the shark attacks.
2016-11-10.lead_paragraph: The lack of subtlety in its title tells you what you need to know about “U.S.S. Indianapolis: Men of Courage,” a dramatization of an almost unbelievable World War II catastrophe. The film, directed by Mario Van Peebles, brays the story in broad strokes and clichés as if the horror of it didn’t speak for itself, which it most certainly does.
2016-11-10.headline_main: Review: ‘U.S.S. Indianapolis,’ a War (Yawn) Catastrophe

2016-11-10.abstract: After a graphic designer in California invites his ex-boyfriend to spend the weekend, lovemaking and much talk ensue.
2016-11-10.snippet: After a graphic designer in California invites his ex-boyfriend to spend the weekend, lovemaking and much talk ensue.
2016-11-10.lead_paragraph: The title of “Lazy Eye” is the common name for amblyopia, an ocular problem afflicting Dean (Lucas Near-Verbrugghe), a successful Los Angeles graphic designer with a second home in the Mojave Desert. As a child, he recalls, his condition was diagnosed, but he never bothered doing the recommended eye exercises to correct it.
2016-11-10.headline_main: Review: In ‘Lazy Eye,’ Yakking Ex-Lovers Reconnect

2016-11-10.abstract: “Betrayal. Sadness. Heartbreak. Numbness. Disbelief.” Despite these feelings, a reader says she will keep fighting to overcome hate and bigotry.
2016-11-10.snippet: “Betrayal. Sadness. Heartbreak. Numbness. Disbelief.” Despite these feelings, a reader says she will keep fighting to overcome hate and bigotry.
2016-11-10.lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
2016-11-10.headline_main: An American Muslim Woman’s Heartbreak, and Hope, After the Election

2016-11-10.abstract: Construction workers dynamiting rock for a new school unearthed the fossil of an “alien-looking” dinosaur.
2016-11-10.snippet: Construction workers dynamiting rock for a new school unearthed the fossil of an “alien-looking” dinosaur.
2016-11-10.lead_paragraph: It had feathers and a beak.
2016-11-10.headline_main: A Dinosaur With a Beak and Feathers Unearthed in China

2016-11-10.abstract: Combatants for Peace, a group of individuals including many former military enemies in the Middle East, seeks solutions to the region’s agonized convulsions.
2016-11-10.snippet: Combatants for Peace, a group of individuals including many former military enemies in the Middle East, seeks solutions to the region’s agonized convulsions.
2016-11-10.lead_paragraph: How much bloodshed can a divided populace stand? In Stephen Apkon and Andrew Young’s documentary, “Disturbing the Peace,” we meet Combatants for Peace, an advocacy-activist group comprising Israelis and Palestinians who have reached their limit and renounced violence. Most are former military or paramilitary personnel seeking a two-state solution to Israel’s agonized convulsions. Their stories are compelling — and persuasive.
2016-11-10.headline_main: Review: ‘Disturbing the Peace’ Profiles Israelis and Palestinians United Against Violence

2016-11-10.abstract: Aaron Paul of “Breaking Bad” and Annabelle Wallis star as a couple torn asunder in this thriller, which Zack Whedon wrote and directed.
2016-11-10.snippet: Aaron Paul of “Breaking Bad” and Annabelle Wallis star as a couple torn asunder in this thriller, which Zack Whedon wrote and directed.
2016-11-10.lead_paragraph: During his tenure on the television series “Breaking Bad,”  the actor Aaron Paul, as the foil to Bryan Cranston’s Walter White, showed an adroit skill at portraying the haplessness that can lie just below the surface of a brash game face. Mr. Paul’s role in the thriller “Come and Find Me,” as a man befuddled by the unexplained disappearance of his girlfriend (Annabelle Wallis), does not expand his performing parameters.
2016-11-10.headline_main: Review: ‘Come and Find Me.’ Then Again, Maybe Not.

2016-11-10.abstract: With “Fear in Porcelain,” Ms. Kim challenges the very notion of a solo, which she regards as part of a narcissistic tradition.
2016-11-10.snippet: With “Fear in Porcelain,” Ms. Kim challenges the very notion of a solo, which she regards as part of a narcissistic tradition.
2016-11-10.lead_paragraph: The contemporary choreographer Sam Kim believes that the dance solo is, well, gross. (Take that, Anna Pavlova and all your dying swans.)
2016-11-10.headline_main: Review: To Sam Kim, One Is the Most Narcissistic Number That You’ll Ever Know

2016-11-10.abstract: This anxious minority swarmed to the polls to elect as president the candidate who promised to turn back the tide of cultural and economic change.
2016-11-10.snippet: This anxious minority swarmed to the polls to elect as president the candidate who promised to turn back the tide of cultural and economic change.
2016-11-10.lead_paragraph: Between Barack Obama’s 2008 election and 2016, America has transformed from being a majority white Christian nation (54 percent) to a minority white Christian nation (43 percent).
2016-11-10.headline_main: The Rage of White, Christian America

2016-11-10.abstract: “The burden is on Mr. Trump to show us he can change,” one reader writes. Another urges him to begin reconciliation by supporting Merrick Garland.
2016-11-10.snippet: “The burden is on Mr. Trump to show us he can change,” one reader writes. Another urges him to begin reconciliation by supporting Merrick Garland.
2016-11-10.lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
2016-11-10.headline_main: Moving On, After a Rancorous Election

2016-11-10.abstract: In this documentary, four poets in China work in hard, sometimes dangerous, jobs, while nourishing themselves by writing poems. They are not alone.
2016-11-10.snippet: In this documentary, four poets in China work in hard, sometimes dangerous, jobs, while nourishing themselves by writing poems. They are not alone.
2016-11-10.lead_paragraph: The Qin Xiaoyu and Wu Feiyue documentary “Iron Moon” has a slowly mounting, but lingering, impact. The film concerns poets in Southern China who, while enduring arduous, sometimes hazardous conditions in working-class occupations, preserve their spirits with verse. Its inspiration is Xu Lizhi, the 24-year-old poet and laborer at a Foxconn electronics factory in Shenzhen, Guangdong Province, who leapt to his death in 2014. Mr. Xu was one of the countless workers from the countryside who travel to China’s growing cities seeking employment, only to be eaten alive by the tedious, pitiless demands of industry.
2016-11-10.headline_main: Review: In ‘Iron Moon,’ Poets Who Know What Work Is

2016-11-10.abstract: Automakers are using sensors and audio systems to diminish engine noise — or enhance it — for the driver and passengers.
2016-11-10.snippet: Automakers are using sensors and audio systems to diminish engine noise — or enhance it — for the driver and passengers.
2016-11-10.lead_paragraph: IT can make engines sound like purring pussycats — or growling tigers.
2016-11-10.headline_main: Giving Today’s Car a Well-Tuned Interior

2016-11-10.abstract: Amid the chaos of pregame pageantry on N.F.L. fields, kickers and long snappers use trial and error to select spots where they can warm up. It’s not always pretty.
2016-11-10.snippet: Amid the chaos of pregame pageantry on N.F.L. fields, kickers and long snappers use trial and error to select spots where they can warm up. It’s not always pretty.
2016-11-10.lead_paragraph: When Lachlan Edwards punts during Jets games, he tries to give the opposition poor field position. When he punts during those final few moments before kickoff, Edwards has a different objective.
2016-11-10.headline_main: Put That Punt a Little to the Left of the Flutists

2016-11-10.abstract: High-performance sportswear has moved from the gym to the street to the world of high fashion. The mecca is in the Flatiron district in New York City.
2016-11-10.snippet: High-performance sportswear has moved from the gym to the street to the world of high fashion. The mecca is in the Flatiron district in New York City.
2016-11-10.lead_paragraph: Athleisure, the high-performance sportswear originally designed for workouts but now worn everywhere, represents a populist, street-up phenomenon that got its start like this: Women loved wearing comfortable and sleek leggings to the gym. Sweat-eliminating wicking fabrics allowed them to add layers before heading to brunch. And sometimes, they didn’t even work out at all.
2016-11-10.headline_main: Workout Gear for When You’re Not Breaking a Sweat

2016-11-10.abstract: Most of us will never take these trips. But I feel improved for having read about them.
2016-11-10.snippet: Most of us will never take these trips. But I feel improved for having read about them.
2016-11-10.lead_paragraph: In her “Sign of the Times” essay, Sadie Stein writes about how we rarely take the kind of holidays many of our parents enjoyed — to a resort where we are coddled like children and the most taxing activity is deciding between reading and napping. Instead, now we strive for self-improvement at every opportunity, even in our down time. We cleanse, do yoga, climb mountains and so on.
2016-11-10.headline_main: T’s New Travel Issue: Editor’s Letter

2016-11-10.abstract: Robert Schwartzman’s understated sex comedy, his first feature, is a bittersweet study of a man who hasn’t yet taken control of his life.
2016-11-10.snippet: Robert Schwartzman’s understated sex comedy, his first feature, is a bittersweet study of a man who hasn’t yet taken control of his life.
2016-11-10.lead_paragraph: “Dreamland” might look from its credits like a vanity project, but it certainly doesn’t play like one. It’s a smart, understated sex comedy, a description that suggests a certain maturity. You’d never suspect it was the first feature from its director, Robert Schwartzman.
2016-11-10.headline_main: Review: A Pianist Adrift Encounters a Cougar in ‘Dreamland’

2016-11-10.abstract: The quartet of comics in this documentary met at a summer camp for people with Asperger’s syndrome.
2016-11-10.snippet: The quartet of comics in this documentary met at a summer camp for people with Asperger’s syndrome.
2016-11-10.lead_paragraph: “Asperger’s Are Us” rarely stretches to be funny or poignant or touching, and that makes this documentary all the more of each. There’s plenty of emotion in this story of four young men who sometimes have trouble expressing their feelings.
2016-11-10.headline_main: Review: ‘Asperger’s Are Us’ Delivers Smart, Perplexing Humor

2016-11-10.abstract: Senator Chuck Schumer, who will take over as the leader of the Senate Democrats after the retirement of Harry Reid, is known as a hard-charging Brooklynite.
2016-11-10.snippet: Senator Chuck Schumer, who will take over as the leader of the Senate Democrats after the retirement of Harry Reid, is known as a hard-charging Brooklynite.
2016-11-10.lead_paragraph: Senator Chuck Schumer, who will take over as the leader of the Senate Democrats after the retirement of Harry Reid, is known as a hard-charging Brooklynite.
2016-11-10.headline_main: Who Is Chuck Schumer?

2016-11-10.abstract: This documentary from the makers of “The Linguists” uses subtle juxtaposition to meditate on change and adaptability.
2016-11-10.snippet: This documentary from the makers of “The Linguists” uses subtle juxtaposition to meditate on change and adaptability.
2016-11-10.lead_paragraph: At this point no documentarian can possibly have a fresh take on climate change, right? Wrong. “The Anthropologist,” a stealthily insightful film by Seth Kramer, Daniel A. Miller and Jeremy Newberger, improbably mixes that topic with a mother-daughter story to produce a distinctive study of change and human adaptability.
2016-11-10.headline_main: Review: ‘The Anthropologist’ Tells a Mother-Daughter Story, With Rising Seawater

2016-11-10.abstract: People with constipation had an average 13 percent higher risk of kidney disease and a 9 percent increased risk of kidney failure.
2016-11-10.snippet: People with constipation had an average 13 percent higher risk of kidney disease and a 9 percent increased risk of kidney failure.
2016-11-10.lead_paragraph: Constipation may increase the risk for kidney disorders, new research has found.
2016-11-10.headline_main: Constipation May Increase Risk of Kidney Disease

2016-11-10.abstract: Players like quarterback Carson Palmer and running back Jay Ajayi have favorable matchups this week.
2016-11-10.snippet: Players like quarterback Carson Palmer and running back Jay Ajayi have favorable matchups this week.
2016-11-10.lead_paragraph: The Sablich brothers have provided award-winning fantasy football advice for The New York Times since 2010. See their weekly player rankings and visit 5thDownFantasy.com for more fantasy analysis. You can also ask them questions through their Twitter account, @5thdownfantasy.
2016-11-10.headline_main: Fantasy Football: Players to Start in Week 10

2016-11-10.abstract: Pablo Picasso’s daughter and granddaughter bring different perspectives to an exhibition of his work at the Gagosian gallery.
2016-11-10.snippet: Pablo Picasso’s daughter and granddaughter bring different perspectives to an exhibition of his work at the Gagosian gallery.
2016-11-10.lead_paragraph: Diana Widmaier-Picasso is used to hearing that she physically resembles her grandmother Marie-Thérèse Walter, Picasso’s muse and mistress.
2016-11-10.headline_main: ‘Picasso’s Picassos’ Unpacks Paintings From the Family Vault

2016-11-10.abstract: David E. Talbert’s film is often disarmingly entertaining, with an appealing and talented cast that includes Danny Glover, Gabrielle Union and Mo’Nique.
2016-11-10.snippet: David E. Talbert’s film is often disarmingly entertaining, with an appealing and talented cast that includes Danny Glover, Gabrielle Union and Mo’Nique.
2016-11-10.lead_paragraph: The family comedy-drama “Almost Christmas” is an often disarmingly entertaining picture, in spite of its being a not particularly well-thought-out cinematic contrivance. After a brief opening montage showing the history of the Meyerses, a middle-class household in Birmingham, Ala., the movie alights on the five days before Christmas 2016. We soon learn that one of its main characters is running for Congress. Even though it’s the middle of December. This is a little distracting.
2016-11-10.headline_main: Review: ‘Almost Christmas,’ a Home-for-the-Holidays Comedy

2016-11-10.abstract: There have been protests near a project in Labrador, and researchers say problems loom at 22 major dams proposed or under construction close to other indigenous communities.
2016-11-10.snippet: There have been protests near a project in Labrador, and researchers say problems loom at 22 major dams proposed or under construction close to other indigenous communities.
2016-11-10.lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Protests. Hunger strikes. Sit-ins that disrupt construction. At the immense Muskrat Falls hydroelectric dam project in a remote and rugged part of Labrador, the indigenous people who live nearby have been raising louder and louder alarms.
2016-11-10.headline_main: Canada’s Big Dams Produce Clean Energy, and High Levels of Mercury

2016-11-10.abstract: In a city tight on outdoor spaces, the garden of the Cooper Hewitt has become an oasis for children and their minders.
2016-11-10.snippet: In a city tight on outdoor spaces, the garden of the Cooper Hewitt has become an oasis for children and their minders.
2016-11-10.lead_paragraph: Ashley Carlson called out homework instructions across a large lawn to her first grader, who was leaving with a babysitter after having practiced cartwheels on the grass, and then turned her attention to her 3- and 4-year-old sons. The two boys, with matching white-blond hair and blue polo shirts, were clambering up a low stone wall and leaning on a painstakingly restored early-1900s ornate iron fence.
2016-11-10.headline_main: Cooper Hewitt Museum: A Mommy-and-Me Hot Spot

2016-11-10.abstract: Sonia Kennebeck’s elegantly unsettling documentary explores the United States’ reliance on aerial combat drones and the emotional and collateral damage.
2016-11-10.snippet: Sonia Kennebeck’s elegantly unsettling documentary explores the United States’ reliance on aerial combat drones and the emotional and collateral damage.
2016-11-10.lead_paragraph: If we can eliminate enemy threats without placing boots on a battlefield, then why not do so? That’s one of the unspoken questions raised, and largely unanswered, by  “National Bird,” Sonia Kennebeck’s elegantly unsettling documentary about the United States’ reliance on aerial combat drones.
2016-11-10.headline_main: Review: ‘National Bird’ Follows Whistle-Blowers in America’s Drone War

2016-11-10.abstract: “Black Pulp!” shows positive racial images, young Arab artists go New Age, and Werner Büttner is back — all within a block of one another in Chelsea.
2016-11-10.snippet: “Black Pulp!” shows positive racial images, young Arab artists go New Age, and Werner Büttner is back — all within a block of one another in Chelsea.
2016-11-10.headline_main: What to See in New York Art Galleries This Week

2016-11-10.abstract: The first show at the Almine Rech gallery’s plush new Upper East Side location draws on private collections to match up Calder and Picasso.
2016-11-10.snippet: The first show at the Almine Rech gallery’s plush new Upper East Side location draws on private collections to match up Calder and Picasso.
2016-11-10.lead_paragraph: Almine Rech Gallery
2016-11-10.headline_main: Calder and Picasso in Parallel, and as They Diverge

2016-11-10.abstract: This show of Beverly Buchanan‘s work has sculptures, earthworks, photographs and more inspired by the rural South, its architecture and its legacies of injustice.
2016-11-10.snippet: This show of Beverly Buchanan‘s work has sculptures, earthworks, photographs and more inspired by the rural South, its architecture and its legacies of injustice.
2016-11-10.lead_paragraph: A stirring show of the African-American artist Beverly Buchanan kicks off “A Year of Yes: Reimagining Feminism at the Brooklyn Museum,” a rallying cry of events and exhibitions devoted to art by women. In some ways, this ruminative exhibition, “Beverly Buchanan — Ruins and Rituals,” is an odd fit for this powerfully affirmative program; Ms. Buchanan (1940-2015) made haunting sculptures, earthworks, photographs and drawings inspired by the architecture of the rural South and its deeply embedded histories of injustice, poverty and loss.
2016-11-10.headline_main: Haunting ‘Ruins and Rituals’ Begins ‘A Year of Yes’ at Brooklyn Museum

2016-11-10.abstract: Zoe Kazan plays a mother driving into the night with her daughter (Ella Ballentine) in this chiller written and directed by Bryan Bertino.
2016-11-10.snippet: Zoe Kazan plays a mother driving into the night with her daughter (Ella Ballentine) in this chiller written and directed by Bryan Bertino.
2016-11-10.lead_paragraph: Aliens may attack while serial killers rev their chain saws, but few monsters seem as reliably scary as mommy dearest. Whether she’s slumped (and dead) in her rocking chair, as in “Psycho,” or pulling a knife on her daughter, as in “Carrie,” there’s just something about mothers that brings out the worst and sometimes the best shivers. For Freud, Medusa’s head, with its writhing snakes, represents the mother’s genitals. The terror of Medusa is the terror of castration, which occurs when a boy sees that his mother doesn’t have a penis — voilà, anxiety!
2016-11-10.headline_main: Review: Watch the Road, and the Driver, Too, in ‘The Monster’

2016-11-10.abstract: For safety’s sake, auto acoustics are tweaked to help drivers distinguish between warning sounds, and let drivers and passengers converse safely.
2016-11-10.snippet: For safety’s sake, auto acoustics are tweaked to help drivers distinguish between warning sounds, and let drivers and passengers converse safely.
2016-11-10.lead_paragraph: Adjusting the acoustics of modern automobiles is not only about comfort or pizazz. There are safety considerations, too.
2016-11-10.headline_main: A Vehicle’s Sound System Can Be a Matter of Life and Death

2016-11-10.abstract: Elizabeth Eaton Converse’s story and heartbreakingly fragile songs form the backbone of Howard Fishman’s play with music.
2016-11-10.snippet: Elizabeth Eaton Converse’s story and heartbreakingly fragile songs form the backbone of Howard Fishman’s play with music.
2016-11-10.lead_paragraph: Popular music is rife with one-album wonders and oddball trajectories, but Elizabeth Eaton Converse, known as Connie, is a textbook cult artist. When her lone record, “How Sad, How Lovely,” came out in 2009, she had been gone for 35 years. One day in 1974, she got into her VW Beetle and left her Ann Arbor, Mich., home. She had recently turned 50, and was never heard from again.
2016-11-10.headline_main: Review: A Lost Folk Musician’s Haunted Dreamland in ‘A Star Has Burnt My Eye’

2016-11-10.abstract: “Marilyn Minter: Pretty/Dirty,” an exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum, regularly fulfills its contradictory subtitle; many works are ravishingly beautiful.
2016-11-10.snippet: “Marilyn Minter: Pretty/Dirty,” an exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum, regularly fulfills its contradictory subtitle; many works are ravishingly beautiful.
2016-11-10.lead_paragraph: After a presidential campaign that underscored various women’s rights issues, what better art exhibition to review than one devoted to provocative images of female independence at its most intimate, centering explicitly on the body.
2016-11-10.headline_main: A ‘Nasty Woman’ of Contemporary Art Fearlessly Renders the Body

2016-11-10.abstract: In 1873, London was blanketed in a fog so dense that people could not see their feet. Still, it took 83 years before clean air rules were introduced.
2016-11-10.snippet: In 1873, London was blanketed in a fog so dense that people could not see their feet. Still, it took 83 years before clean air rules were introduced.
2016-11-10.lead_paragraph: In December 1873, London was blanketed for a week in a yellow fog so thick that people could not see their feet. “Ladies & gentlemen,” Mark Twain said in a public lecture at the time, “I hear you, & so know that you are here — & I am here, too, notwithstanding I am not visible.”
2016-11-10.headline_main: A Lesson for India in a Fog So Thick It Could Kill a Cow

2016-11-10.abstract: Paul Verhoeven’s film is a psychological thriller, a strangely dry-eyed melodrama, a kinky sex farce and a savage comedy of bourgeois manners.
2016-11-10.snippet: Paul Verhoeven’s film is a psychological thriller, a strangely dry-eyed melodrama, a kinky sex farce and a savage comedy of bourgeois manners.
2016-11-10.lead_paragraph: The opening scene of “Elle” is a shocker: a brutal sexual assault witnessed by a house cat and filmed with pitiless detachment. “The opposite of a trigger warning,” as a friend of mine said. Everything that follows is, in some ways, even more shocking, as the movie — a masterpiece of suave perversity, directed by Paul Verhoeven — leads its audience through a meticulously constructed maze of ambiguity, scrambling our assumptions and expectations at every turn, dispensing discomfort and delight and daring us to distinguish one from the other.
2016-11-10.headline_main: Review: In ‘Elle,’ Isabelle Huppert Subverts the Role of Rape Victim

2016-11-10.abstract: In Denis Villeneuve’s film, Amy Adams plays a linguist struggling to understand interplanetary visitors checking in at 12 spots around the globe.
2016-11-10.snippet: In Denis Villeneuve’s film, Amy Adams plays a linguist struggling to understand interplanetary visitors checking in at 12 spots around the globe.
2016-11-10.lead_paragraph: In what’s perhaps the first science-fiction film — Georges Méliès’s 1902 marvel “A Trip to the Moon” — a group of astronomers lands in the Man in the Moon’s eye. They’re soon taken prisoner by moon men, but a quick-witted astronomer clobbers the king and they escape, with one earthling vanquishing moon men with an umbrella. Humans have been zapping extraterrestrials ever since. It’s so easy to fight the unknown, at least in movies.
2016-11-10.headline_main: Review: Aliens Drop Anchor in ‘Arrival,’ but What Are Their Intentions?

2016-11-11.abstract: The anchor has emerged as this presidential election’s unlikely feminist heroine, pressing Donald J. Trump about his disrespectful comments about women, and paying the price for those questions.
2016-11-11.snippet: The anchor has emerged as this presidential election’s unlikely feminist heroine, pressing Donald J. Trump about his disrespectful comments about women, and paying the price for those questions.
2016-11-11.lead_paragraph: Even had there been no news in Megyn Kelly’s new memoir, “Settle for More,” the book would have drawn a considerable audience. Ms. Kelly, the 45-year-old anchor on Fox News, has emerged as this presidential election’s unlikely feminist heroine and Hildy Johnson, the intrepid gal reporter who made herself indispensable to the brass and resisted the herd mentality of the men around her. She was the hen in the Fox house, taking it upon herself to ask at nearly every turn: Shouldn’t we be concerned that the Republican nominee for president is profoundly disrespectful of women in his public discourse? And accused of being a sexual predator at that?
2016-11-11.headline_main: Review: Megyn Kelly Tells Tales Out of Fox News in Her Memoir, ‘Settle for More’

2016-11-11.lead_paragraph: RALEIGH, N.C. — Roy Cooper, a Democrat, held a razor-thin lead on Thursday in North Carolina’s bitterly contested race for governor. If it holds, it would be a rare bright spot for his party this week, one that has much to do with Mr. Cooper’s call for repealing a state law limiting transgender bathroom access that has subjected North Carolina to a gale of international criticism, boycotts and cancellations.

The inspiration is both personal and refreshingly simple. “I wanted a great American neighborhood steakhouse,” Mr. LeFevre said. “Food that is soulful makes me remember growing up in the Midwest.” The result is the Arthur J, which opened in June 2015.

2016-11-11.abstract: The Bataclan theater was a part of our history, and we wanted our daughters to know that no tragedy is ever truly distant or foreign.
2016-11-11.snippet: The Bataclan theater was a part of our history, and we wanted our daughters to know that no tragedy is ever truly distant or foreign.
2016-11-11.lead_paragraph: My 7-year-old daughter scampered over the cobblestones of a narrow Paris street, proudly holding a bag of fresh cherries. She had asked for them herself: “Des cerises, s’il vous plaît!” Meanwhile, a few steps away, my 4-year-old was offering her finest “Merci” to the carousel attendant collecting tokens for the next ride. She squealed every time she caught sight of the Eiffel Tower in the distance, convinced she had stepped into the pages of a “Madeline” story. At that moment, my husband and I felt fortunate and happy to be in France as a family, to be able to share with our girls a place that has been formative to us.
2016-11-11.headline_main: Family Travel in a Time of Fear

2016-11-11.abstract: Exploring (and saving money in) Washington’s Hoh Rain Forest, and the small, quirky coastal town of Port Townsend.
2016-11-11.snippet: Exploring (and saving money in) Washington’s Hoh Rain Forest, and the small, quirky coastal town of Port Townsend.
2016-11-11.lead_paragraph: I was motoring along Route 101 in northwest Washington State in my little rental car, getting a kick out of the fact that I frequently drive the same highway in Southern California, where I live. There were few other similarities, though: The air in Washington had a refreshing bite to it, cold and clean. The sweet smell of wet earth seemed to follow me wherever I went, indoors or out. And soon after I left Port Angeles — a small town on the 101 that’s a quick 90-minute ferry ride to Victoria, British Columbia, across the Strait of Juan de Fuca — and entered Olympic National Park, it began to rain and didn’t stop until I left the park seven hours later.
2016-11-11.headline_main: An American Rain Forest and Its Charming Neighbor

2016-11-11.snippet: The “Illuminated River” project aims to transform the Thames into a glowing spectacle.
2016-11-11.lead_paragraph: LONDON — London’s bridges will slowly fill with light as the tide rises. Luminous colors will wash across their surfaces. Beams will shoot out from each bridge, pierce the sky and then drop, connecting with a beam on a neighboring bridge to trace the path of the Thames. The bridges’s underbellies will glow gently; the banks will offer floating stages for performances; waterfalls will create a screen for projections; a weave of projected light planes will hover over the surface of the Thames, creating a ghostly river of light.
2016-11-11.headline_main: London Bridges Are Lighting Up

2016-11-11.abstract: Merging biometric information, I.D. photos and addresses and even marital status in one place could invite abuses.
2016-11-11.snippet: Merging biometric information, I.D. photos and addresses and even marital status in one place could invite abuses.
2016-11-11.lead_paragraph: The government of President François Hollande has moved to combine existing information on at least 60 million French citizens into a single sprawling  database. The government says the goal of merging data from French passports and national identity cards is to prevent identity fraud. But the measure risks opening the door to mass government surveillance of the entire country and increases the danger that private information about citizens could be hacked.
2016-11-11.headline_main: The Risks of France’s Big New Database

2016-11-11.lead_paragraph: Among the weighty subjects pondered by literary intellectuals, dance seldom rates very high. The dance critic Arlene Croce once started an essay with the quip, “World’s thinnest book: ‘English and American Literary Men Speak About the Dance.’” So it might come as a surprise that dance is at the heart of “Swing Time,” the fifth novel by one of today’s most prominent literary figures, the British writer Zadie Smith.

2016-11-11.abstract: A collection of interviews with David Bowie finds the rock star talking about literature, flashy clothes and Scientology.
2016-11-11.snippet: A collection of interviews with David Bowie finds the rock star talking about literature, flashy clothes and Scientology.
2016-11-11.lead_paragraph: In 2013, David Bowie published a widely circulated list of his 100 favorite books. William Burroughs was not among them, but the Beat writer did make an impression on the rock star. In 1974, Rolling Stone published a talk between the two at Bowie’s home in London. It’s one of several interviews collected in the recently published “David Bowie: The Last Interview and Other Conversations.” Bowie told Burroughs that his novel “Nova Express” “blew my head off,” noting similarities between it and his own futuristic creation, the concept-album character Ziggy Stardust: “Maybe we are the Rodgers and Hammerstein of the ’70s, Bill!”
2016-11-11.headline_main: Chatting With Bowie

2016-11-11.abstract: Melissa Sweet’s “Some Writer!” is a middle-grade biography of E.B. White, the New Yorker writer who was the author of classics like “Charlotte’s Web.”
2016-11-11.snippet: Melissa Sweet’s “Some Writer!” is a middle-grade biography of E.B. White, the New Yorker writer who was the author of classics like “Charlotte’s Web.”
2016-11-11.lead_paragraph: An illustrated book for children about a writer who wrote children’s books with illustrations seems an oddly special and self-enclosed genre, but “Some Writer!,” Melissa Sweet’s book about the life and work of E.B. White, is still a pretty good one. Despite a title that feels a bit too coyly obvious — mirroring, as it does, the most famous line in White’s book “Charlotte’s Web,” where Charlotte the spider writes “Some Pig!” in her web to promote the doomed Wilbur — “Some Writer!” certainly will fulfill kids’ natural curiosity about the author of a “classic” that, unusual thing, still really works for them.
2016-11-11.headline_main: Some Review! Adam Gopnik on an E.B. White Biography for Kids

2016-11-11.snippet: Marilyn Minter is a risk-taker who revels in depicting the range of our human desires.
2016-11-11.lead_paragraph: “If I paint a glass of water, people think it’s erotic,” the artist Marilyn Minter said during a recent visit to her studio in New York’s Garment District. She laughed ruefully, but they’d have reason. Outrageously beautiful and irresistibly disturbing, Ms. Minter’s increasingly monumental paintings invoke a spectrum of human desires: for sex, food, affection and, hardly least, for being seen.
2016-11-11.headline_main: Lush Morsels From an Artist’s Erotic Imagination

But the Chicago cafe, which could easily be mistaken for a large Starbucks, is much more than that, serving as a community hub, mostly for older people, with dozens of classes on topics like flower arranging, Egyptian history and digital safety.

2016-11-11.lead_paragraph: Over the past few months, 360-degree videos have gained a lot of traction on the modern web as a new immersive storytelling medium. The New York Times has continuously aimed to bring readers as close to stories as possible. Last year we released the NYT VR app with premium content on iOS and Android. We believe VR storytelling allows for a deeper understanding of a place, a person, or an event.

2016-11-11.abstract: I ran Obama’s 2008 campaign. Should I have known better this time?
2016-11-11.snippet: I ran Obama’s 2008 campaign. Should I have known better this time?
2016-11-11.lead_paragraph: Like many people around the world, I expected a comfortable Hillary Clinton victory on Tuesday. But I’m not a random pundit when it comes to understanding presidential races and the electorate — I managed one Obama presidential campaign and oversaw another from the White House. So of all the forecasts that got it wrong, my prediction that Mrs. Clinton was a 100 percent favorite was a glaring miss.
2016-11-11.headline_main: David Plouffe: What I Got Wrong About the Election

2016-11-11.abstract: The polarization between the prosperous urban regions and the rural areas where people feel left behind was sharply clear in Tuesday’s vote.
2016-11-11.snippet: The polarization between the prosperous urban regions and the rural areas where people feel left behind was sharply clear in Tuesday’s vote.
2016-11-11.lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump fared very poorly in American cities in Tuesday’s election. Hillary Clinton did just as badly among rural voters. The political divide between the two groups has been growing more stark in America for years, and 2016 showed an even sharper split than 2012.
2016-11-11.headline_main: The Election Highlighted a Growing Rural-Urban Split

2016-11-11.abstract: Retracting my recession call and more; this will take a while.

2016-11-11.lead_paragraph: As I said in today’s column, nobody who thought Trump would be a disaster should change his or her mind because he won the election. He will, in fact, be a disaster on every front. And I think he will eventually drag the Republican Party into the abyss along with his own reputation; the question is whether he drags the rest of the country, and the world, down with him.
2016-11-11.headline_main: The Long Haul

2016-11-11.snippet: In all five boroughs, the little creature is often easier to identify with your ears than with your eyes.
2016-11-11.lead_paragraph: As common as they are, field crickets often defy identification. Even experts resort to the plebeian measures any hiker might employ to recognize one; the plain fact is, crickets are often easier to identify with your ears than your eyes. So listening to a merry band of chirpsters singing from under a log in an empty field is often a simpler way to determine who’s calling than catching one, killing it and tacking it to a board for examination.
2016-11-11.headline_main: A Chirp From Under the Logs: The Fall Field Cricket

2016-11-11.abstract: On the necessity of resisting the new normal.
2016-11-11.snippet: On the necessity of resisting the new normal.
2016-11-11.lead_paragraph: It is a Sunday afternoon in a provincial town in France. Two men meet at a cafe. One of them, Berenger, is half-drunk. He is being berated by his companion, Jean. All of the sudden, they hear a great noise. When they and other townspeople crane their necks to figure out what’s going on, they see a large animal thundering down one of the streets, stamping and snorting all the way. A rhinoceros! Not long after, there’s another. They are startled. It’s outrageous. Something must be done. What they begin to do is argue heatedly about whether the second rhino was the first one going past a second time or a different one, and then about whether the rhinos are African or Asiatic.
2016-11-11.headline_main: A Time for Refusal

2016-11-11.abstract: Michael Connelly, whose “The Wrong Side of Goodbye” is No. 2 on the hardcover fiction list, says: “I really wanted to go back to my elders with this book — the private eye novels and writers that inspired me.”
2016-11-11.snippet: Michael Connelly, whose “The Wrong Side of Goodbye” is No. 2 on the hardcover fiction list, says: “I really wanted to go back to my elders with this book — the private eye novels and writers that inspired me.”
2016-11-11.lead_paragraph: The Crime Beat: With his Harry Bosch detective novels, Michael Connelly has always harked consciously back to the glory days of Los Angeles crime writing. Once, he even rented the apartment where Raymond Chandler’s hero Marlowe lived in the 1973 film version of “The Long Goodbye.” So if you hear an echo of that title in the latest Bosch book, “The Wrong Side of Goodbye” (new at No. 2 in hardcover fiction), you’re not mistaken. “I really wanted to go back to my elders with this book — the private eye novels and writers that inspired me,” Connelly said via email. “The title, the opening in Pasadena, the missing-heir case, much of the book is a tip of the hat to writers like Chandler and Ross Macdonald.”
2016-11-11.headline_main: The Story Behind This Week’s Best Sellers

2016-11-11.lead_paragraph: In this new weekly feature, we will surface some of the more thoughtful and provocative concerns that come into our office. The public editor’s column can only address so much and, though we’ll reply to many of your comments, we unfortunately aren’t unable to reply personally to everything that lands in our inbox. By giving a weekly glimpse into our mailbag, we hope to give exposure to the fluctuating concerns of The Times’s audience — and in doing so, help facilitate a better conversation between the Gray Lady and her readers.

2016-11-11.abstract: The 42-year-old’s approach is all about self-care and having great conversations with friends.
2016-11-11.snippet: The 42-year-old’s approach is all about self-care and having great conversations with friends.
2016-11-11.lead_paragraph: As senior vice president and chief diversity officer of Omnicom Group, one of the biggest marketing, communications and advertising companies in the world, Tiffany R. Warren is the head of a team focused on advancing the careers of women, minorities and L.G.B.T. employees. And as founder and president of ADCOLOR, a nonprofit she started in 2005 to promote diversity in creative fields, she leads a community of professionals dedicated to helping one another and mentoring others. She is also a board member of GLAAD, the American Advertising Federation and the Ghetto Film School. On Sundays, Ms. Warren, 42, says, she is all about self-care. She lives in a five-bedroom house in the Claremont section of the Bronx.
2016-11-11.headline_main: How Tiffany Warren, an Executive at Omnicom Group, Spends Her Sundays

He was 83.

2016-11-11.abstract: Tips on making optimum use of small spaces.
2016-11-11.snippet: Tips on making optimum use of small spaces.
2016-11-11.lead_paragraph: As anyone who lives in a big city knows, space is a valuable commodity. Whether you’re in a minuscule studio or a Classic 6 with too few closets, there is rarely enough of it. Most of us try to make the best of what we’ve got, embracing our tiny kitchens and eking out storage where we can. But what do designers who specialize in small spaces — and those who have made an art form of living in them — know that the rest of us don’t? Below, some tips and tricks.
2016-11-11.headline_main: Getting Organized in a Tiny Apartment

As two dancers arrive leaping, more letters fade in, spelling “DIVISIBILITI.”

But modern audio dramatists have been turning out intriguing scripted podcasts for several years, and they’re showing no signs of slowing down. Take a guided tour through the past, present and future of audio drama with these fictional standouts.

2016-11-11.abstract: The scene at a Sotheby’s auction of the musician’s art collection was filled by fans and memories.
2016-11-11.snippet: The scene at a Sotheby’s auction of the musician’s art collection was filled by fans and memories.
2016-11-11.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Waiters held trays of Champagne-filled glasses on the landing. Enormous photographs of David Bowie stared or smiled out from the walls. The soundtrack from “Ziggy Stardust: The Motion Picture” played, and a dim blue light filled Sotheby’s auction rooms in London as guests strolled in on Thursday night for the first of three eagerly anticipated sales of some 350 works from Bowie’s art collection on behalf of his estate. (The auction, called “Bowie/Collector,” had two more sales on Friday.)
2016-11-11.headline_main: Bidding to Own a Piece of David Bowie

2016-11-11.abstract: Canadians like their hydroelectric power, but while it may address climate change concerns, it is not without its own issues.
2016-11-11.snippet: Canadians like their hydroelectric power, but while it may address climate change concerns, it is not without its own issues.
2016-11-11.lead_paragraph: Because many parts of Canada rely on electricity produced by dams, “hydro” is often synonymous with electrical power and electrical utilities. The country’s efforts to cut emissions linked to climate change have, not surprisingly, renewed interest in hydroelectricity. But demonstrations in Labrador last month and research led by a Nova Scotia native now at Harvard that was published this week highlighted an often overlooked consequence of hydro dams — mercury buildup in the water behind them. Without costly and time-consuming remediation, they can poison indigenous people who live downstream.
2016-11-11.headline_main: Canada Today: Dams, Fiddles and That New Leader Next Door

2016-11-11.abstract: With every line Mr. Cohen shared, implicitly and in his lyrics, there was a humbling knowledge of mortality.
2016-11-11.snippet: With every line Mr. Cohen shared, implicitly and in his lyrics, there was a humbling knowledge of mortality.
2016-11-11.lead_paragraph: Leonard Cohen, who was 82 when he died on Monday, was young once. That can be hard to remember after his years of public, silver-haired eminence: touring arenas while he was in his 70s and playing leisurely three-hour-plus shows that seemed to slow down time itself. He intoned his songs with serene gravity, revealing once again how carefully chiseled every one of his quatrains is. And with every line he shared, implicitly and in his lyrics, there was a humbling knowledge of mortality: one that grows even more significant on Mr. Cohen’s final studio album, “You Want It Darker,” which was released less than a month ago.
2016-11-11.headline_main: An Appraisal: Leonard Cohen, Master of Meanings and Incantatory Verse

2016-11-11.abstract: The nation may be almost evenly split between Democrats and Republicans, but Republicans now control almost every level of government
2016-11-11.snippet: The nation may be almost evenly split between Democrats and Republicans, but Republicans now control almost every level of government
2016-11-11.lead_paragraph: SOMERS, Wis. — It is the stunning paradox of American politics. In a bitterly divided nation, where Tuesday’s vote once again showed a country almost evenly split between Democrats and Republicans, one party now dominates almost everything in American governance.
2016-11-11.headline_main: Republicans Expand Control in a Deeply Divided Nation

2016-11-11.headline_main: Why ‘Def Comedy Jam’ Gets No Respect

2016-11-11.abstract: Ms. Collins’s latest engagement at Café Carlyle emphatically shows that her pristine soprano is undiminished.
2016-11-11.snippet: Ms. Collins’s latest engagement at Café Carlyle emphatically shows that her pristine soprano is undiminished.
2016-11-11.lead_paragraph: It’s almost unheard-of for a pop soprano in her 70s to surpass her younger self in stamina, precision of intonation and vocal command. But that was what Judy Collins, 77, did at Thursday’s opening-night show of her latest engagement at Café Carlyle. The evening was particularly intense because of the death of her friend Leonard Cohen, which she only acknowledged after a performance that culminated with a somber rendition of his love song “Suzanne.” Her 1966 recording put him on the songwriting map.
2016-11-11.headline_main: Review: Judy Collins’s Clear, Pure Brook of Song

2016-11-11.lead_paragraph: If you’re in any doubt as to the dearth of decent movie roles available to women of a certain age — certain never to see 40 again, at any rate — then buy a ticket for “Shut In.” In this achingly inept thriller, you will see Naomi Watts do what she can to sell a plot of such preposterousness that the derisory laughter around me began barely 20 minutes in.
2016-11-11.headline_main: Review: ‘Shut In’ (Naomi Watts Should Really Get Out More)

2016-11-11.abstract: Archaeologists have found more than 40 vessels in the Black Sea, some more than a millennium old, shedding light on early empires and trade routes.
2016-11-11.snippet: Archaeologists have found more than 40 vessels in the Black Sea, some more than a millennium old, shedding light on early empires and trade routes.
2016-11-11.lead_paragraph: The medieval ship lay more than a half-mile down at the bottom of the Black Sea, its masts, timbers and planking undisturbed in the darkness for seven or eight centuries. Lack of oxygen in the icy depths had ruled out the usual riot of creatures that feast on sunken wood.
2016-11-11.headline_main: ‘We Couldn’t Believe Our Eyes’: A Lost World of Shipwrecks Is Found

2016-11-12.abstract: For public servants who fear how Trump might govern, there is a moral responsibility to serve.
2016-11-12.snippet: For public servants who fear how Trump might govern, there is a moral responsibility to serve.
2016-11-12.lead_paragraph: Of all the conservatives who opposed Donald Trump during his campaign for the presidency, his most vehement opponents were the men and women who had served in past Republican administrations, and particularly in the departments of state and of defense. One hundred and twenty-two Republican foreign policy hands signed a letter denouncing Trump as a menace to American values and world peace. George W. Bush’s C.I.A. director, Michael Hayden, suggested that Trump was a useful idiot for Russian interests. Both neoconservatives and realists — Robert Kagan and Paul Wolfowitz, Brent Scowcroft and Richard Armitage — indicated that they would vote for Hillary Clinton.
2016-11-12.headline_main: You Must Serve Trump

2016-11-12.snippet: Trump’s victory is saddening, but not surprising.
2016-11-12.lead_paragraph: Millions of Americans registered a protest vote on Tuesday, expressing their fierce opposition to an economic and political system that puts wealthy and corporate interests over their own. I strongly supported Hillary Clinton, campaigned hard on her behalf, and believed she was the right choice on Election Day. But Donald J. Trump won the White House because his campaign rhetoric successfully tapped into a very real and justified anger, an anger that many traditional Democrats feel.
2016-11-12.headline_main: Bernie Sanders: Where the Democrats Go From Here

2016-11-12.abstract: The 12-game match pits the champion, Magnus Carlsen of Norway, against the Russian challenger, Sergey Karjakin. And Woody Harrelson was there too.
2016-11-12.snippet: The 12-game match pits the champion, Magnus Carlsen of Norway, against the Russian challenger, Sergey Karjakin. And Woody Harrelson was there too.
2016-11-12.lead_paragraph: The long recovery of Lower Manhattan from Hurricane Sandy advanced a step on Friday with the start of the World Chess Championship, the first championship in the United States since 1995, at the Fulton Market Building. The 12-game match, which is scheduled to run until the end of the month, pits the champion, Magnus Carlsen of Norway, 25, against the Russian challenger, Sergey Karjakin, 26, who disheartened many American chess fans by defeating two higher-rated American players in the qualifying tournament in March.

2016-11-12.abstract: Civil rights groups say their inboxes and call centers are lighting up with reports of abuse, but caution that it’s too soon to say whether the trend will last.

2016-11-12.lead_paragraph: In New York, men shouted, “You’re next!” at a black policewoman, making shooting motions with their hands. In California, a high school student told a classmate, “You support Trump? You hate Mexicans!” before throwing her to the ground and hitting her. Online, anonymous users wrote on Twitter, “Just reported you to ICE. Expect a van at your door tomorrow” to illegal immigrants.

2016-11-12.abstract: Did she really expect me to respect her choice when it undermined my presence in this country, in this university, in my very own dorm room?
2016-11-12.snippet: Did she really expect me to respect her choice when it undermined my presence in this country, in this university, in my very own dorm room?
2016-11-12.lead_paragraph: When she outed herself to me as a Trump supporter, I realized I had finally found the “silent majority.” I looked at her, this suddenly strange girl who sleeps a few feet away from me, my college roommate. The silent majority has seen me put on my head scarf in the morning and take it off at night. The silent majority has touched my face, done my makeup, watches “Gilmore Girls” religiously. The silent majority occasionally enjoys sliced mango before bed.
2016-11-12.headline_main: I’m Muslim, but My Roommate Supports Trump

This young man grew up in a fairly disadvantaged neighborhood, in a fairly disadvantaging city, in a very disadvantaging nation — all the result of our shared history of slavery and institutional inequality that allows American cops to choke blacks on Youtube and go home and play with the kids.

2016-11-12.abstract: The president-elect would do well to recognize the profound concern of Western democracies used to seeing America as a beacon for progress and stability.
2016-11-12.snippet: The president-elect would do well to recognize the profound concern of Western democracies used to seeing America as a beacon for progress and stability.
2016-11-12.lead_paragraph: The forces that brought Donald Trump to victory were largely American. The repercussions of his election, however, have rocked Western democracies accustomed to seeing the United States as a beacon for democracy, progress and stability. If the president-elect wants to take seriously his responsibilities as head of the free world, he should waste no time in making clear how much of his campaign bluster was just that.
2016-11-12.headline_main: The World Waits and Wonders About Donald Trump

2016-11-12.lead_paragraph: News of the death of Leonard Cohen, musical poet and great Canadian, hit on Thursday like a punch to the gut, an early blast of winter. We can do the Leonard Cohen thing and brood. Or we can heed this spontaneous eulogy from another of our most admired songwriters, Rosanne Cash. “Rolling through Iowa,” she said on Twitter on Friday afternoon, “in wonder and awe that we had such a man.”

But in the days leading up to the election, there was a distinct possibility that this 227-year-old gender barrier would be hurdled, and so we asked women to tell us about their own vividly recalled barriers. Almost 1,200 of you responded. Here are some of your stories.

2016-11-12.abstract: Petworth, a neighborhood in the District of Columbia, is popular with young families — and flippers.
2016-11-12.snippet: Petworth, a neighborhood in the District of Columbia, is popular with young families — and flippers.
2016-11-12.lead_paragraph: In 2009, Robert H. Mandle and his wife, Maria, were living in an apartment in Arlington, Va., and shopping for a single-family home. They were shown a 1919 three-bedroom townhouse in Petworth, a centrally situated neighborhood in the District of Columbia. The 1,775-square-foot house on Rock Creek Church Road NW was at the end of a row of attached buildings, which meant it had abundant light. And then there was the charming fact that President Lincoln had spent his summers across the road. But the property, which was listed at more than $400,000, needed cosmetic improvements and seemed expensive for the amount of space.
2016-11-12.headline_main: Petworth, Washington, D.C.: A Place of Porches

2016-11-12.lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, when Hillary Clinton stood in the New Yorker Hotel for her farewell speech, she did so in one of her signature Ralph Lauren pantsuits. Dark gray, with purple lapels and a matching purple shirt (and a matching purple tie for Bill Clinton), it underscored, as so many of her fashion choices did in the run-up to the election, a point: the way two colors/factions — red and blue — can unite to make something new.

2016-11-12.abstract: Can those allergic to cats and dogs expect accommodations in buildings where pets are welcome?
2016-11-12.snippet: Can those allergic to cats and dogs expect accommodations in buildings where pets are welcome?
2016-11-12.lead_paragraph: Q. I live in a pet-friendly co-op in Riverdale, in the Bronx. Unfortunately, I am highly allergic to dogs and cats. When pet owners wash their pets’ clothes and bedding in the common laundry room, some of them do not clean out the hair from the lint catchers in the dryers, leaving me to clean it out. This has triggered several allergic reactions. When I asked the board to set aside specific washers and dryers for the pet paraphernalia, it refused, saying pet owners should have unlimited access to all machines. Do any city rules address this problem? And what can be done to mitigate my problem?
2016-11-12.headline_main: Pet Allergies in a Pet-Friendly Building

2016-11-12.abstract: This is the story of the Paris attacks by those who lived through them. “I will always live with the fact that I saw ringing cellphones that said ‘Papa,’ ‘Maman,’ on the dead.”
2016-11-12.snippet: This is the story of the Paris attacks by those who lived through them. “I will always live with the fact that I saw ringing cellphones that said ‘Papa,’ ‘Maman,’ on the dead.”
2016-11-12.lead_paragraph: The night of Nov. 13, 2015, Islamic State militants attacked eight places in and around Paris, killing 130 people and wounding nearly 500. It was the most lethal attack in France since World War II. Confusion gripped the city as two teams of attackers struck nearly simultaneously. One struck at the Stade de France, just outside Paris, while the other shot up cafes and bars in the hip 10th and 11th Arrondissements. About 20 minutes later, a third team of attackers entered the Bataclan concert hall in the same neighborhood, taking hostages and killing scores.
2016-11-12.headline_main: Paris: One Year On

2016-11-12.lead_paragraph: My wife Sheryl WuDunn and I are in Philadelphia for a meeting of the American Philosophical Society, and this morning at about 7 I went down to the Franklin Hotel lobby to grab a cup of coffee. Sheryl was sleeping, so to reduce the sound I closed the door but didn’t quite let it lock. A man emerged from somewhere at about the same time and also seemed to be waiting for the elevator, but when it came he said that he was waiting for his wife and I should go ahead.
2016-11-12.headline_main: Why You Should Always Lock Your Hotel Room Door!

2016-11-12.lead_paragraph: Bitterness. Hostility. Rage. The varieties of anger are endless. Some are mild, such as grumpiness, and others are powerful, such as wrath. Different angers vary not only in their intensity but also in their purpose. It’s normal to feel exasperated with your screaming infant and scornful of a political opponent, but scorn toward your baby would be bizarre.
2016-11-12.headline_main: The Varieties of Anger

2016-11-12.abstract: An extraordinary period of globalization has ended. The period from World War I through World War II offers lessons for what might come next.
2016-11-12.snippet: An extraordinary period of globalization has ended. The period from World War I through World War II offers lessons for what might come next.
2016-11-12.lead_paragraph: The age of globalization generated great prosperity. As the flow of goods, money and people across borders surged, millions benefited. But the elite gained the most. And as inequality rose, it stirred pockets of fierce resentment among those left behind. When the great shock came, the discontented turned to nationalist firebrands, who promised to impose controls on free trade, global banks and immigrants. Globalization stalled. A new age of deglobalization hit full stride.
2016-11-12.headline_main: When Borders Close

2016-11-12.snippet: Scenes from a triumphant Trump first term.

2016-11-12.headline_main: He Made America Feel Great Again

2016-11-12.abstract: How does a party that views government as the enemy actually begin to govern?
2016-11-12.snippet: How does a party that views government as the enemy actually begin to govern?
2016-11-12.lead_paragraph: Washington — On the morning of Nov. 8, Republicans in the nation’s capital were grim-faced and resigned to Hillary Clinton’s impending triumph, hoping only that Donald J. Trump wouldn’t lose so badly as to cost the party the Senate. By midnight they were in ecstasy, as it became apparent that Mr. Trump would take the presidency and Republicans would maintain majorities in both houses of Congress. A few months from now, it’s all but certain that Mr. Trump will nominate, and the Senate will confirm, a new conservative Supreme Court justice. At that point, Republicans will control all three branches of government.
2016-11-12.headline_main: When Republicans Take Power

2016-11-12.lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago I was sitting poolside in Florida with a friendly retiree who was standing in the warm aqua water, beaming with friendliness. We started chatting, first about his hometown, Pittsburgh, and the many great athletes from there. Soon the conversation pivoted to Vietnam and his experiences as a draftee there. Embarrassed because I was spared from that jungle and moral crucible, I just listened. First it was a few madcap stories about his arrival in ’Nam, but then his thoughts swam along a darker current.
2016-11-12.headline_main: What’s the Use of Regret?

Trump campaigned on the slogan “Make America Great Again,” a phrase whose “great” was widely heard as “white.” Certainly the election has been analyzed as a victory for white Christian Americans, especially men. Against Mr. Trump were all the rest of us: professionals with advanced degrees and the multiracial, multiethnic millions.

2016-11-12.snippet: Since my story went public, I’ve heard from many women about their painful experiences.
2016-11-12.lead_paragraph: I’ve never been a good sleeper, but now more than ever, after having lost my job as a news anchor this past summer, I find myself lying awake at night thinking about my daughter — and your daughters, too. I’ve been asking myself this simple question: Will our girls finally be the ones to have workplaces free from sexual harassment? This question became even more compelling during the presidential race, where offensive comments about women were dismissed as “locker room talk.”
2016-11-12.headline_main: Gretchen Carlson: My Fight Against Sexual Harassment

2016-11-12.abstract: In which the term “Casual Friday” takes on a whole new meaning, thanks to Joel Fagliano.

2016-11-12.lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — If you work for a company that has a “Casual Friday” policy, you know that the extent to which you can dress casually is largely dictated by the company. You’re never going to come to work in your favorite sweats, but you’re also freed from the more binding forms of corporate wear.
2016-11-12.headline_main: Clothes That Fit

2016-11-12.abstract: Mr. Nilekani, finally free to focus on investments, fears an increase in anti-globalization sentiment but is betting on India.
2016-11-12.snippet: Mr. Nilekani, finally free to focus on investments, fears an increase in anti-globalization sentiment but is betting on India.
2016-11-12.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Nandan Nilekani, a co-founder of one of India’s biggest information technology services companies, is an older billionaire but a young investor. In his nearly 30 years of starting and then building up Infosys, he did not have the time to focus on investing anywhere else, he said. Not to mention that most of his wealth was tied up in the company.
2016-11-12.headline_main: How Nandan Nilekani, an Infosys Billionaire, Invests His Money

2016-11-12.abstract: Voters discuss what comes next for white, black and brown Americans.
2016-11-12.snippet: Voters discuss what comes next for white, black and brown Americans.
2016-11-12.lead_paragraph: (Race/Related is a weekly newsletter exploring race and ethnicity. Scattered throughout this edition are views of some Brooklyn voters in artwork by Cari Vander Yacht. These illustrations are juxtaposed against extended conversations with a handful of white Trump voters about race, identity, and politics. Sign up. Tell us what you think racerelated@nytimes.com.)
2016-11-12.headline_main: Trump and Identity
