2016-11-17.lead_paragraph: Target’s bull’s-eye will be hard to repeat.
2016-11-17.headline_main: Target’s Turnaround Still Faces Challenges

2016-11-17.abstract: The director discusses a sequence where Newt Scamander (Eddie Redmayne) loses track of one of his beasts in a bank.
2016-11-17.snippet: The director discusses a sequence where Newt Scamander (Eddie Redmayne) loses track of one of his beasts in a bank.
2016-11-17.lead_paragraph: A wizard (Eddie Redmayne) reveals his powers to an unsuspecting bank customer (Dan Fogler) in this scene from “Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them,” the new movie from the Harry Potter universe with an original screenplay by J. K. Rowling. The film takes place in 1926 New York and centers on the magizoologist Newt Scamander (Mr. Redmayne) and the magical creatures he carries around in a suitcase.
2016-11-17.headline_main: David Yates Narrates a Scene From ‘Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them’

2016-11-17.abstract: Mr. Dassey was to be freed on Friday while the state appealed a judge’s ruling overturning his 2007 conviction on murder and sexual assault.
2016-11-17.snippet: Mr. Dassey was to be freed on Friday while the state appealed a judge’s ruling overturning his 2007 conviction on murder and sexual assault.
2016-11-17.lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court on Thursday blocked the release of Brendan Dassey, one of the subjects of Netflix’s “Making a Murderer,” from a prison in Wisconsin while the state appeals a judge’s decision to overturn his conviction on murder and sexual assault charges.
2016-11-17.headline_main: Appeals Court Blocks Release of Brendan Dassey, of ‘Making a Murderer’

2016-11-17.abstract: Since I had just gotten a clingy gold cocktail dress for a fancy awards dinner, I felt a restrictive, possibly totalitarian, undergarment was necessary.
2016-11-17.snippet: Since I had just gotten a clingy gold cocktail dress for a fancy awards dinner, I felt a restrictive, possibly totalitarian, undergarment was necessary.
2016-11-17.lead_paragraph: I’m a little tired today because I just went six rounds with a Spanx Extra Firm Control body suit, an undergarment constructed with the same sort of expandable concrete used in airport runways. Possibly you heard us battling it out at Saks. I knew Spanx’s reputation, of course. I’d been told by friends that putting on one of their control garments would take every ounce of strength in me, that women have gotten these items on only to pass out on the floor and never make it to their event.
2016-11-17.headline_main: Suck It In, New York, It’s Party Season

2016-11-17.abstract: Most fracking-induced quakes in the United States are related to wastewater disposal from oil and gas wells. Scientists see a different culprit in Alberta.
2016-11-17.snippet: Most fracking-induced quakes in the United States are related to wastewater disposal from oil and gas wells. Scientists see a different culprit in Alberta.
2016-11-17.lead_paragraph: In the debate over fracking of oil and gas wells, opponents often cite the risk that the process can set off nearby earthquakes. But scientists say that in the United States, fracking-induced earthquakes are not common.
2016-11-17.headline_main: In Canada, a Direct Link Between Fracking and Earthquakes

2016-11-17.abstract: The industry group backpedals after a backlash from architects and says it will hold events across the country to promote dialogue.
2016-11-17.snippet: The industry group backpedals after a backlash from architects and says it will hold events across the country to promote dialogue.
2016-11-17.lead_paragraph: A week after the American Institute of Architects pledged to work with President-elect Donald J. Trump, the organization walked back its statement and apologized.
2016-11-17.headline_main: American Institute of Architects Apologizes for Statement of Support for Trump

2016-11-17.abstract: By altering photosynthesis in tobacco, researchers improved the plant’s production, a method they hope will prove successful in food crops.
2016-11-17.snippet: By altering photosynthesis in tobacco, researchers improved the plant’s production, a method they hope will prove successful in food crops.
2016-11-17.lead_paragraph: URBANA, Ill. — A decade ago, agricultural scientists at the University of Illinois suggested a bold approach to improve the food supply: tinker with photosynthesis, the chemical reaction powering nearly all life on Earth.
2016-11-17.headline_main: With an Eye on Hunger, Scientists See Promise in Genetic Tinkering of Plants

2016-11-17.abstract: The big weekend, which includes Atlético Madrid versus Real Madrid and Manchester United versus Arsenal, is a chance for four European leagues to battle globally for fans and sponsors.
2016-11-17.snippet: The big weekend, which includes Atlético Madrid versus Real Madrid and Manchester United versus Arsenal, is a chance for four European leagues to battle globally for fans and sponsors.
2016-11-17.lead_paragraph: Nothing, perhaps, has better captured what it means when Atlético Madrid faces Real Madrid than what Luis Aragonés uttered a few minutes before the final of the 1992 Copa del Rey.
2016-11-17.headline_main: On Rivalry Weekend in Europe, the Real Battle Is for Viewers Elsewhere

2016-11-17.abstract: Interest in the often esoteric natural wine category is strong as the recent RAW Wine fair in Brooklyn shows.
2016-11-17.snippet: Interest in the often esoteric natural wine category is strong as the recent RAW Wine fair in Brooklyn shows.
2016-11-17.lead_paragraph: It may seem shocking, precious or counterintuitive to think of wine as alive. But RAW Wine billed its recent trade and consumer fair as a celebration of “wines with emotion. Wines that have a humanlike, or living, presence.”
2016-11-17.headline_main: Wine That’s Not Only Natural, It’s Alive

2016-11-17.abstract: “Art in a Time of Chaos” at the China Institute Gallery features singular works from between the third and sixth centuries, which was a tumultuous period.
2016-11-17.snippet: “Art in a Time of Chaos” at the China Institute Gallery features singular works from between the third and sixth centuries, which was a tumultuous period.
2016-11-17.lead_paragraph: What a shock to wake up one morning and find armed men, who spoke no language you knew and looked like no people you’d ever seen, roaming the streets of your city. And more shocking still to learn that your protectors — your leaders, your army — had fled in the night. This scene repeated itself many times in China beginning in the third century A.D., when the Han dynasty collapsed and non-Chinese nomads swept down from the north and breached the Great Wall.
2016-11-17.headline_main: Chinese History, Writ in Stunning Stone

2016-11-17.abstract: The government took steps Thursday to temper growing impatience with the seemingly slapdash way a ban on high-currency bills was carried out.
2016-11-17.snippet: The government took steps Thursday to temper growing impatience with the seemingly slapdash way a ban on high-currency bills was carried out.
2016-11-17.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — As the chaos surrounding Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s ban on high-currency bills entered its ninth day, the government moved Thursday to address some of the problems amid signs of growing impatience with the slapdash way the policy seems to have been carried out.
2016-11-17.headline_main: India Offers Some Relief to Chaos It Created With Currency Ban

2016-11-17.abstract: Those who feel misogyny carried the day are taking stands against a male-dominated world, from the workplace to rituals like holiday cards.
2016-11-17.snippet: Those who feel misogyny carried the day are taking stands against a male-dominated world, from the workplace to rituals like holiday cards.
2016-11-17.lead_paragraph: This year, Svea Vikander has decided that she and Evla, her 3-year-old daughter, will be the focal point of her family’s holiday card. She decided to relegate her husband and son to a smaller picture below.
2016-11-17.headline_main: After the Election, Some Women Assert Themselves With Small Gestures

2016-11-17.abstract: Baltimore City Public Schools said the teacher was no longer employed, and a school district official said she had crossed the line.
2016-11-17.snippet: Baltimore City Public Schools said the teacher was no longer employed, and a school district official said she had crossed the line.
2016-11-17.lead_paragraph: A Baltimore public-school teacher is no longer employed after a cellphone video showed her berating minority students with “abusive” language that included a racial slur, the school district said on Thursday.
2016-11-17.headline_main: Video Shows Baltimore Teacher Using Racial Slur in Class

2016-11-17.abstract: Turnout did not plummet this year, as some argued. But it did change.
2016-11-17.snippet: Turnout did not plummet this year, as some argued. But it did change.
2016-11-17.lead_paragraph: Barack Obama’s two victories created the impression of a strong wind at the back of the Democratic Party. Its constituencies — the young, the nonwhite, the college educated — were not only growing but were also voting in increasing numbers. The age-old issue of voter turnout finally seemed to be helping the political left.
2016-11-17.headline_main: The Democrats’ Real Turnout Problem

2016-11-17.snippet: Suggested reading by book critics and editors at The New York Times.
2016-11-17.lead_paragraph: At a moment when all eyes are glued to the tumult of escalating news headlines, let’s take a few hours, a day, perhaps even a long weekend to take refuge in the stories that transcend the news cycle and the books that more deeply explain the forces behind it.
2016-11-17.headline_main: 8 New Books We Recommend This Week

2016-11-17.abstract: The group Space Center Houston is helping restore the 1960s appearance of the operations room of the Mission Control Center in Houston during Apollo moon missions.
2016-11-17.snippet: The group Space Center Houston is helping restore the 1960s appearance of the operations room of the Mission Control Center in Houston during Apollo moon missions.
2016-11-17.lead_paragraph: During the Apollo moon missions, tension filled the operations room at the Apollo Mission Control Center in Houston. NASA staffers’ consoles were not only piled with paperwork but also hastily removed suit jackets, American flags and uneaten snacks. And their amber glass ashtrays overflowed with cigarette butts.
2016-11-17.headline_main: Apollo Missions to the Moon: The Memorabilia Stage

2016-11-17.abstract: The Times opinion columnist Andrew Rosenthal on Trump’s appointments, contact with Vladimir Putin and other news. Susan Lehman is host.
2016-11-17.snippet: The Times opinion columnist Andrew Rosenthal on Trump’s appointments, contact with Vladimir Putin and other news. Susan Lehman is host.
2016-11-17.lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this podcast, Andrew Rosenthal, a Times Op-Ed columnist, talks about the news — the good, the bad and that which makes him mad.
2016-11-17.headline_main: Good, Bad and Mad: Andrew Rosenthal on the News

2016-11-17.abstract: “New York at Its Core,” at the Museum of the City of New York, considers what money, density and diversity have wrought from 1609 to today.
2016-11-17.snippet: “New York at Its Core,” at the Museum of the City of New York, considers what money, density and diversity have wrought from 1609 to today.
2016-11-17.lead_paragraph: “NEW YORK AT ITS CORE,” which opens Friday at the Museum of the City of New York, is the culmination of an audacious curatorial gamble: Is it possible to make a metropolis that is perpetually in flux the centerpiece of what the museum bills as its first permanent exhibition?
2016-11-17.headline_main: This Museum Show Explains Why New York Is So New Yorky

2016-11-17.abstract: A reader points out that Democrats won the popular vote for president and made gains in the Senate and the House.
2016-11-17.snippet: A reader points out that Democrats won the popular vote for president and made gains in the Senate and the House.
2016-11-17.lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
2016-11-17.headline_main: Not a Republican Mandate

2016-11-17.abstract: Swansea, once a hub of industrial activity, has fallen on harder times. A project to harness tides in the nearby bay offers a chance at rejuvenation.
2016-11-17.snippet: Swansea, once a hub of industrial activity, has fallen on harder times. A project to harness tides in the nearby bay offers a chance at rejuvenation.
2016-11-17.lead_paragraph: SWANSEA, Wales — From the brackish, brown water of the bay, Swansea’s past fortunes are plain to see.
2016-11-17.headline_main: For a Welsh City, the Tides Offer Renewal

2016-11-17.abstract: Social media’s political sway is a given in places like the Philippines, Indonesia and Colombia, where false news often emerges to influence the vote.
2016-11-17.snippet: Social media’s political sway is a given in places like the Philippines, Indonesia and Colombia, where false news often emerges to influence the vote.
2016-11-17.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Facebook rumors force a well-known politician to publish proof of his heritage. Fake images show a prominent female leader in a hangman’s noose. A politician’s aide decries violent crime with a Facebook photo of a girl’s corpse — an image that turns out to come from another country.
2016-11-17.headline_main: Fake News in U.S. Election? Elsewhere, That’s Nothing New

2016-11-17.abstract: By studying hills that formed after an asteroid struck the Yucatán Peninsula, researchers found that materials deep in Earth’s crust were brought toward the surface.
2016-11-17.snippet: By studying hills that formed after an asteroid struck the Yucatán Peninsula, researchers found that materials deep in Earth’s crust were brought toward the surface.
2016-11-17.lead_paragraph: Some 66 million years ago an asteroid crashed into the Yucatán Peninsula in Mexico, triggering the extinction event that obliterated the dinosaurs and nearly extinguished all life on Earth. It struck with the same energy as 100 million atomic bombs, and left behind a 100-mile-wide scar known today as the Chicxulub crater.
2016-11-17.headline_main: Drilling Into the Chicxulub Crater, Ground Zero of the Dinosaur Extinction

2016-11-17.abstract: This exhibition at the Children’s Museum of the Arts includes David Bowie’s earliest music video and other interstellar adventures for kids (and parents).
2016-11-17.snippet: This exhibition at the Children’s Museum of the Arts includes David Bowie’s earliest music video and other interstellar adventures for kids (and parents).
2016-11-17.lead_paragraph: Ground Control to Major Tom: Hordes of children are invading your space.
2016-11-17.headline_main: David Bowie and Other Artists Lead Children on a Galactic Adventure

2016-11-17.abstract: Even fans of chess might struggle to connect with the cursory approach to this documentary’s subject, the prodigy Magnus Carlsen, and to the game itself.
2016-11-17.snippet: Even fans of chess might struggle to connect with the cursory approach to this documentary’s subject, the prodigy Magnus Carlsen, and to the game itself.
2016-11-17.lead_paragraph: There’s something ineffably sad about child prodigies. Tramping along an often solitary path to greatness, one that allows few detours for the innocent pleasures of childhood, these small wonders can tug at the heart. And so it is with Magnus Carlsen, the Norwegian chess champion at the center of “Magnus,” Benjamin Ree’s insipid and uninformative portrait of singularity and obsession.
2016-11-17.headline_main: Review: ‘Magnus’ Delves Into the Life of a ‘Mozart of Chess’

2016-11-17.abstract: The Belgian documentary begins with a divorce, follows a man to rehab, and includes the aftermath of an alcohol-induced auto accident.
2016-11-17.snippet: The Belgian documentary begins with a divorce, follows a man to rehab, and includes the aftermath of an alcohol-induced auto accident.
2016-11-17.lead_paragraph: The Belgian documentary “Ne Me Quitte Pas” (“Don’t Leave Me”) begins with a bang, so to speak. A man and a woman are discussing their marriage, or soon-to-be lack thereof; the woman is leaving him. The man, drawing from a can of beer, casually requests sex from her one last time. Befuddled, she refuses. He presses the issue, wryly, or, rather, in a tone that he believes to be wry. “You’ll forget me in no time,” the woman says with firmness and equanimity.
2016-11-17.headline_main: Review: ‘Ne Me Quitte Pas’ Takes 2 Alcoholics and Chronicles the Tedium of Their Lives

2016-11-17.abstract: A Chinese comedic melodrama, with a divorce of convenience followed by a real jilting, has situational intrigue marred by a labored approach.
2016-11-17.snippet: A Chinese comedic melodrama, with a divorce of convenience followed by a real jilting, has situational intrigue marred by a labored approach.
2016-11-17.lead_paragraph: There’s some intriguing social commentary in the Chinese comedic melodrama “I Am Not Madame Bovary,” an adaptation of Liu Zhenyun’s novel of the same name, directed by Feng Xiaogang. But appreciating it, and the other points of interest in the movie, requires a perhaps unusual amount of patience, or even indulgence.
2016-11-17.headline_main: Review: ‘I Am Not Madame Bovary’ Takes Man Trouble to New Levels

2016-11-17.abstract: Automakers promoted their high-tech bona fides and environmentally friendly conscience at the AutoMobility LA conference.
2016-11-17.snippet: Automakers promoted their high-tech bona fides and environmentally friendly conscience at the AutoMobility LA conference.
2016-11-17.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — For decades, the car business has been about style, performance, image and fuel efficiency. But suddenly, the industry is in a technological and sociological upheaval that may force automobiles — and the companies that make them — to change more in the next five years than they have in the last 50.
2016-11-17.headline_main: At the Los Angeles Auto Show, an Industry Ponders Its Digital Future

2016-11-17.abstract: With Bob on his shoulder, a homeless busker, James, is able to face just about anything — a negligent father, street ruffians and drug withdrawal.
2016-11-17.snippet: With Bob on his shoulder, a homeless busker, James, is able to face just about anything — a negligent father, street ruffians and drug withdrawal.
2016-11-17.lead_paragraph: If Grumpy Cat and “Keanu” haven’t sated your appetite for screen felines, try “A Street Cat Named Bob,” a savvy exercise in inspirational feel-good cinema lightly seasoned with grit. Adapted from James Bowen’s autobiography (part of a Bob franchise), the movie, directed by Roger Spottiswoode, tells how an orange cat enters the life of James (Luke Treadaway), a homeless London busker struggling with heroin addiction. Though James has a sobriety adviser (a firm Joanne Froggatt, as a persuasive living argument for public health care) who finds him housing, it is the cat, which James names Bob, who teaches him about responsibility and what it’s like to feel loved.
2016-11-17.headline_main: Review: ‘A Street Cat Named Bob’ Helps His Owner Detox

2016-11-17.abstract: Putting the two together will yield a green-energy company whose products include electric cars and solar panels for homes.
2016-11-17.snippet: Putting the two together will yield a green-energy company whose products include electric cars and solar panels for homes.
2016-11-17.lead_paragraph: PALM SPRINGS, Calif. — Elon Musk has succeeded in combining two parts of his business empire, as investors in Tesla Motors and in the solar panel maker SolarCity agreed on Thursday to a merger.
2016-11-17.headline_main: Tesla and SolarCity Shareholders Approve Merger

2016-11-17.abstract: Brooklyn Touring Outfit’s “Co. Venture” explores the ties between the dancer Pepper Fajans, 31, and David Vaughan, 92, a former Merce Cunningham archivist.
2016-11-17.snippet: Brooklyn Touring Outfit’s “Co. Venture” explores the ties between the dancer Pepper Fajans, 31, and David Vaughan, 92, a former Merce Cunningham archivist.
2016-11-17.lead_paragraph: When David Vaughan first met Pepper Fajans, it was not in Mr. Fajans’s capacity as a dancer (which he is), but as a carpenter (which he also is). Mr. Fajans was building a set for “Mondays With Merce,” a video series devoted to the work of the choreographer Merce Cunningham. Mr. Vaughan was the Cunningham company’s longtime archivist; Mr. Fajans eventually became Cunningham’s caretaker for 10 months until his death in 2009 and then, during the company’s final tour, looked after Mr. Vaughan. Despite their difference in ages — Mr. Vaughan is 92, Mr. Fajans 31 — they formed a deep bond.
2016-11-17.headline_main: Review: A Cross-Generational Bond, Conveyed in Dance

2016-11-17.abstract: Tips on how to navigate the holiday in an especially polarized climate.
2016-11-17.snippet: Tips on how to navigate the holiday in an especially polarized climate.
2016-11-17.lead_paragraph: My son is my only child. When he was 4, I divorced his father and raised him on my own. I didn’t receive any financial support, so I worked full time to support us. Now my son is married with three children. But since he married, I am not included in family holidays like Thanksgiving or Christmas. For years, I invited them, but they never accepted. They spend holidays with my daughter-in-law’s family. It bothers me that my in-laws don’t seem to care that I’m left alone. I’ve had many talks with my son about this, but nothing changes. Is there anything more I can do?
2016-11-17.headline_main: Dumped Moms, Gun-Toting Guests: It’s Thanksgiving

2016-11-17.abstract: President Obama, appearing with Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany, also warned Donald J. Trump to take the presidency seriously.
2016-11-17.snippet: President Obama, appearing with Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany, also warned Donald J. Trump to take the presidency seriously.
2016-11-17.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — In his strongest public comments since the election, President Obama on Thursday sharply criticized the spread of fake news online and said that President-elect Donald J. Trump would not remain in office for long if he failed to take the job seriously.
2016-11-17.headline_main: Obama, With Angela Merkel in Berlin, Assails Spread of Fake News

2016-11-17.abstract: Alan Williams, a reserve center, is in his second season with the Phoenix Suns. His mother, Jeri Williams, is in her first month as the leader of the city’s police force.
2016-11-17.snippet: Alan Williams, a reserve center, is in his second season with the Phoenix Suns. His mother, Jeri Williams, is in her first month as the leader of the city’s police force.
2016-11-17.lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Alan Williams and his mother, Jeri, watched on television this summer as San Francisco 49ers quarterback Colin Kaepernick protested police brutality and racial injustice by refusing to stand during the national anthem. Kaepernick’s political statement was personal for both Williams, a second-year player for the Phoenix Suns, and his mother, who had recently agreed to become the city’s police chief.
2016-11-17.headline_main: This Phoenix Suns Reserve Calls the City’s Police Chief ‘Mom’

2016-11-17.abstract: Idris Elba and Richard Madden star in this well-executed variation of the buddy-cop formula, set in Paris.
2016-11-17.snippet: Idris Elba and Richard Madden star in this well-executed variation of the buddy-cop formula, set in Paris.
2016-11-17.lead_paragraph: You’ve got to love the juxtaposition in “The Take,” a tasty thriller directed by James Watkins. Tech- and media-savvy bad guys go up against that most humble of miscreants: a pickpocket.
2016-11-17.headline_main: Review: A Pickpocket Is Recruited by the C.I.A. in ‘The Take’

2016-11-17.abstract: This documentary is a dual portrait of intertwined artists: Howard Brookner, who died of AIDS early in his career, and his nephew Aaron Brookner, now also a filmmaker.
2016-11-17.snippet: This documentary is a dual portrait of intertwined artists: Howard Brookner, who died of AIDS early in his career, and his nephew Aaron Brookner, now also a filmmaker.
2016-11-17.lead_paragraph: “Uncle Howard” begins with a scene portraying its director, Aaron Brookner, as a man on a mission. Filmed with a shaky video camera, he follows the poet John Giorno into his apartment, hot on the trail of a cache of films made by Mr. Brookner’s uncle, Howard Brookner.
2016-11-17.headline_main: Review: ‘Uncle Howard’ Looks Back at a Filmmaker’s Work Cut Short

2016-11-17.abstract: “With All Due Respect” will terminate as Bloomberg reshuffles its politics team.
2016-11-17.snippet: “With All Due Respect” will terminate as Bloomberg reshuffles its politics team.
2016-11-17.lead_paragraph: With the election now in the rearview mirror, Bloomberg has decided to terminate its daily politics show “With All Due Respect” hosted by the political journalists John Heilemann and Mark Halperin and refocus its Bloomberg Politics team, according to a staff memo on Thursday.
2016-11-17.headline_main: Bloomberg to End Its Daily Politics Show

2016-11-17.abstract: In its grandest project yet, the concert series Wordless Music will screen Terrence Malick’s film with live accompaniment at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
2016-11-17.snippet: In its grandest project yet, the concert series Wordless Music will screen Terrence Malick’s film with live accompaniment at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
2016-11-17.lead_paragraph: Ronen Givony, who founded the omnivorous concert series Wordless Music, is often surprised that he’s the first to pounce on a new musical opportunity. In 2008, he faced no competition from major orchestras in vying to give the American premiere of a piece by Radiohead’s Jonny Greenwood. And several years ago, he broke out of the pops-like mold of film-soundtrack karaoke with a live performance of the magical Cajun-inspired score for “Beasts of the Southern Wild.”
2016-11-17.headline_main: ‘The Tree of Life’ Unfurls, With a Live Orchestra and Choir

2016-11-17.abstract: The troupe, visiting from The Hague, is presenting four works from its repertory of contemporary ballet.
2016-11-17.snippet: The troupe, visiting from The Hague, is presenting four works from its repertory of contemporary ballet.
2016-11-17.lead_paragraph: The most technically proficient dancers aren’t always the ones who can make us feel most deeply. Take, for example, Nederlands Dans Theater, which returned to City Center on Wednesday. It appears there’s nothing that this limpid troupe can’t do, in terms of stretching the body to spectacular extremes. Yet for the most part, the choreography the dancers so impeccably master limits them to showing off.
2016-11-17.headline_main: Review: Nederlands Dans Theater Prizes Procedure Over Passion

2016-11-17.abstract: John Travolta and Kate Bosworth star in a cliché-filled drama about the men who keep power transmission lines working.
2016-11-17.snippet: John Travolta and Kate Bosworth star in a cliché-filled drama about the men who keep power transmission lines working.
2016-11-17.lead_paragraph: Hollywood desperately needs to expand its search for working-class heroes beyond the narrow universe of police officers, firefighters and soldiers. But underappreciated occupations deserve better than the cliché-clogged, utterly predictable “Life on the Line,” a terrible movie about the workers who keep the electrical grid functioning.
2016-11-17.headline_main: Review: ‘Life on the Line,’ a Plodding View of High-Wire Labor

2016-11-17.abstract: The museum has announced the 63 participants in its survey of what’s happening now in contemporary art — the new, the influential and the provocative.
2016-11-17.snippet: The museum has announced the 63 participants in its survey of what’s happening now in contemporary art — the new, the influential and the provocative.
2016-11-17.lead_paragraph: FOR the first time in 20 years, the lead-up to the Whitney Biennial coincided with the presidential election, a background that could not help but inform the selection of artists and artwork that will be on view when the biennial opens on March 17, the first in the museum’s new downtown building.
2016-11-17.headline_main: Here Comes the Whitney Biennial, Reflecting the Tumult of the Times

2016-11-17.abstract: This documentary about the industry in West Virginia is not well made but raises timely issues.
2016-11-17.snippet: This documentary about the industry in West Virginia is not well made but raises timely issues.
2016-11-17.lead_paragraph: “Blood on the Mountain” is a clumsily made attack on the coal industry in West Virginia, but it benefits considerably from the events of the past two weeks. The film jumps around chronologically and thematically in a way that dilutes its impact, but it still provides plenty of cause to question the wisdom of President-elect Donald J. Trump’s stated intentions of reviving coal mining and reducing environmental and other regulations.
2016-11-17.headline_main: Review: ‘Blood on the Mountain’ Looks at the Ravages of Coal Mining

2016-11-17.abstract: “Best Worst Thing That Ever Could Have Happened,” a documentary by Lonny Price, examines the buildup and collapse of “Merrily We Roll Along” in 1981.
2016-11-17.snippet: “Best Worst Thing That Ever Could Have Happened,” a documentary by Lonny Price, examines the buildup and collapse of “Merrily We Roll Along” in 1981.
2016-11-17.lead_paragraph: I was one of the few to see the original production of “Merrily We Roll Along,” which opened on Broadway in 1981 and, having received mostly catastrophic reviews, closed after 16 performances. On the night I saw it, the audience response was polite but halfhearted because by then it was already a certified flop.
2016-11-17.headline_main: Review: Merrily (and Ruefully) Recalling an Epic Broadway Flop

2016-11-17.abstract: During the era surrounding World War I, in the Caucasus region, a romance is complicated by religious and political boundaries.
2016-11-17.snippet: During the era surrounding World War I, in the Caucasus region, a romance is complicated by religious and political boundaries.
2016-11-17.lead_paragraph: “Ali and Nino” aspires to epicness and comes pretty close to getting there.
2016-11-17.headline_main: Review: ‘Ali and Nino,’ a Love Story Set Against Majestic Backdrops

2016-11-17.abstract: Anna Biller’s new film stars Samantha Robinson as a magical seductress whose charms turn out to be lethal.
2016-11-17.snippet: Anna Biller’s new film stars Samantha Robinson as a magical seductress whose charms turn out to be lethal.
2016-11-17.lead_paragraph: “The Love Witch” is, among other things, a study in the color red. Elaine, whose vocation is succinctly captured in the title of Anna Biller’s new film, is first seen driving north from San Francisco in a bright red convertible with a matching set of luggage in the back seat and a slightly contrasting shade of lipstick on her mouth and on the stubbed-out cigarettes in the car’s ashtray. Later on, red wine will be spilled, and there will be blood from various sources.
2016-11-17.headline_main: Review: ‘The Love Witch,’ Hell-Bent on Capturing Your Heart

2016-11-17.abstract: Adam Irving’s documentary is the story of Darius McCollum, a man with Asperger’s syndrome who borrows trains and buses for joy rides.
2016-11-17.snippet: Adam Irving’s documentary is the story of Darius McCollum, a man with Asperger’s syndrome who borrows trains and buses for joy rides.
2016-11-17.lead_paragraph: The documentary “Off the Rails,” Adam Irving’s first film, is an assured and thoughtful debut. He presents the story of Darius McCollum, a man with a long history of taking New York City subway trains and buses for joy rides even though he is not a transit employee. But Mr. Irving’s subtext is a criminal justice system that has no way to deal with an offender like Mr. McCollum, who has Asperger’s syndrome, other than to keep throwing him in prison.
2016-11-17.headline_main: Review: In ‘Off the Rails,’ an Eager Conductor Stalks New York’s Transit System

2016-11-17.abstract: Rosemary Mayer’s works offer a trip back to a feminist cooperative gallery; the Anton Kern Gallery celebrates with a group show; and Chapter NY juxtaposes two sculptors.
2016-11-17.snippet: Rosemary Mayer’s works offer a trip back to a feminist cooperative gallery; the Anton Kern Gallery celebrates with a group show; and Chapter NY juxtaposes two sculptors.
2016-11-17.lead_paragraph: Southfirst 60 North Sixth Street Williamsburg, Brooklyn Through Dec. 11
2016-11-17.headline_main: What to See in New York Art Galleries This Week

2016-11-17.abstract: In its raw honesty, “The Edge of Seventeen,” like “Clueless,” is among the best films about high school kids in years.
2016-11-17.snippet: In its raw honesty, “The Edge of Seventeen,” like “Clueless,” is among the best films about high school kids in years.
2016-11-17.lead_paragraph: In the grand scheme of things, losing a trusted friendship is a painful blow, but it usually isn’t the end of the world. If you’re an unpopular teenager, however, and the interloper is a sibling, it can feel like that.
2016-11-17.headline_main: Review: ‘The Edge of Seventeen’ Takes Teenage Movies to a Higher Place

2016-11-17.abstract: This summer’s Tanglewood Festival in the Berkshires will include Mr. Nelsons conducting or participating in 11 concerts over four weeks.
2016-11-17.snippet: This summer’s Tanglewood Festival in the Berkshires will include Mr. Nelsons conducting or participating in 11 concerts over four weeks.
2016-11-17.lead_paragraph: Bayreuth’s loss is the Berkshires’ gain.
2016-11-17.headline_main: Bayreuth’s Loss Is Tanglewood’s Gain, When It Comes to Andris Nelsons

2016-11-17.abstract: The film tells the true story of the brash fighter Vinny Pazienza, who fractured his neck in a car accident but earned his place back in the ring.
2016-11-17.snippet: The film tells the true story of the brash fighter Vinny Pazienza, who fractured his neck in a car accident but earned his place back in the ring.
2016-11-17.lead_paragraph: For its first 40 minutes or so, “Bleed for This,” the “based on a true story” boxing picture directed by Ben Younger and starring Miles Teller, follows the sports-movie-comeback-narrative playbook with extreme fidelity. It would be tiresome were it not for the casual energy of the filmmaking. Mr. Teller plays Vinny Pazienza, the Rhode Island-born-and-bred boxer who, as the film opens in 1988, seems a bit feckless. Staying up too late in Las Vegas the night before a big fight, he goes on to lose that match. His third in a row. His own manager announces in a televised interview that the fighter should hang up the towel.
2016-11-17.headline_main: Review: ‘Bleed for This’ Is a Boxing Movie That Gets Boxing

2016-11-17.abstract: This thriller, directed by Tom Ford, toggles between the life of a wealthy woman (Amy Adams) and the events in a novel she is reading by her ex-husband.
2016-11-17.snippet: This thriller, directed by Tom Ford, toggles between the life of a wealthy woman (Amy Adams) and the events in a novel she is reading by her ex-husband.
2016-11-17.lead_paragraph: Joan Didion wrote that “we tell ourselves stories in order to live.” Sometimes, though, we tell stories to kill, to stick a stiletto in and watch the blood drain. That’s the moral of “Nocturnal Animals,” a harsh cautionary tale about love, vengeance and the divide between life and art, that shadowy space in which real people are turned into fictional characters and old hurts made into narrative grist. Here, an unhappy girlfriend becomes a happy wife, a betrayed man becomes a victim all over again, and assorted murderers take turns bringing the pain.
2016-11-17.headline_main: Review: ‘Nocturnal Animals,’ Brutality Between the Pages and Among the Fabulous

2016-11-17.abstract: “Francis Picabia: Our Heads Are Round So Our Thoughts Can Change Direction” is the Museum of Modern Art’s first substantial show for an artist among the earliest proponents of Cubism and Dada.
2016-11-17.snippet: “Francis Picabia: Our Heads Are Round So Our Thoughts Can Change Direction” is the Museum of Modern Art’s first substantial show for an artist among the earliest proponents of Cubism and Dada.
2016-11-17.lead_paragraph: Make way for Francis Picabia, one of the grandest, most mordant exemplars of early modernism, and perhaps the least familiar. The Museum of Modern Art — having for decades drummed the artistic feats of Picasso, Matisse, Mondrian and Duchamp into cultural consciousness — has finally rolled out the red carpet for this capricious, prolific, subversive fellow traveler.
2016-11-17.headline_main: Francis Picabia, the Playboy Prankster of Modernism

2016-11-17.abstract: This “oral history” seeks a serious understanding of everything about Mr. Stewart, especially the thinking that made the show what it was.
2016-11-17.snippet: This “oral history” seeks a serious understanding of everything about Mr. Stewart, especially the thinking that made the show what it was.
2016-11-17.lead_paragraph: Chris Smith’s new book about “The Daily Show” in the Jon Stewart years has a theory about the events that let the show find its voice. After Bush vs. Gore in 2000 and just after the 9/11 attacks, real news became so surreal and television news so lathered that a fake news show could find its footing just by playing things relatively straight.
2016-11-17.headline_main: Review: ‘The Daily Show (The Book)’ Reveals How Jon Stewart Made News

2016-11-17.snippet: With authoritarian leaders on the rise, democratic values are increasingly threatened.
2016-11-17.lead_paragraph: President Obama is devoting much of the last foreign trip of his term to reassuring European allies that Washington will maintain its security commitments under Donald Trump and stay true to its democratic principles. Before leaving Washington, he met with Mr. Trump and said the president-elect “expressed a great interest in maintaining our core strategic relationships,” including “strong and robust NATO” partnerships.
2016-11-17.headline_main: When Obama’s Gone, Who Will Stand Up for Democracy?

2016-11-17.lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — The United States said Thursday that it was ready to impose an arms embargo against South Sudan, a shift in position that many rights groups called long overdue to help stop the deadly violence convulsing the world’s youngest country.
2016-11-17.headline_main: U.S., in Shift, Backs Arms Embargo for South Sudan as Genocide Risk Rises

I think Trump is in the White House because of me.”

2016-11-18.abstract: Within the professional political class, Mayor Bill de Blasio and Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo now seem to be elevating their longstanding rivalry to one for the role of progressive opponent in chief.
2016-11-18.snippet: Within the professional political class, Mayor Bill de Blasio and Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo now seem to be elevating their longstanding rivalry to one for the role of progressive opponent in chief.
2016-11-18.lead_paragraph: In the days since an election that will substantially reduce the likelihood of your going to Midtown more than three times over the next four years, the pervasive mood in New York has been grief-stricken and despairing. The city has emerged, perhaps unpredictably, as the nation’s capital of discontentment (Los Angeles, San Francisco, we know that you are trying), the frontier of enmity to the potential hardships and catastrophes Donald J. Trump’s impending presidency might produce.
2016-11-18.headline_main: With Anti-Trump Advantage, Cuomo and de Blasio Vie to Be Opponent in Chief

2016-11-18.abstract: The Dutch composer Louis Andriessen has won the Kravis prize, and the Philharmonic will debut a work of his with Jaap van Zweden, also Dutch, conducting.
2016-11-18.snippet: The Dutch composer Louis Andriessen has won the Kravis prize, and the Philharmonic will debut a work of his with Jaap van Zweden, also Dutch, conducting.
2016-11-18.lead_paragraph: The New York Philharmonic will offer its audiences a taste of new Amsterdam when the Dutch maestro Jaap van Zweden becomes its music director in the 2018-19 season.
2016-11-18.headline_main: An Extra Layer of Dutch for New York Philharmonic

2016-11-18.abstract: From a neighborhood farmers’ market to Russian bazaar in Brighton Beach, Ms. Motamed’s day is something of an epicurean odyssey.
2016-11-18.snippet: From a neighborhood farmers’ market to Russian bazaar in Brighton Beach, Ms. Motamed’s day is something of an epicurean odyssey.
2016-11-18.lead_paragraph: For Nilou Motamed, the editor in chief of Food & Wine magazine, Sundays are for exploring markets and restaurants near her home in Carroll Gardens — as well as several other neighborhoods. Ms. Motamed, 45, lives with her husband, Peter Jon Lindberg, 46, a contributing editor at Condé Nast Traveler, who also recently became director of inspiration for Conrad Hotels & Resorts. They met in 2000 while working at Travel & Leisure magazine. “Our first date was over martinis at the Royalton Vodka Bar, where we had a heated discussion about who made the best cannoli in New York,” she said. “We agreed to disagree, and three years later we were married.”
2016-11-18.headline_main: How Nilou Motamed, Editor of Food & Wine Magazine, Spends Her Sundays

2016-11-18.abstract: From her tiny kitchen in Chinatown, Sarah Lohman, a self-described historic gastronome, recreates eating regimens of yore.
2016-11-18.snippet: From her tiny kitchen in Chinatown, Sarah Lohman, a self-described historic gastronome, recreates eating regimens of yore.
2016-11-18.lead_paragraph: In the kitchen of her small apartment in Chinatown, Sarah Lohman worked a mound of pasta dough with a rolling pin.
2016-11-18.headline_main: Devouring (and Drinking) American History

2016-11-18.abstract: Mr. Rahimi is accused of setting off a bomb in Chelsea, and planting a second device that failed to detonate. He has also pleaded not guilty to charges that stem from attacks in New Jersey.
2016-11-18.snippet: Mr. Rahimi is accused of setting off a bomb in Chelsea, and planting a second device that failed to detonate. He has also pleaded not guilty to charges that stem from attacks in New Jersey.
2016-11-18.lead_paragraph: Ahmad Khan Rahimi, the New Jersey man accused of setting off a bomb in Manhattan on Sept. 17 that injured more than 30 people, pleaded not guilty on Thursday to federal charges stemming from that attack and a failed attempt to explode a bomb nearby.
2016-11-18.headline_main: Ahmad Rahimi Pleads Not Guilty in Manhattan Bombing

2016-11-18.abstract: The revamped system aims to address longer wait times by seating customers rather than having them wait at a counter.
2016-11-18.snippet: The revamped system aims to address longer wait times by seating customers rather than having them wait at a counter.

2016-11-18.lead_paragraph: Dear Diary,
2016-11-18.headline_main: A Memorable Night at McSorley’s

2016-11-18.abstract: The crowded, grubby shop on the Lower East Side of Manhattan has amassed a fervent group of loyalists with business practices that are increasingly rare.
2016-11-18.snippet: The crowded, grubby shop on the Lower East Side of Manhattan has amassed a fervent group of loyalists with business practices that are increasingly rare.

2016-11-18.abstract: Many of the artists whose works adorn the subway walls are not mosaic experts themselves. A master craftsman helps them recreate their visions.
2016-11-18.snippet: Many of the artists whose works adorn the subway walls are not mosaic experts themselves. A master craftsman helps them recreate their visions.
2016-11-18.lead_paragraph: Q. The mosaic that has gone up at the entrance to the Hudson Yards subway station on 34th Street is breathtaking. Who is responsible for selecting new artworks, and who installs them?
2016-11-18.headline_main: Who Installs the New Mosaics in New York’s Subways?

2016-11-18.abstract: Speaker Paul D. Ryan said the House would go along with the request and pass a stopgap measure that would keep the government running at current spending levels until March.

2016-11-18.headline_main: Donald Trump Seeks to Delay Action on Spending Bills Until His Term Starts

2016-11-18.abstract: In addition to developing system dynamics modeling, Mr. Forrester, an M.I.T. professor, was an inventor of magnetic core memory for computers.
2016-11-18.snippet: In addition to developing system dynamics modeling, Mr. Forrester, an M.I.T. professor, was an inventor of magnetic core memory for computers.
2016-11-18.lead_paragraph: Jay W. Forrester, an electrical engineer whose insights into both computing and organizations more than 60 years ago gave rise to a field of computer modeling that examines the behavior of things as specific as a corporation and as broad as global growth, died on Wednesday at his home in Concord, Mass. He was 98.
2016-11-18.headline_main: Jay W. Forrester Dies at 98; a Pioneer in Computer Models

2016-11-18.abstract: An article and a documentary drawing on material provided by Edward Snowden say the federal agency conducts surveillance from an AT&T building.

2016-11-18.lead_paragraph: On any person who desires such queer prizes, New York will bestow the gift of loneliness and the gift of privacy.

2016-11-18.abstract: Prime Minister Narendra Modi tries to fight corruption by calling in old rupees.
2016-11-18.snippet: Prime Minister Narendra Modi tries to fight corruption by calling in old rupees.
2016-11-18.lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India has declared war on corruption, a big factor in perpetuating poverty in that country. But his shocking decision on Nov. 8 to remove and replace large-denomination paper money was poorly thought out and executed.
2016-11-18.headline_main: India’s Strange Cash Problem

2016-11-18.abstract: Charlie Engle has run extreme distances for many reasons: to test his limits, to build his celebrity, to serve penance and to keep himself sane.
2016-11-18.snippet: Charlie Engle has run extreme distances for many reasons: to test his limits, to build his celebrity, to serve penance and to keep himself sane.
2016-11-18.lead_paragraph: It was a warm Saturday morning in October, and on a 50-acre farm just north of Bell Buckle, Tenn. (pop. 425), 46 runners gathered at the starting line, preparing to run one of the quirkiest, yet most arduous, of races. Called the Big Backyard Ultra, the race required contestants to run a course that spanned 4.167 miles, over trails etched out of the farm, every hour.
2016-11-18.headline_main: Charlie Engle Runs for His Life, Once Again

2016-11-18.abstract: We want to hear from those living in India on Mr. Modi’s move, and the impact it has had on you and your family.
2016-11-18.snippet: We want to hear from those living in India on Mr. Modi’s move, and the impact it has had on you and your family.

2016-11-18.headline_main: Tell Us How Narendra Modi’s Banning of Rupee Notes Affects You

2016-11-18.abstract: The president-elect met with the prime minister of Japan, Shinzo Abe, and also held meetings with several experts and the Israeli ambassador.
2016-11-18.snippet: The president-elect met with the prime minister of Japan, Shinzo Abe, and also held meetings with several experts and the Israeli ambassador.
2016-11-18.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President-elect Donald J. Trump embarked on one of the rituals of the American presidency on Thursday, meeting in New York with the prime minister of Japan, Shinzo Abe, as he continued his fitful adjustment to the protocols of high-level diplomacy.
2016-11-18.headline_main: Donald Trump, After Fits and Starts, Focuses on Foreign Policy

2016-11-18.abstract: The Yankees reportedly shed $23 million of McCann’s contract over the next two years, while paving the way for Gary Sanchez to be the everyday catcher.
2016-11-18.snippet: The Yankees reportedly shed $23 million of McCann’s contract over the next two years, while paving the way for Gary Sanchez to be the everyday catcher.
2016-11-18.lead_paragraph: Continuing their transformation into a younger and financially leaner team, the Yankees traded Brian McCann and cash on Thursday to the Houston Astros for two raw pitching prospects, Albert Abreu and Jorge Guzman.
2016-11-18.headline_main: Yankees Trade Brian McCann to the Astros

2016-11-18.abstract: In 2006, the former New York City mayor made $10 million from 108 speeches he delivered to audiences around the world, and more money from other projects.
2016-11-18.snippet: In 2006, the former New York City mayor made $10 million from 108 speeches he delivered to audiences around the world, and more money from other projects.
2016-11-18.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It was a golden year for Rudolph W. Giuliani, a mad dash that would take him to 11 countries on four continents, and by the time 2006 was done, earn him $16 million — a princely sum compared with the $7,000 he claimed to have in 2001, when he went through a divorce.
2016-11-18.headline_main: How Rudolph Giuliani, Possible Cabinet Pick, Made Millions as Ex-Mayor

2016-11-18.abstract: Mr. Denk’s performance, which concluded Lincoln Center’s White Light Festival, wove a story through the ages.
2016-11-18.snippet: Mr. Denk’s performance, which concluded Lincoln Center’s White Light Festival, wove a story through the ages.
2016-11-18.lead_paragraph: The inquisitive pianist Jeremy Denk faced a challenge in planning “Medieval to Modern,” the program he presented at Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday. Over some 80 minutes, with no breaks, Mr. Denk played 23 works spanning 600 years, from a lament by the 14th-century French composer Guillaume de Machaut to an obsessive 1985 étude by Gyorgy Ligeti.
2016-11-18.headline_main: Review: Jeremy Denk and His Piano Take a 600-Year Tour

2016-11-18.abstract: Ms. Balmori’s projects included buildings, gardens and master plans that emanated from “very clear human engineering with ecology and with landscape.”
2016-11-18.snippet: Ms. Balmori’s projects included buildings, gardens and master plans that emanated from “very clear human engineering with ecology and with landscape.”
2016-11-18.lead_paragraph: Diana Balmori, a landscape architect whose ecologically sensitive designs integrated buildings and the natural environment in projects ranging in scope from urban rooftop gardens to South Korea’s new administrative capital, Sejong City, died on Monday in Manhattan. She was 84.
2016-11-18.headline_main: Diana Balmori, Landscape Architect With a Blending Philosophy, Dies at 84

2016-11-18.abstract: James Rackover, 25, and Lawrence Dilione, 28, are accused of killing Joseph Comunale, 26, in Manhattan, then burying his body on the Jersey Shore.
2016-11-18.snippet: James Rackover, 25, and Lawrence Dilione, 28, are accused of killing Joseph Comunale, 26, in Manhattan, then burying his body on the Jersey Shore.
2016-11-18.lead_paragraph: Two men were charged with murder in Manhattan on Thursday, a day after the body of a Connecticut man they had partied with over the weekend was found in a shallow grave on the Jersey Shore.
2016-11-18.headline_main: 2 Men Charged With Murder After Buried Body Is Found in New Jersey

2016-11-18.abstract: In this dance-theater piece, the second in a proposed trilogy, adults act — and act out — like teenagers putting on a show.
2016-11-18.snippet: In this dance-theater piece, the second in a proposed trilogy, adults act — and act out — like teenagers putting on a show.
2016-11-18.lead_paragraph: Will Faye Driscoll ever grow up? At BAM Fisher on Wednesday, this choreographer presented the New York premiere of her “Thank You for Coming: Play.” The second installment in a proposed trilogy, it’s the latest in a longer line of works that expend her considerable directorial skill and creative vitality on sophomoric attitudes, ideas and sentiments.
2016-11-18.headline_main: Review: Faye Driscoll’s ‘Play’ Channels a Howl Into Fun and Games

2016-11-18.abstract: Stripped of its cinematic distractions, this Off Broadway adaptation directed by John Doyle comes across as blunt and bland.
2016-11-18.snippet: Stripped of its cinematic distractions, this Off Broadway adaptation directed by John Doyle comes across as blunt and bland.
2016-11-18.lead_paragraph: A lone spark of subversion brightens the generally damp proceedings of “Dead Poets Society,” which opened on Thursday night at Classic Stage Company, directed by that streamliner deluxe John Doyle and featuring the comic film star Jason Sudeikis in an advanced state of decency. This enlivening flicker occurs well past the midpoint of Tom Schulman’s tidy adaptation of his Oscar-winning screenplay from 1989, when hopes have worn thin.
2016-11-18.headline_main: Review: ‘Dead Poets Society,’ Starring Jason Sudeikis as the Idealistic Teacher

2016-11-18.abstract: Peter Wentz starts our solving weekend with a Scrabbly, crunchy puzzle.
2016-11-18.snippet: Peter Wentz starts our solving weekend with a Scrabbly, crunchy puzzle.
2016-11-18.lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — A terrific start to our weekend by Peter Wentz, with a central stack and intersecting long Down entry that is just awesome. How could you not like GINGERBREAD COLDHEARTED BARMITZVAHS, with CONDOLEEZZA RICE “dropping in”?
2016-11-18.headline_main: The Divine Comedy

2016-11-18.abstract: Towers, an arena, even a salt shed: Over the past decade, the cityscape has been transformed.
2016-11-18.snippet: Towers, an arena, even a salt shed: Over the past decade, the cityscape has been transformed.
2016-11-18.lead_paragraph: The soaring spires, the sloping shores, the straitjacket of the street grid — many things give form to the great metropolis. The skyline may be our most recognizable feature, despite how unrecognizable it can often be.
2016-11-18.headline_main: The New Shapes of New York

2016-11-18.abstract: The move is the latest turn in the scandal involving unauthorized spending at the City University of New York, the largest public urban university in the country.
2016-11-18.snippet: The move is the latest turn in the scandal involving unauthorized spending at the City University of New York, the largest public urban university in the country.

2016-11-18.abstract: Mr. Billings was the first staff director of the Senate environment subcommittee and an alter ego of Senator Edmund S. Muskie, Democrat of Maine.
2016-11-18.snippet: Mr. Billings was the first staff director of the Senate environment subcommittee and an alter ego of Senator Edmund S. Muskie, Democrat of Maine.
2016-11-18.lead_paragraph: Gretchen Garber grew up in Washington State but, afflicted with chronic lung disease, spent vacations with her grandparents in Montana. “By the end of the summer,” she said, “I would be able to stand up straight, finally, and go back to suffer another winter of asthma.”
2016-11-18.headline_main: Leon G. Billings, Architect of Clean Air and Clean Water Acts, Dies at 78

2016-11-18.abstract: Thierry Gourjon spent thousands of hours at Gleason’s, in Brooklyn, and his black-and-white photos portray the sport’s intoxicating swirl of violence and grace.
2016-11-18.snippet: Thierry Gourjon spent thousands of hours at Gleason’s, in Brooklyn, and his black-and-white photos portray the sport’s intoxicating swirl of violence and grace.
2016-11-18.lead_paragraph: Gleason’s Gym, the oldest boxing gymnasium in New York, will move from its address on the Brooklyn waterfront next month. It is moving only a block away, but the relocation leaves behind an era’s worth of sweat and grime that has accumulated in this temple to the sweet science.
2016-11-18.headline_main: At Gleason’s Gym, Years of Sweat and Grime

2016-11-18.abstract: The deal to resettle refugees and asylum seekers held in detention camps in the Pacific might not happen now that Donald J. Trump is the president-elect.
2016-11-18.snippet: The deal to resettle refugees and asylum seekers held in detention camps in the Pacific might not happen now that Donald J. Trump is the president-elect.
2016-11-18.lead_paragraph: CANBERRA, Australia — Barring some unexpected development, none of the refugees held in detention camps on the Pacific islands of Nauru and Manus are likely to be resettled in the United States before President-elect Donald J. Trump takes office, Australian and American officials said this week.
2016-11-18.headline_main: As Trump Nears Office, Australian Deal to Move Refugees to U.S. Is in Doubt

2016-11-18.abstract: The move could put a retired intelligence officer who believes Islamist militancy poses an existential threat in one of the most powerful roles in shaping military and foreign policy.

Flynn, potentially putting a retired intelligence officer who believes Islamist militancy poses an existential threat in one of the most powerful roles in shaping military and foreign policy, according to a top official on Mr. Trump’s transition team.

2016-11-18.abstract: Ms. Gruber, a photojournalist and writer whose career spanned seven decades, often crossed the line from journalist to human rights advocate.

2016-11-18.lead_paragraph: Ruth Gruber, a photojournalist and author who documented Stalin’s gulags, life in Nazi Germany and the plight of Jewish refugees intercepted by the British on the infamous passage of the Exodus to Palestine in 1947, died on Thursday at her home in Manhattan. She was 105.

2016-11-18.snippet: The swindle reeks of bad faith.
2016-11-18.lead_paragraph: Vincent writes: Here in South Jersey, a doughnuts-and-coffee chain offers a promotion. On the day after a Philadelphia Eagles win, customers get a free iced coffee. My wife, a New York Giants fan, will often collect a free coffee, even though she roots against the Eagles. Please bar her from partaking of coffee the Eagles have earned for their fans.
2016-11-18.headline_main: Judge John Hodgman on a Giants Fan Posing as an Eagles Fan

2016-11-18.abstract: Practice on a piece of fruit. Don’t numb the skin.
2016-11-18.snippet: Practice on a piece of fruit. Don’t numb the skin.
2016-11-18.lead_paragraph: “Simplicity is really key in tattoos,” says Talia Migliaccio, a tattoo artist. “It’s about making a mark and how those marks relate to the world around us.” Migliaccio suggests starting with a couple of lines or a meaningful number, something basic, small and easy to execute. Like most people who give tattoos for a living, Migliaccio recommends going to a professional if possible. But if you’re going to do your own stick-and-poke tattoo — which is not unlike a prison tattoo — practice first on fake skin or a piece of fruit to get the feel for needle work.
2016-11-18.headline_main: How to Give Yourself a Tattoo

2016-11-18.abstract: Are you confident that the United States’s constitutional democracy is strong enough to weather whatever challenges may come its way?
2016-11-18.snippet: Are you confident that the United States’s constitutional democracy is strong enough to weather whatever challenges may come its way?
2016-11-18.lead_paragraph: For the second time in less than two decades, the United States elected a president who won the most electors to the Electoral College but lost the popular vote. Yet, Americans’ allegiance to the Constitution is so strong that in both cases, the winner of the popular vote conceded quickly and publicly so that the country could move forward with the peaceful transfer of power.
2016-11-18.headline_main: How Strong Is Your Faith in American Democracy?

2016-11-18.lead_paragraph: When you are raised to be a good Christian girl, you don’t just go to church; you date the church. Church is the significant other with whom you spend weekends and evenings, the boyfriend whose friends become your friends, the girlfriend with whom you share all your dreams.
2016-11-18.headline_main: When Eve and Eve Bit the Apple

2016-11-18.abstract: A sister returns after more than a decade.
2016-11-18.snippet: A sister returns after more than a decade.
2016-11-18.lead_paragraph: When my sister, Maryan, came to Kenya to visit us in the Dadaab refugee camp last spring, it had been 11 years since we had seen her. Our family arrived a quarter-century ago to escape the war in Somalia and has been here since. I was born in the camp, 21 years ago. But in 2005, when I was 9, Maryan and her husband and son were accepted for resettlement in the United States.
2016-11-18.headline_main: The Refugee Camp She Once Called Home

2016-11-18.abstract: The Aarhus Street Food Market serves authentic Danish food — and food from Mexico and Italy, too.
2016-11-18.snippet: The Aarhus Street Food Market serves authentic Danish food — and food from Mexico and Italy, too.
2016-11-18.lead_paragraph: “It’s Danish Christmas in a sandwich,” said Mads Ravn, a Danish archaeologist, about the flaeskesteg sandwiches we were devouring. Flaeskesteg, the Christmas dinner of Denmark, is pork with a rind that’s been roasted to a crispy crackling. At Stegen & Dellen, a vendor at the new Street Food Market in Aarhus, it’s served year-round on a pillowy brioche bun slathered in mayonnaise and topped with bracing red kraut and long curls of pickled cucumber, wrapped in butcher paper (and, in this case, washed down with a Midtfyns Stout from a neighboring vendor, Olfred).
2016-11-18.headline_main: At a Danish Street Market, Flaeskesteg and Tacos

Trump won 4.1 percent of the vote in the District of Columbia. Washington does not pine for him.

2016-11-18.lead_paragraph: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. — Dev Patel wanted the lead role in the forthcoming film “Lion” so badly that he showed up at the Los Angeles home of the screenwriter Luke Davies in 2013 to plead for the part. From the moment the young actor heard of the project, he had been intrigued by its improbable story and conflicted hero. The director Garth Davis was there, too, and the three settled in over fresh ginger tea. But then Mr. Patel noticed a whiteboard covered in a blizzard of Post-its. He looked at the notes. “I was like, wait, you haven’t done the script yet?” he said.
2016-11-18.headline_main: Dev Patel Tapped His Inner Alpha for ‘Lion’

Debbas, a partner at the boutique law firm Romer Debbas, was representing a couple buying a Manhattan condominium who wanted the option to back out of the deal if Donald J. Trump won the election. After Mr. Debbas explained that no seller would agree to such a contingency, they signed the contract and took their chances.

2016-11-18.lead_paragraph: SUKHUMI, Georgia — He is blind in one eye and has a bad hip that makes it painful to sit, never mind endure the kicks and punches that are an essential part of his job as a mixed martial arts fighter. He is also nearly twice the age of many of his rivals at the top of his harrowingly brutal profession.

2016-11-18.snippet: The broadcast of the awards started with a postelection statement and then continued with an honor for Marc Anthony and a broad array of performances.
2016-11-18.lead_paragraph: The 17th annual Latin Grammy Awards broadcast started with a postelection statement: “Tu Enemigo” (“Your Enemy”). It’s a duet, originally released in 2015, by Pablo López, from Spain, and Juanes, from Colombia, with lyrics that reject the demonization of immigrants. “Don’t ask me what I came for/Better ask yourself how you got here,” Juanes sang, backed by a white-robed choir and a team of drummers while Cirque du Soleil aerialists writhed overhead.

2016-11-18.abstract: Can anything be done to rein in an industry that sucks millions of dollars out of Australians’ pockets?
2016-11-18.snippet: Can anything be done to rein in an industry that sucks millions of dollars out of Australians’ pockets?
2016-11-18.lead_paragraph: Australia tops its fair share of lists, including hosting the deadliest animals on earth and, perhaps paradoxically, some of the world’s most livable cities. But the country also tops the charts on an indicator that is far more insidious: gambling losses. Last year, Australians lost $17.5 billion, or about $949 per adult. These per capita losses are among the highest in the world.
2016-11-18.headline_main: Australia Has a Serious Gambling Problem

2016-11-18.headline_main: Last Wish of Dying Girl, 14, to Be Frozen, Is Granted by Judge

2016-11-18.snippet: Where to eat, sleep and shop in the land down under the land down under.
2016-11-18.lead_paragraph: It’s only a 90-minute flight from splashy Sydney, but the Australian state of Tasmania feels much farther. Part of the island’s haunted, otherworldly mien might be attributable to its geographical and atmospheric particulars: It is, after all, the country’s last defense before Antarctica, and its extreme southerly position means that for much of the year the land is shrouded in a crepuscular light.
2016-11-18.headline_main: In Southern Tasmania, Great Food and Rugged Appeal

2016-11-18.abstract: Our secessionary mood is an emotional reaction to the election of Donald Trump and a reflection of the power of our own brand of liberalism.
2016-11-18.snippet: Our secessionary mood is an emotional reaction to the election of Donald Trump and a reflection of the power of our own brand of liberalism.
2016-11-18.lead_paragraph: San Francisco — THIS is going to sound very California, but here goes: I drowned my election sorrows by surfing. It didn’t help, but I was struck by something afterward. All my life, I’ve seen strangers on California beaches — bearded bodysurfers drinking local Bourbon, Republican volleyball players eating vegan energy bars — trade warm glances that say, “I salute your lifestyle choices and respect your privacy.” After the election, those furtive nods implied nausea, terror and a compassion born of confidence that others felt much the same. Within that compassion, I sensed the emergence of something new in California public life: an awareness that we Californians are bound together as one people by the shared values of our increasingly tolerant and pluralistic society.
2016-11-18.headline_main: I Wish We All Could Be Californian

2016-11-18.abstract: Thinking about the war in Syria reminds me of my grandmother in the 1980s, who tried to make sense of Lebanon’s scarred landscape from her porch.
2016-11-18.snippet: Thinking about the war in Syria reminds me of my grandmother in the 1980s, who tried to make sense of Lebanon’s scarred landscape from her porch.
2016-11-18.lead_paragraph: When I was a child, I spent most summers at my grandparents’ home in the Lebanese mountain village of Roumieh, overlooking Beirut and the Mediterranean coast. From the swing on the veranda, an expanse of umbrella pines and terracotta-roofed villages tumbled steeply toward the sea.
2016-11-18.headline_main: A Lesson in Emotional Geography

2016-11-18.abstract: “Chaos” is the latest Patricia Cornwell novel featuring the iron-willed forensic pathologist Kay Scarpetta.
2016-11-18.snippet: “Chaos” is the latest Patricia Cornwell novel featuring the iron-willed forensic pathologist Kay Scarpetta.
2016-11-18.lead_paragraph: As a world-renowned forensic pathologist, Dr. Kay Scarpetta, the iron-willed protagonist of Patricia Cornwell’s insanely popular procedural mysteries, is often called out of town for high-level professional consultations. That pattern is relaxed in CHAOS (Morrow/HarperCollins, $28.99), which finds Scarpetta at home with her husband, Benton Wesley, a criminal-intelligence agent for the F.B.I., and taking care of business as director of the Cambridge Forensic Center. Although she’s hardly a lyrical writer, Cornwell allows her heroine a rare opportunity to express her affection for Boston, and especially for her favorite park along the Charles River. “I’ve been here many times,” Scarpetta says, with some warmth, recalling hikes with Benton from their home near the Harvard campus in the “sublime” New England weather of the spring and fall.
2016-11-18.headline_main: The Latest and Best in Crime Fiction

2016-11-18.lead_paragraph: A lot of people in politics and the media are scrambling to normalize what just happened to us, saying that it will all be OK and we can work with Trump. No, it won’t, and no, we can’t. The next occupant of the White House will be a pathological liar with a loose grip on reality; he is already surrounding himself with racists, anti-Semites, and conspiracy theorists; his administration will be the most corrupt in America history.

2016-11-18.abstract: For a supposedly neglected cohort, the white working class sure has made its presence felt lately on the best-seller list.
2016-11-18.snippet: For a supposedly neglected cohort, the white working class sure has made its presence felt lately on the best-seller list.
2016-11-18.lead_paragraph: Bloc Party: For a supposedly neglected cohort, the white working class sure has made its presence felt lately on the best-seller list. (And in, you know, the voting booth. But this column is about books, not politics, so let’s take a deep breath and open our chakras; you can turn to the Op-Ed page if you really want to get riled up again.) This year the historian Nancy Isenberg spent 11 weeks on the hardcover nonfiction list with “White Trash,” tracing the role of poor white people from colonial times to the present. Then came J.D. Vance with “Hillbilly Elegy,” a blend of memoir and sociology that’s still selling well — after 16 weeks, it’s No. 3 in hardcover nonfiction. Now here’s Arlie Russell Hochschild, a Berkeley sociologist who got to know Tea Party types in Louisiana for the National Book Award finalist “Strangers in Their Own Land,” new at No. 14 on the hardcover nonfiction list.
2016-11-18.headline_main: The Story Behind This Week’s Best Sellers

2016-11-18.abstract: Ang Lee shot his new movie at 120 frames per second, far faster than the typical 24. It is uncommonly clear. But maybe viewers prefer softer textures.

2016-11-18.lead_paragraph: Ang Lee’s new film, “Billy Lynn’s Long Halftime Walk,” contains sights perhaps never so vividly rendered in a movie. When bullet casings fly from a machine gun, each one is clearly visible rather than appearing in a blur. When Billy Lynn (Joe Alwyn), a soldier on leave from Iraq, tears up at the national anthem or experiences battle flashbacks during the smoke bombs of a Destiny’s Child performance, the emotions in his eyes register with uncommon clarity.
2016-11-18.headline_main: The Images in ‘Billy Lynn’? Razor Sharp. Your Eyes? Bewildered.

Fishermen have protested being told they could not fish, complaining that they have no other means to feed their families. And residents living near Machu Picchu shut down trains to the famous Inca ruins, saying that the company operating the railway is unresponsive to commuters relying on it to get to work.

2016-11-18.lead_paragraph: When “All Def Comedy,” my showcase for up-and-coming black comedians, had its premiere on Nov. 12 on HBO, it brought back memories of “Def Comedy Jam,” its ’90s-era predecessor. In The New York Times, Jason Zinoman wrote an appreciation of the old show, calling it “trailblazing” and “filled with a staggering amount of talent.” While I liked a lot of what he said, he lacked insight on one point: how important a platform like this still is. The new show “arrives in a very different comedy climate,” he wrote, adding, “There are more platforms today” and noting that “the scene is less segregated.”

2016-11-18.abstract: “Confrontation,” opening tomorrow at Museum Berggruen, brings together the American painter’s work and that of modernist masters.
2016-11-18.snippet: “Confrontation,” opening tomorrow at Museum Berggruen, brings together the American painter’s work and that of modernist masters.
2016-11-18.lead_paragraph: When Udo Kittelmann, the director of Berlin’s Nationalgalerie, initially floated the idea of an exhibition that would position George Condo’s work against pieces from Museum Berggruen’s 20th-century art collection, the American painter had some doubts. “Udo said, ‘You make so many modernist references,’ but I didn’t want to have a George Condo at random sitting next to a Picasso or a Matisse,” Condo remembers. “You’d see the absolute differences, as much as it appears to be referential.” Kittelmann spent two full days rummaging through the artist’s New York storage space, finally landing on a nontraditional approach, and convinced Condo to go along with it: The curator cleared out the museum’s 28 rooms, installed his pick of 118 Condo paintings, drawings, collages and sculptures — most never shown before — and then reinstalled parts of the Berggruen’s collection accordingly.
2016-11-18.headline_main: A New Show That Puts George Condo Next to Picasso

2016-11-18.abstract: In this breezy musical at York Theater Company, four friends navigate the 1950s, the 1960s and the inevitability of change.
2016-11-18.snippet: In this breezy musical at York Theater Company, four friends navigate the 1950s, the 1960s and the inevitability of change.
2016-11-18.lead_paragraph: If you’re a theatergoer who prefers to stay in your seat during intermission, rethink that philosophy for “A Taste of Things to Come,” the breezy musical at York Theater Company. There’s something in the lobby you ought to see.
2016-11-18.headline_main: Review: ‘A Taste of Things to Come’ Is a Recipe for Catchy Musical Theater

2016-11-18.abstract: This year has seen the loss of Prince, David Bowie, Merle Haggard, and, now, three more towering figures have died. A look at their legacies.
2016-11-18.snippet: This year has seen the loss of Prince, David Bowie, Merle Haggard, and, now, three more towering figures have died. A look at their legacies.
2016-11-18.lead_paragraph: This year, the world of pop music has been thick with mourning — Prince, David Bowie, Merle Haggard, and too many more. And just in the last couple of weeks, more deaths of towering figures: the melancholy poet Leonard Cohen, in the throes of a late-life creative surge; the revered songwriter and session player Leon Russell; and Mose Allison, a hybridizer of bebop and blues with a wicked streak in his lyrics.
2016-11-18.headline_main: Mourning the Greats: Leonard Cohen, Leon Russell and Mose Allison

2016-11-18.abstract: A lot could go wrong as the C.E.O. attempts to integrate the automaker and the solar-panel company. But indulgent investors are likely to give him a pass.
2016-11-18.snippet: A lot could go wrong as the C.E.O. attempts to integrate the automaker and the solar-panel company. But indulgent investors are likely to give him a pass.
2016-11-18.lead_paragraph: Tesla Motors’ eager shareholders have made Elon Musk too cool to fail. Their decision to back the Silicon Valley billionaire’s quixotic $2.6 billion bid for SolarCity, a solar-panel company run by his cousin, sets up an epic 2017 juggling act. A lot could go wrong as Mr. Musk tries to integrate the two companies without compromising on Tesla’s ambitious production targets. Indulgent investors, though, are likely to give him a pass.
2016-11-18.headline_main: Elon Musk Faces Epic Juggling Act After Tesla-SolarCity Deal

2016-11-18.lead_paragraph: The Museum of Modern Art honored Tom Hanks at its annual film benefit on Tuesday, which was presented by Chanel. 2016-11-18.lead_paragraph: For his bookshop and website One Grand Books, the editor Aaron Hicklin asked people to name the 10 books they’d take with them if they were marooned on a desert island. The next in the series is Ahilan Arulanantham, director of advocacy and legal director at the ACLU of Southern California and a 2016 MacArthur Genius Grant Recipient. He shares his list exclusively with T.

2016-11-19.abstract: Fell running might seem like a masochistic peculiarity of Northern England, but it kept me sane through decades of life on the road.
2016-11-19.snippet: Fell running might seem like a masochistic peculiarity of Northern England, but it kept me sane through decades of life on the road.
2016-11-19.lead_paragraph: LEEDS, England — I’m just back from a run. An hour with friends from my running club, along a forested ridge close to my home, with various loops, climbs and scrambles, at night, wearing headlamps. The lack of sun at this time of year seeks to keep us on lighted roads, but here’s the first nighttime run of the autumn season; we kick through wet leaves, skip over slippery tree roots and jump from boulder to boulder as we cross the hill’s crest.
2016-11-19.headline_main: I Get Knocked Down by the Hill, but I Get Up Again

2016-11-19.abstract: Fake news should be shunned, but the discussion of it misunderstands a new media world in which every story is at risk of being discredited, not by argument but by sheer force.
